If we want to restore integrity to our election systems and secure our votes from tampering, we must break our addiction to speed and leave the super-vulnerabilities of the electronic system behind. Kevin Roose's article posted in the NYT today is worth reading on this topic: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/04/technology/election-tech.html. Roose writes that there is a "silver lining" in what so many are mistakenly calling a "Democratic debacle" in Iowa: "When it comes to the actual business of registering and counting people’s votes, many of the smartest tech experts I know fiercely oppose high-tech solutions, like “paperless” digital voting machines and mobile voting apps. After all, every piece of technology involved in the voting process is a possible point of failure. And the larger and more interconnected the technical system, the more vulnerable it is to an attack." We need to keep this in mind during the primary process and as we prepare our nation for the critical November voting. Let's make sure that in every state there is, at minimum, a real paper ballot and tallying process--whether it's the main process or a validation check on fallible electronic systems now in place and too late to change. See also an article in The Atlantic on the drive to secure the integrity of our votes by sticking with paper ballots and tallies: https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/12/guardian-of-the-vote/544155/
Excellent writing and analysis Frank, including the “kidney stone” metaphor. Priceless!

Some vague mythos of "Iowa" is now the false scapegoat for everything wrong with the nominating process.  The comment box doesn't have space for all the examples, so I'll just drop one from here in the NYT

David Leonhardt proclaims Iowa "has already helped doom two black candidates (Cory Booker and Kamala Harris)." That's just totally false. They dropped out because they couldn't raise money, and if opinion polls played into that, they were either national polls or polls of SC where neither Booker or Harris could make even a little dent in black support for Joe Biden – the old, white, male, old-school, purplish regular guy candidate. You know, the one who fits the Iowa demographics all those pundits are saying should disqualify it from having a caucus. The one the who nevertheless seems to have finished no better than fourth in the state that established, yes, that barrack Obama was a viable alternative to Hilary Clinton in 2008.

Anyway, the real problem here is that all the people complaining about Iowa are the same people who created this mythical Iowa in the first place, the people obsessed with who "wins" a process that doesn't even claim to have winners and losers, the people who commission opinion poll after opinion poll to generate "hot" news copy, the people who turn a modest process of apportioning a few delegates into a massive hype. If you think that would be any different if/when another state goes first, you're sadly mistaken.

The frustration with the Democratic primary system is not new, but it seemed as though everyone felt powerless to change it, even the candidates. Over fifty years ago when I studied the Democrats attempt to democratize their presidential  nominating process after the disaster of the 1968  Democratic Convention, the Caucus seemed at the time an acceptable alternate democratic process to primaries.  Their shelf life seems up.  Beside the latest problems in Iowa, there are also states where both caucuses and primaries are held with the more democratic primary being only a 'beauty pageant"  and the delegates actually come out of the caucus.  Primaries with extended voting allow much greater participation with few of the problems we see in Iowa, and it also less likely that a dedicated army of a candidate's partisans can cancel the popular vote pick by overwhelming a caucus.  This happened in two states in the 2016 campaign.   Its times to  replace the  " democratish"'  Caucus  with  the more democratic primary.

For the future:

Let New Hampshire have their "First in the Nation" primary, but they have to share it with another, more diverse state from another region of the country, say, North Carolina. The following week Iowa and another more diverse state from another region, say, California, have their primaries on the same day.

I am up for a "National Primary Day". I am up for a series of Super-Tuesdays. I am up for anything that gets rid of the "caucus" system and organizes voters who are actual Democrats to choose who their standard-bearer will be. It needs to be fairness all around. Diverse and Non-diverse together. Urban, exurban and rural. Everything. Make the process simple, easy & democratic: one person, one vote.

At this critical moment the most important thing is to get rid of Trump and McConnell and the corrupt republican senate. Don't let a tof like Brad Parscale make you a cynic. Sorry, Iowa. You need to let the caucus system go for the good of the country.

Everybody makes mistake and this was just one of them. However what is inexcusable is to not have tested the software, corrected the problems, and taught the people who were supposed to use it on how to use and have the reps from the software company on the ground to do tech support.

What still escapes me is why the democratic Party cannot have a one day national primary a couple of months ahead of the general election. Compress the heck out of the process, save money and anxiety. 

If ever we wanted to have good candidates to run for election the American system is quite possibly the worst example of how to keep the good people out of it. A two plus year campaign effort will test even the most determined candidate.

Hopefully this will be enough to finally end this insane tradition of a tiny, white farm state going first. And maybe even end the caucus all together. What every state needs is an all mail open primary. Works great in Colorado. No having to stand in line or leave your house (so the disabled, working, or parents can actually take part), paper trail for each ballot, you can vote early...

Remember too that Brad Parscale, Trump and "the rest of his wretched gang" are bums and are grasping at straws to cover up any examination of the destruction they've done to our Republic. In time they will only get more desperate and mean, and Lord knows to what degree the incompetent clown at the top of the ticket will melt down in public and on Twitter between now and then. Two simple statements that would address most structural problems this country is facing:

1. One person, one vote.

Ad 2: Fair taxation that is progressively applied the higher the income, while subsidies and exemptions are categorically denied and eliminated, is the most efficient way to stop the increase in income inequality, which excludes the majority of the population from sharing the country's wealth, and is a safeguard against an oligarchy of billionaires and  corporations.

Caucuses may have served a purpose in a rural, largely illiterate, agrarian past when voters had little else to do in the winter, couldn't read editorials, position papers, ballots etc. but make no sense today. The voting system in America is broken and outdated.
It does not represent all the people fairly.

I would ask the people in charge of election processes in every state to Please:

Leave computer systems out of the process.
Save computer systems for the absolutely final historical documentation of the vote tallies.

These voters are writing their votes down with pen and paper and either mailing in their physical document through our federally protected U.S. Postal Service, or handing it to a local elections volunteer.

This is the person-to-person moment that seals our bond to our country. We need to preserve this intimacy with a limited chain of people who are individually responsible for their role the process.

Web-based communication is essentially anonymous, despite the PIN roadblocks and identity puzzles. Personal responsibility is fairly easy to avoid and flaunting this anonymity has given new meaning to the word "troll".
It's entirely subject to the idiosyncrasies of whoever is writing the specific application's code. How things work in the application will make sense to the coder and the "team" - but it won't necessarily make sense to the tens of millions of Americans who don't do their work in this medium.
And once a communication is released into the web, it is in a global public domain for any interested party - quite a boon for all these cottage industries gathering advertising contracts and scraping up salable data. 

Web-based communication is offered as a "convenience".

Please keep it out of our American elections process.

This country seems to have a knack for overly complicating important things, from healthcare delivery to our election process. Campaigns go on for years and take gazillions of dollars, voting takes the better part of a year, the popular vote is not necessarily reflected in the final results (i.e. Donald Trump). This is nuts, and if anything good comes out of the Iowa debacle it will be the opportunity to reconsider the whole thing. One example to consider as an alternative might be France, which also has a Presidential system. To get the Presidency in France you need over 50% of the popular vote. Voting is on Sunday, which helps working families. There is nothing else on the ballot, just the question of who shall be President. Voting is literally transparent: A clear plastic box at the polling place, in which voters place an envelope containing a card with their preferred candidate's name. There is a first turn, in which all candidates from fringe parties to mainstream get to compete. Counting is done by hand, with representatives of each candidate in the room. After the first turn, unless one of the candidates got 50% of the votes, the two top candidates compete in a second and final turn, held two weeks later.  Totally low tech, hack-proof, and democratic. We could do worse. Actually, we do.

Everyone please stop hyperventilating. The Iowa Democratic Party simply violated the cardinal KISS principle - keep it simple stupid. Their original intent, in the wake of the close vote in 2016 (Clinton 49.9%, Sanders 49.6%), was to insure the integrity of the process by gathering more data on the results in each caucus. Under the old system, only one data point was required: who won each of the 1,600 precincts. In 2020, they required more data: i.e., the numbers of voters caucusing for each candidate in round 1, then the results from round 2 when supporters of candidates with less than 15%, i.e., those deemed non-viable, had to either join another candidate group or leave. Conveying that information required more 'bandwidth' than a simple telephone call so they created an App for that. Only they did it on the cheap and never tested it. KISS. They should have simply saved the paper ballots they had each attendee fill out to create a record in case the vote was too close to call, and just phone in the winner as in years past. KISS. This debacle is not an indictment of the party or the American electoral process. It is simply another example of the road to hell being paved with good intentions.

Rank choice electronic voting. Simple. Effective. Democratic. Basically, a voting method in a related form to a caucus. Iowa should not be first, I will agree with. However, no one should be first. There should be a national primary day, just like there is one national election day. Let the several states run primary elections, caucuses, or whatever method they choose to select candidates, but all at the same time. 

First, it would be more fair. As it stands, some possibly viable candidates are winnowed out because they do not do well in particular states. Also, too many people vote for a candidate in the later primaries not because they necessarily agree with their policies but because they did well in earlier states. 

Second, it would be less expensive. The necessity to restart a campaign after each set of primaries would be gone, it would be one and done. 

The biggest losers to this change would be the media, as they would have to work harder to cover primaries all over the country and would not be able to write innumerable articles about how this state helped that candidate, and that state hurt the other one. Boo Hoo.

The precinct was tied: 2 each to these 4 candidates.

Iowa should not be first in the Democratic primaries. If we’re going to continue with the state by state primary system (as opposed to holding larger - and fewer - primaries by having varied groups of states hold their primaries on the same day and rotate the order every election cycle; think about several Super Tuesdays), then at least pick early states with populations that look like America’s population profile.

As to the caucus system, those who have child or elder care responsibilities; those who work evening or night shifts; those not physically able to participate; and others with equally legitimate conflicts are left out of the equation since it’s a one-night, multiple hour commitment that doesn’t fit the reality of the 21st century lives of many Iowans. 

There are a myriad of reasons why Iowa will kick and bite to keep their first in the nation status, but none that can overcome the national (and political party) shortfalls of maintaining it there.

It is my determination that states like Oregon have the absolute best approach to voting.  When there is an election, scanable paper ballots are mailed to all registered voters with an information packet describing all candidates and initiatives on the ballot.  Once a voter has filled out their ballot they have the option to mail the ballot in, or drop it off in one of many very convienient ballot boxes throughout the state.  No waiting in line for hours in nasty weather, no taking off work and losing income, no vulnerable touch screen machines, and an auditable paper trail.  

From where I am sitting right now there are 7 boxes within 10 miles, the closest is less than half a mile away.

What more could anyone ask for if they want fair elections?

I caucused last night and served as a volunteer.  Over 60 percent of the registered Dems in my precinct showed up, enthusiastically participating in what many of us view as the most important election in nearly a century. Many left saddened by the realization that a caucus cannot simulate a primary when you have 9 candidates, 4 of which have nearly equal levels of support. In my precinct Klobuchar received about 12 percent of the first preference count, but in the end received no delegates. Other candidates probably experienced  similar outcomes in other precincts. My hypothesis is that the leadership expected these discrepancies to average out such that at the county level there would be a close match between the initial preference votes and the distribution of delegates. When this did not happen the first inclination was to look for data errors, and there no doubt were some, but in fact the  real problem was probably that  surprisingly large and awkward discrepancies between the preference counts and the final delegate distribution implied that there were errors when the data was in fact correct.

Hype seems to drive the phenomenon ... people becoming inflated in their importance about something, by the press reporting on this as importance; and then back to inflating the people who become even more frenzied than before in their considered authority; and then back to the press; etc. Our insecurities, revealed in arrogance of this kind, are hurting us badly. It is time for the parties to take control of the primary/caucus process. Candidate selection should provide opportunities for candidates, particularly those with limited upfront resources and modest name recognition. This can be done by having a small number of primaries initially, with more states having primaries later on in the selection process. 

This can be done by having four primary dates at six-week intervals, starting in February and ending in May, with five states in the initial primary, then 10, 15 and 20 in the other three primaries. 

The five states should be diverse geographically, politically, and should as an aggregate reflect the nation's diversity. The remaining primary groupings should also have a balanced representation overall. There should be no more caucuses. Iowa and New Hampshire should not be granted special dispensation. 

Ballot security is essential. Voting should be on paper ballots. States that don't use paper ballots should not be permitted to hold a primary election unless they use paper ballots. This will encourage recalcitrant states to get on board. 

It is essential that the candidate selection process be structured in a way that encourages a diverse candidate field at the outset and winnows down the field in a rational (relatively speaking) way. Paper ballots will ensure the integrity of the results. If the current fiasco in Iowa doesn't provide the impetus for change, I can't imagine what would?

And why no mention of Warren, but Klobuchar gets a shout-out even though she trails the top four? Is the press already trying to write Warren out of the narrative? 

There are months to go yet. One party is attempting to address long-standing problems with the primary process. They are trying to fix a system that turned off voters in 2016 who thought it was unfair. They are putting their candidates through a test of their abilities to campaign and message.

And the other side?

They are crushing dissent in their party. They are rigging the process everywhere they can. Money is flooding the system thanks to their legal assaults that turned dark money loose. They are purging likely Democratic voters, restricting voting, refusing to secure our elections. They have gerrymandered like mad, and packed the courts with judges who OK it. They lie about all this - and the press ignores it.

We are supposed to hope we can vote Trump out - when he just got a pass on rigging the election from the GOP?

Silver lining here. 

Yes, it's a mess. And it's a shame because a lot of people spent several hours together being good citizens, and some traveled considerable distances to get there. Many of them have already put a lot of effort into supporting the candidate they believe will be best for America. They deserved better.

But the votes will be counted and the system created a paper trail that will make it possible to be sure the results are accurate. 

The silver lining part is that we have had a sharp lesson in voting security. We have seen that systems for managing elections need to be tested thoroughly for security and reliability and scalability before we depend on them to decide our future. And we see that we are still at a stage where a paper trail is absolutely necessary.  

The process of evaluating and acquiring software requires expertise, and I don't know how many of the people responsible for doing it have the requisite skill sets or resources for testing, or access to those who do. 

So what we have here is an instance of a system being tested to destruction and probably failing safe because of all of those signed paper ballots. And people who think the Iowa vote is unrepresentative and the state too small for the vote to mean much, can take comfort in the fact that it happened here and not in Michigan or Indiana or California.

Nothing surprises me about the Unholy Mess in Iowa. Like the rest of the world, Iowa is caught between old world and digital election practices. The former is prone to errors in miscounting and reporting. The latter and is replete with fears of hacking, errors committed by computer illiterate people, and crooked developers who can design an app to deliver predetermined results in a clandestine manner. So what are we to do.

Most importantly, we need to do what businesses and statisticians do everyday: find ways to triangulate and validate data. This translates into developing a variety of ways to measure the vote that can be looked at in tandem to get an accurate result. Moreover, by using such simple statistical and research techniques, such as data triangulation, you build in ways to verify the results of several measurements. So if you have doubts about the validity of the results, you have a few methods that can be analyzed alone for their reliability and also in tandem. At least in that way you can average the results across three different methodologies if there is reason to doubt the validity of the data.

Putting aside the embarrassing lack of diversity which is not representative of the nation in any way, and the incompetence of last night, can we once and for all admit that the antiquated and absurd caucus process needs to be put down.

The spectacle of caucus goers whose first candidate isn't "viable" in that particular gym running over to join another candidate's tribe while being followed by TV crews is a travesty of considered and thoughtful democracy. It is more like a party game than a primary. 

And the impact of those TV crews inserting themselves in to the process as it is happening cannot be ignored. The power of instant albeit fleeting celebrity on the otherwise anonymous participants was clear to anyone watching.  Are we all now living in a reality show? 

Can we not just have a vote?! These issues are actually important!

Actually, the stakes are not that high, and that is the point. 

Starting with small states is ideal because everyone who was not on the fringes has time to recover. Candidates who are on the fringes can rarely afford the cost of campaigning in a very large state without spending 100% of their effort there. Starting with a caucus and not a primary adds to the minimization of Iowa's importance. I do not support Bloomberg, but he is no dummy and he has decided he does not need delegates from the first 4 states.

The most important feature of an "early state" is not a national-average-level of diversity or even a working app tonreport results, it is being small enough that campaigning there is not all about massive amounts of money. Our first four states are like that and each represents a different region of the country. It is a pretty good but imperfect system - the kind that good engineers might leave alone because the downside risk of a change outweighs the possible benefit of going from good to great.

There is another factor - Iowa has a history of being first. Our politics are so messed up and hyper-analyzed, what entity could agree on which state is first and stick to that agreement over time? 

Much like thinking present-day electric cars in America will actually fight climate change, blaming the state of our politics on the odd sequencing of primaries is between being useless and being outright counter-productive.

In an age when the GOP is working to make it harder for legitimate citizens to vote, the Iowa caucus is the Democratic contribution to the stone soup. The single mother who has to pick up her children from daycare and take them home and feed them cannot attend.  The healthcare workers on 2nd and 3rd shift cannot attend.  The elderly couple who have given up driving at night cannot attend.  And maybe the guy who doesn't want to get into a confrontation with his neighbors who are slavishly devoted to a different candidate is intimidated into not going.  Let's move past this cabal and try to ensure that it doesn't happen again.

I have participated in the Iowa Caucus, and the biggest problem has always been human errors. A NYT reporter said one precinct made a mistake calculating viability (286 total x15%) causing a do-over. On Twitter, a secretary of a precinct reported that his district was awarding 2 delegates each to Sanders, Warren and Buttigieg. But the totals were 111, 83 and 49... So how can that be right?

A Warren caucus-goer told her campaign, people were allowed to vote in the first count and then go home if they needed/wanted to if their group was "viable." But then in the second-round count, those people were not counted. 

It's important that transparency has been put into place as a safeguard against these human errors that have no doubt been part of the Iowa Caucuses forever. We are just now finding out how many errors happen. But, really, why are we doing this? Iowa has about 700,000 registered Democrats compared to around 645,000 Republicans. Voters claiming independent outnumber both parties at just under 750,000 voters. The expected number, willing to caucus for their candidates = 200,000.

Is it just me, or am I seeing a lot of Bloomberg Astroturfing in the NYT comment section? I wasn't seeing this before the Super Bowl, but now I see that practically every third comment is pro-Bloomberg. I'm not saying that it's impossible that Bloomberg could increase in popularity so quickly on the NYT, but the fact that there are stump comments all over the place makes me more than a little suspicious. 

For those who don't know, Astroturfing is basically paying commenters to say things on a 'free' comment section to advertise a good or service. And the speed with which I have seen Bloomberg comments blow up usually would indicate someone is being paid to make them.

This is HUGE in an election year. Remember that you can be influenced by comment sections. If you see a pile of comments with similar messages that seem shoehorned into the conversation, look at the sentence structure. Verify that you're reading unique comments Meddling doesn't just happen on Facebook.

Chapter III of Lewis Caroll’s “Alice in Wonderland” contains what strikes me as a fit description of the Iowa Caucus:

—“What is a Caucus-race?” said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it thought somebody ought to speak, and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.

—“Why,” said the Dodo, the best way to explain it is to do it,”  (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, i will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)

—First it marked out a race course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there.  There was no “One, two, three, and away.” but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over.  However, when they had been running half an hour or so, and were qjuite dry again, the Dodo sddenly called out “The race is over!” and they all crowded around it, panting, and asking, “But who has won?”

—This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence.  At last the Dodo said, “Everybody has won, and all must have prizes.”

To run a caucus properly, all you need are pencils, paper and above all, the desire to do it right. Have everyone get together, discuss among themselves which candidate would be best and why. Then vote while everyone hangs around. Tabulate the votes. Double-check the results. (Save your work!) Announce the results. Then repeat the process. Everyone goes home before midnight, and the results announced in the morning.

This isn't three dimensional chess. Or even two dimensional chess. It's more like keeping a bowling score.

It looks to me like an epic media failure, not a failure of the method.  Get over instant results, and poll taking.  Te election selection will happen when the party leadership is certain of its results.

An app failed to live up to its promise but that is not the issue.

We really need to modernize our primaries and have a common system across the country!

It seems to be the app that caused the holdup.  They should have counted votes and phoned it in as they always have.

Poll watchers in the coming primaries and eventual election beware.  Paper ballots or a paper trail are crucial.

It's a mess, but it's also one that's revealed, not for the first time, the lack of any sense of affiliation or loyalty on the part of Bernie's supporters when it comes to Democratic Party.  A little set back - victory parade delayed - they begin attacking the host and imagining conspiracies that rival pizza gate. It's good for Democrats to find out now where they really stand with Bernie supporters, and to know they run away with the ball like they did the last time should the object of their heart's desire not become the nominee.

Well, just the gift that keeps on giving and giving, that's all -- Democrats in 2020, handing Trump every victory they can possibly find.  Impeachment, Iowa Caucuses, State of the Union, Acquittal -- what's next, cancelling the rest of the primaries and the coronation of dream ticket Clinton and Bloomberg?

.

My goodness, what an unmitigated disaster. Tens of thousands of hours spent by campaign volunteers over the last many months, tens of millions of dollars spent by candidates and PACs.

Why? Not because Iowa is even remotely important in terms of actual numbers. Out of the 4,366 delegates at the national convention, Iowa will send … 56. They are a rounding error. 

Obviously it is because it is first. The first moment when the rubber starts hitting the road. When the perpetually shifting uncertainties of polls gets replaced by voters casting actual votes. 

So the reason for outsized expenditure of time and money is 100% about being able to claim "momentum". It isn't the moon, but it is the launch pad ships take off from to get there. Given that function, its primary role is to be rock solid. 

Iowa people actually are. They take it very seriously. Caucusing is HARD. Way more than showing up at a ballot box (or these days just mailing it in). A lot of Iowans try to see all the candidates in person. 

But the process here is a nightmare. You can't launch rockets from rickety wooden platforms built on sand. Not only due to the delay, but because the delay is based on what they call "inconsistencies". Anyone that loses, or doesn't win as big as expected will immediately claim it was rigged. (Imagine Sander's supporters, for instance, if he doesn't win big - they are already pre-disposed to believe the deck is stacked against them.)

This is chaos.

This debacle reminds me of the rollout of the horrific beta version of the ACA website "healthcare.gov".  That mess could have killed Obamacare if some creme de la creme techies weren't recruited to come and fix the problems.   There are actually similarities in the Iowa app-fiasco and healthcare.gov.   Neither was properly tested and both were rolled out way too fast.  Iowa shouldn't be testing a "new app" the month of the caucuses.  

Six months ago, it should have been put on a release schedule starting with maybe 10 precincts.  There should have been sufficient user training (could have used Skype or Facetime to do this across Iowa).   Then the fault tolerance of the system should have been tested by shutting down software and servers.  Stress testing of the backup phone lines should have been performed.  The security of the app should have been vetted by third-party pros.   After all the kinks in the 10 test precincts were worked out, the rollout should have been expanded over 3-4 months until all 1700 precincts were online and fully tested.

I suspect none of that happened.

given all we've been through with 2016 and Trump's efforts to corrupt this election, I'm surprised to, at first glance, see no comments suggesting Putin or the POT pulled something here.  Do we know there wasn't some kind of sabotage?  It's clear Trump  will do whatever he has to to corrupt elections, and Putin certainly feels free to as well considering the US President's defending his 2016 actions and Moscow Mitch's protection of his actions as well by refusing to bring any bills to protect our elections to the floor.
I read once that in ancient Greece the leaders of the government were chosen randomly from a group designated as capable. Has Iowa returned us to that system ? I like it.

The real problem is that the Iowa debacle completely contradicts the progressive narrative: the system is broken, Trump is incompetent, trust us, we can fix it.  And tonight, in his State of the Union, Trump will continue to contradict the narrative by talking about the strength of the economy.  Hopefully the results come out before his speech.

Sounds more like the Sanders victory was to much for the Corporate wing of the Democratic party so they hide a major poll the day before the caucus. Then when Sanders would take a win they muddied it so they can say it doesn't count. After 2016 I would not put anything past the corrupt Corporate wing of the party. This is still Hillary's party after all.

The Democrats are determined to continually change the rules for primaries and caucuses until they get the result they want - any nominee that’s not Bernie Sanders. President Trump versus Bernie Sanders will be a landslide victory for Mr. Trump. In addition any hopes of retaking the Senate for the Democrats will be swept away.

Having serial primaries in the first place is ridiculous, however the choices are tallied. The results in an initial handful of primaries shouldn't be able to influence the rest of the election---who gets press coverage, who gets donor money. Either have all the primaries the same day, just like regular elections, or do away with them entirely and let everyone show up in November and rank their choices

Yes, the infrastructure breakdown is, frankly, awful,  but worse to me this morning was reading about one Iowa voter, after her candidate didn't reach the threshold, she walked out of the gym. She refuse to vote for anybody else because, she claimed, nobody else could beat Trump. To me, that's far more devastating - both for our party and for our country. Voters -we did not do our jobs in 2016 to keep Trump out of office-we must never, ever let that happen again. Vote!
Just how difficult is it to count a group of people standing in a certain area of a gym floor and report that number?
"There’s no excuse for this, not given how long the Iowa Democratic Party had to prepare...." Exactly.

A little perspective, please. A mess, sure, but not the carnage of a major accident on the interstate during the commute hour. Iowa will still assign its delegates, which is the true point of the exercise. Iowans don't owe any candidate momentum going into New Hampshire. They don't owe the media a gorgeous Broadway opening. Iowans owe themselves better than they got, and I am sure this morning they are disappointed and embarrassed, but come on, take the outrage pot off the burner.

As a former Iowan, this should be the end of Iowa caucus as first in the nation, and maybe of the caucus system itself for Iowa.  
As a current New Yorker, I don't get to vote until the primary results are essentially decided.
Paper ballots for everywhere in the country.  Rotating "first in the nation" primaries.

Things happen. Life is full of glitches. Fine. But Iowa has had three plus years to plan for this. And the caucus system is a relic of a bygone era. Time to scrap Iowa as the first primary state and their archaic practice. Too much importance is placed on this place in the grand scheme of things.

Goodness, a simple count and a phone call. Or a spreadsheet and email of results. Or drive the results to Des Moines. How difficult can democracy be? Is this the first time we've done this? Even my kids can count to 100, multiple times if needed. This is the United States of America!

I don't understand the overreaction. Yes, there were problems with the over-engineered systems put in place, and the "talking heads" were visibly frustrated at having to go to bed without having their chance to pontificate on why the winner won. But it's not the end of the world. Life goes on. An overly complex system failed under strain, but no lives were lost, and neither (it appears) was any of the data. Given that, there is nothing wrong with waiting a day to ensure the totals are tallied correctly. It's human error, not a grand conspiracy or some pseudo-supernatural harbinger of future chaos.

There are lessons to be learned here, surely, but the sky is not--I repeat IS NOT--falling.

I think it’s fine to have to wait for results to be tallied, and double- and triple-checked. What matters to me is that the final results be accurate and verifiable with a paper trail. 

Bless the Iowans for slowing down and taking the time to get it right.

My German friend told me they hand count every ballot in front of witnesses in each precinct before sending the tallies on. The voters don’t get the results until the next day, but everything is transparent and not vulnerable to hacks.

On the national level, we have failed to attend to election security. That is the real story.

On the bright side, many voters complained Iowa needed to come down a peg. Well, Iowa is down a peg. Whatever the results, good or bad, the delay makes the impact less dramatic. This isn't necessarily a bad thing. If anything, Iowa just made an excellent case for removing their "first in the nation" status. The incident is also another example why simple is better. We use paper ballots for a reason.

Unfortunately, yes, Trump will latch onto the incident like a gila monster but who really cares? If not this, something else. If you're participating in a Democratic primary, you probably don't follow Trump's bumbling cascade of invective nonsense. Whoever Trump is speaking to, it's not the people willing to stay up late waiting for caucus results. For them, the insults are just gasoline on a fire.

Finally, Iowa probably won't change the fundamentals of the race no matter when the results are released. Sanders and Biden demonstrate the divide. Warren has enough support to continue. Buttigieg and Klobuchar siphon off Biden votes or not. Everybody else gets to make a concession speech except Bloomberg. That's exactly the same place we were last Tuesday. That's probably the same place we'll be until Super Tuesday.

And anyway, we saw this coming when the Des Moines Register scrapped their poll. I didn't really expect a smooth night. I wasn't disappointed.
Mr. Bruni says it all. It's time we cancel the Iowa fracas and move to a thoroughly democratic process in picking a party nominee.

The more we wring our hands over this as some sort of symbol of disarray, the more the corrupt Republican Party will gloat. Caucuses are chaotic and unreliable by nature and should be discontinued entirely. For now, we should give the Iowa results the tiny bit of significance they deserve and move on. Next time, if there is a next time, we do what Bloomberg did, and skip the Iowa caucuses altogether.

That's what often happens to people connsumed with delusional hatred and blind anger - they can't think and act straight. And seeing how it makes them even angrier and less rational, I predict that we will see more of it in this campaign.

That's what often happens to people connsumed with delusional hatred and blind anger - they can't think and act straight. And seeing how it makes them even angrier and less rational, I predict that we will see more of it in this campaign.

My first thought: if blame has been narrowed down to the new App, perhaps it was pre-programmed to self-destruct on the night of the actual caucuses, even though it may have performed fine in testing. Not exactly hacking, per se, but something like a pre-loaded ticking time bomb, meant to cause exactly what happened. All it would take is one rogue programmer on the development team to insert a last line of code before the App was downloaded by the Party. Or, maybe it’s just more straightforward: Democrats are just as incompetent as they appear. I’m sure Donald Trump won’t hesitate to use his time well at the State of the Union address to get in a few digs.

Maybe it's time to reconsider the entire primary process.  What purpose does meeting the candidates actually serve. Is it so you can shake their hand, see them up close, kick the tires and say you personally met them and knew them when.  Is it still 1885? Should we have a whistle-stop tour.  Let's be truthful.  Is there anything to be learned at a stump speech.  Most of these people are career politicians, they have endless records and position papers. We have an internet, and hopefully thoughtful journalists who can ask relevant questions.  Lets save some money,  have a few nationally televised and streamed debates, let the major press outlets do some in depth interviews.  Have three months in which to advertise, and then hold a one day primary. Let each candidate keep the percentage of delegates that they earn and settle it at a convention. And then get out the vote. Vote for the party that most closely reflects your ideals and move on. None of these people are so exceptional that it will make that much of a difference. And, most importantly, deliver the House and Senate whenever possible.  The rest of it is merely wasted time.

Human managers (usually local party hacks) have always been able to tamper with both the caucus members, and unverifiable caucus size counts.

The introduction of an app that mathematically computes these numbers appears to have exposed all the inconsistencies and overt cheating that went unseen in the pre-digital age.  

If political parties don't honor one-person/one-vote when selecting candidates,  voters in the general election are deprived of their federally-protected voting  rights.  

One can hope that the winner in this year's final Iowa Caucuses will be Democracy.

Before trashing all local and national elections please understand this important fact.  The Iowa caucuses for BOTH parties are run and managed by the political parties, NOT the highly regulated election processes overseen by the states' elections officials.  The problems in Iowa were caused by party officials who likely know nothing about how to run an election, test the process before caucus day arrives, and implement other controls that ensure confidence in the results.  Elections, primaries and caucuses are extremely complicated and should be run by professionals, not political organizers who may end up under water in a sea of complications.  It's time for Iowa election officials to take control of this mess!

Did the app fail or did the people that were using it not understand how to use it?  The Times just published an article that Iowa truly does reflect America because it has lots of older folks.  Judging form the TV reporting, most of the senior people in the party are older and seniors tend not to be as computer savvy as younger people.  The people that write these apps also tend to assume that the user has certain knowledge and skills that may not have been present here.

Also, it has been reported that people had trouble downloading the app.  That means they had never used it before.  That means there was no dry run.  It was all new and insufficiently tested.  These types of specialty programs can be very finicky.  Everything has to be done in the correct sequence or they fail.  Bad code is everywhere.  

This is a colossal failure of management which just gave the GOP a powerful talking point.  Count the ballots by hand and manually tally the results.  This is no way to pick a president.

Not the best omen perhaps. Now those who wish to pile on Iowa have a legitimate reason. Certainly the endlessly repeated canard about Iowa being unrepresentative of the country, too old, too white, too agrarian, should be put to rest. The vote there will show the same breakdown between moderate and more progressive voters that you would get anywhere in the country. The point is not one's age or race when it comes to voting but how one thinks that matters.

The States are little banana republics when it comes to the "technology" associated with voting.  The script has been written so many times it's an absolute joke at this point, and it's followed to a "T" every four years.  At the 11th hour, a State suddenly discovers that its system for tallying/checking ballots doesn't work, and everything -- including the results of a presidential election -- simply descends into chaos.

This is what happens thanks to a clause in our very, very flawed Constitution that leaves the handling of elections to individual States instead of to the federal government.  You would think at this point that Congress would set minimum standards for recording and disseminating voting totals, with States free to set even higher standards, but that, of course, would be too sensible and, god forbid, might somehow hurt Republican candidates.  Trump has felt free to tell California what it can and can't do with respect to in-state auto emissions, but boy, when it comes to voting, it's States' Rights all the way down.

Iowa is a bad joke.  It should be booted to last on the election counter -- the sooner the better.

If there was ever a case to scrap the existing state driven primary process and replace it with a national primary for the presidential election, where all states vote at the same time, by the same rules, Iowa has bolstered such a case. Given the number of candidates, perhaps two or three such primaries, with the top vote getters advancing to the next round. That couldn't be worse than this debacle.

Thank you SO much for holding the Iowa Democratic Party accountable for this, and refusing to accept both the situation and their effort to lie their way to like their way out of it.

I watched the caucuses on CNN last night.  I saw caucus officials report they were unable to use their app, and one guy waiting on hold to report his results by phone get hung up on, right in front of a CNN camera.   At midnight caucus officials were still saying they couldn't report their results.

Then the Iowa Democratic Party announced there were no problems with the app or the phone, they were just doing two completely different versions of insuring accuracy.   

I have increasingly run into this commercially; the attitude seems to be it's perfectly cool for the IT, the web site, or important features of the web site not to work, for months, or even years.  I just had a weeks long battle with Ancestry.com, who told me if I continue using their web site I use it as is! 

I'm sure the Iowa Democratic Party doesn't even understand yet that the entire country thinks the whole thing even matters.

I think the biggest takeaway from last night is that turnout seems to be on par with 2016, far below the record set in 2008. If the mission is to beat Trump, it does not look like that motivation is there.

It is unfortunate to read all of the people in the comments show their hatred for a "flyover" state. If anyone is wondering why Trump was elected, this is it. Continuously telling an entire state that they do not represent America is exactly why people in these states have chosen to abandon the Democratic party.

They have voting machines and a proven system of reporting results developed over time, yet they cling to the past while the rest of the World progresses forward.  That pretty much sums up the problem we have with a segment of our population in America....they don't know how to adapt.

Iowa has just surrendered its place as the first state where aspiring Democratic presidential candidates begin to gather votes on the road to the convention.
I trust that the Democratic Party at the state and national levels adopt more effective ways to develop leaders representative of the party, organize those of us who are members of the party, and move into the age of electronic election culture.
The debacle in Iowa--breathtakingly incompetent.

It’s just a caucus, folks, months away from the election. There are no easy answers in this election season, and Iowa wouldn’t have clarified things that much anyway, even with all the hype. So...fix this...and move on.

I believe that, between this Iowa debacle and the changing debate rules, Tom Perez should do the honorable thing and resign. 

The debate rules could not be changed to allow Andrew Yang on stage even though there were not enough “approved” polls between debates to qualify for that next debate.

However, now the DNC is changing the rules to have Michael Bloomberg on the debate stage. 

Then the Iowa caucus process really leads me to question the results. 

So in general I have little confidence in the fairness of selecting a Democratic nominee.

My gut feeling is that the delay is an excuse for the DNC to game the Iowa caucus to work against Sanders.  His strong showing may have stunned or even frightened the corporatists who cring at the very sound of "socialist", whether it is used as modifying a noun in Bernie's case or as a formal noun by itself(as in Eugene V. Debs, the 1920 Socialist candidate from Indiana).   And so they elevate their preferred candidate, who is obvious even with Trump.  I'm hoping this isn't going to end up as a circular firing squad.

Soon Trump will be investigating the Sanders graft and corruption, and his obsession with Biden's "corruption" will be conveniently transformed into a 'nothing burger' as the political winds shift further to the left.

The Iowa caucus.  First contest in the nation for no particular reason.  A caucus, for no particular reason.  Bizarre rules.  Weighted towards rural whiter older folks.  And now the questionable event has been executed badly.

My question is, will there be a change or is this just another case where we are stuck in a status quo?

Tom Perez has been the DNC chair for 3+ years. Does he or anyone on his team ever pay attention to detail? It’s called dotting the “i’s” and crossing the “t’s.” Old-fashioned stuff that comes back to bite hard when ignored.
Haven’t read all the comments, but this Iowa thing is actually pretty funny. A party that desperately wants to beat the incumbent President, can’t even organise its first nominating contest.

Why, why, *why* would the Iowa Democratic Party roll out a brand new app and try to use a brand new count method this year of all years? What was wrong with the way they did it in 2016? Or any election year before that? Were there ever any indications of improprieties or inaccuracies? No? 

Then I ask again: why would they decide to mess with a tried and true method right now? They'll be lucky if they don't lose their place as first state for caucus voting with this debacle. And they'd deserve to.

It's not the candidates fault that this Iowa 'Dog and Pony show'
was chaotic. Most folks will realize it eventually. It's time to restructure the primary process. Enough with Iowa and New Hampshire having a disproportionate influence and the media
coverage giving it more significance than is warranted.

One positive note: Finally Iowa may consider ditching the caucus system and look to adopting another, much better, cheaper, and quicker one.
Look to Oregon's vote by mail system if you want one that is cheaper than most voting systems, is very dependable as it has a paper trail, and the results can be quickly known.
Of course, if I can offer Evan more unsolicited advice...Democratic Party, please consider having the voting follow time zones, not this goofy patchwork that you are using now. This isn't 1820, it is 2020, and elections are all we have between us and Trumpist authoritarianism. 
Hugh

The lesson is easy to discern.
Get technology out of voting.
Paper ballots, counted by hand. Yes, we have to wait a little longer for results.
It won't kill us.

If you want to know who is responsible for all of this then look no further than the fact that the Socialist candidate's campaign pushed through the unwieldy system of three separate result tallies in place of a single one. This has resulted in the mess we have today.

Otherwise, we would have had the results last night.

It is just a preview of what their effect on the country would be if he were in the WH.

After all of the months of anticipation, media coverage, and many millions of dollars spent THIS is what results from the Democratic caucus in Iowa?  A great display of incompetence, which Trump and his henchmen will gladly gloat about and use to remind all Americans why any Democrat should not be president.

Two things should come out of this:

- This should be the last time Iowa is given the honor of being the first state in the caucus/primary process.

- All involved in the selection, administration, and application of the vote tabulation systems in Iowa should lose their jobs.

This might be a good opportunity to look back to 2015 and 2016, and to understand how an inexperienced Republican candidate could prevail against experienced, moral hopefuls. No one has had the courage to really investigate. It might just explain the Iowa mess today. Polls? Media hype? The Moscow effect? Last laugh? Perhaps individual voters should take the lead, and demand paper ballots, demand that media be restricted from any reporting at least a few days before a vote, and other measures which might restore the purity of the vote. Refuse to share with pollsters, protect personal privacy. Use of Apps? C'mon, a voting app is as accurate as a dating app. Catfishing, anyone?
I don't belong to an organized political party. I'm a Democrat.

Run by Democrats for Democrats, its a rigged game built for a multi purpose outcome. There has been significant movements inside the DNC  of powerful past and present operatives representing dark horses to seize control at the convention in Wisconsin. The Iowa debacle simply sets up a scenario at the convention where the insider DNC committee will crown their chosen one, a candidate who did not even run in Iowa.

Britain’s Conservative Party selected a new leader in a little over a month in the Autumn of 2019, the new leader went on to win a landslide victory in Dec 2019 after a six week campaign.  Can anyone seriously argue that the order of magnitude longer time scales required in the US produce demonstrably better results.  It is high time for a radical reform of the entire system.

There were reports that a special app used to transmit vote totals had malfunctioned. Who built the app and how it had been deployed? Ironically, it was introduced in order to “get results out to the public quicker” and had been “hastily put together” over the last two months. There had been security concerns from the start, and when NPR questioned the state party chairman, he “declined to provide more details about which company or companies designed the app, or about what specific measures have been put in place to guarantee the system’s security”. Ironically, it was apparently developed by a firm literally called “Shadow”, partly funded by the Pete Buttigieg campaign.

If you’re a Sanders supporter, you have reason to be suspicious. We had already seen the Des Moines Register suppress the results of its “gold standard” poll on the eve of the election, after a complaint from Buttigieg. And with 0% of caucus results in, Buttigieg declared himself “victorious”, praising the “incredible result” and saying Iowa had “shocked the nation”. The only thing that had shocked the nation at this point was Iowa’s total inability to perform the relatively simple task of counting people’s votes. But Buttigieg, good McKinseyite that he is, was getting a head start on deploying the PR spin.
I rather the Iowa Dems get it right than get it fast. It is not ideal but what would be worse is having the result questioned as to its legitimacy.

We'll recover. 9 months is like 2 years in American politics. The only candidates hurt by this mess are the 'old guard' of the Democratic Party, as this 'glitch' is proof-positive of the need for new blood at the top. This opens the door for Mayor Pete, and I'm fine with that.

The key is to not lose sight of the ultimate goal of unseating Trump, nor to allow this to diminish the enthusiasm and importance of that goal. Learn from your mistakes and move on with a new generation of fresh faces and bold new ideas and solutions to our most pressing problems. That's what progressives do. IMO, this could be the best thing that happened to the Democratic Party since JFK/LBJ. We've had our own 'swamp' to drain and now is the time to do it.

For me,  this is a prime example the Democrats’ problems with rural America and lots of other voters.  There’s a profound cluelessness about how people who don’t live in hi tech super urban areas live their lives. (I’m a democrat.)

This reminds me of the bungled rollout of Obamacare.  The difference is that Obama was smart enough to bring in people and spend money to fix that. 

I dread the possibility that we’re in for a bunch of bad decisions by the Democratic “leadership”, culminating in Trump winning and a bunch of Democrats writing post election books on “what happened.”

Maybe in the long run this will cause Iowa to change it's rule about being first ballot state. Since it's not an ethnically - or otherwise - representative state, that might be for the best. (Assuming a 2024 election .... which, as the GOP moves rapidly towards autocracy, is a very daring assumption).

Both parties need to change to a more representative system.   Have 4-6 geographically and demographically diverse states vote at once, having votes every other week.  No more having two rural states winnowing down our candidates.

As far as our so-called electoral system is concerned, many might argue that the situation is serious but still not hopeless. No, to the contrary, the situation is hopeless but not serious, says the cynic in me. Or as the world's greatest cynics, the French, are fond of saying, "plus que ca change, plus que c'est la meme chose."

There's a reason (actually multiple reasons) why other "caucus states" like Minnesota have switched to a primary format:
1. It's undemocratic. In an era where Democrats are pushing for more and easier ballot access, it's hard to imagine a system that rewards activists vs. everyday voters more than this one.
2. It's convoluted. Especially in this year's version of the Iowa caucus, where both raw vote totals and delegate counts are reported, it's hard to figure out the winner. The tech meltdown is the icing on the cake, not the root cause.
3. It rewards peer pressure. Everybody has been in a "show of hands" situation, starting with grade school, where people look around before raising their hands. Is the caucus really that different?
Regardless of the expected results (Sanders on top, Biden tailing, and so forth), nobody can claim victory after this fiasco. Iowa deserves to lose its place in line, unless it commits to a primary format (and paper ballots) in 2024, and that still doesn't address its homogeneous demographics.

If we were sent to monitor a system like this is a developing country we would declare it severely broken. A state with an unrepresentative demographic, bizarre voting times excluding people who work, with small kids, elderly, 17 year olds hopping from group to group like a popularity contest. Come on. Chaos playing right into Trump’s hands.

Just think of all the volunteers and staff who put aside their lives for months to go door to door and participate in every community event. The campaigns that were abandoned before they'd really begun. I am a proud Democrat who is ashamed of my party allowing this to happen. Iowa absolutely can no longer be first. And get rid of the caucuses! I participated in one in Maine, and it was so awkward and uncomfortable I will never be back. The right to vote also includes the right to privacy.

No more caucuses, and Iowa shouldn’t go first.

The Democratic Party should require every state to have a regular, day-long primary. Voters deserve privacy and reasonable access to the ballot, both of which are denied by the caucus system. 

And the country deserves a primary season that begins and ends with fairness and representation of all Americans.

I truly appreciate the value of a neighborly community event around voting. If I lived in Iowa, I would look forward to the caucuses. But the infringement on a clear and fair democratic process cannot stand.

Concur with several of the previous comments.  This latest development begs the question how and why the Democratic Party has left the vetting and grooming of the finalists to the hands of Iowans and the like.  1% of the population and 90% white.(Census Data)

I have the ultimate confidence that with the paper trail that exists the proper result will emerge. If it was all done electronically there would be accusations of a hacked or rigged vote. Paper ballots across the nation should be the norm even if there is a delay that upsets the media, video or print.

This country is giving democracy a bad name.  Iowa always first, New Hampshire always second is a perverse way to begin the nomination process and the whole staggered primary system ensures that the eventual nominee is chosen by less than a majority.  Add to that the gerrymandering of House districts, the two-senators-per state set up, and the Electoral College and you have a creaking anachronistic contraption that guarantees conservative outcomes greater than actual conservative sentiment in the country.

Nothing less than monumental incompetence, I’d say, right up there with the fouled-up pre-caucus poll.

Technical delays, baloney. Lack of alpha testing and beta testing a new system, and extensive training those who were supposed to use it, can only end in abject failure as we witnessed last night and into this morning.

Of course the results, if they ever do emerge, will be contested by the candidates who do poorly, and questioned by anyone with a modicum of intelligence.

If you think those on the right are obsessed with conspiracy theories, wait ‘til you see how those on the left join their ranks.

It’s time to put the Iowa caucuses where they belong, out to pasture.

This debacle gives me more reason to support Mike Bloomberg for President. He recognized the inability of the national Democratic Party to come to grips with the fact that Iowa and New Hampshire (where I used to live) were totally unrepresentative of the population of the country as a whole. His strategy of bypassing the early states shows his intelligence and his ability to provide answers to problems.

I’m not going to trash the earnest people of Iowa. They are doing their best to provide the two extra data points the Sanders campaign insisted on. They are using paper, which is far more reliable than the “technology” that is subject to interference, real and imagined. Patience is a virtue, have it if you can,....

Perhaps the god of the Iowa caucus has run its last con; 48 years was enough for the mortals to catch on.
 Seriously. That a  state with little resemblance to most of the U.S.; four electoral votes that went to Donald J. Trump  should play a hyperbolic role in this country's election- rather obscene. Various reports indicate that over 11 million dollars and thousands of candidate visits have graced the state (read: paranoia )- and for what?
An untried tallying system is not the problem. Blind obeisance to a manufactured system of false importance- is.

 Reports of Caucus participants *unable* (read: unwilling) to give their Caucus-Coins to Viable Candidates-instead tossing them to a no-longer-in-the-race-Cory Booker, should be all the rest us need to hear, to determine Iowans are as fickle and unreliable a gauge as any others. 
The media-manufactured Iowa gold standard and candidates literally chasing after fake- Iowa gold dust, has hopefully met its timely demise.

I was raised in Des Moines and was always proud of how my fellow Iowans  took their responsibilities very seriously to weigh the candidates and deliver the first vote in the nation for the President.  I vociferously defended that preeminent role against criticism from my fellow Democrats here in DC even after the confusion of the 2016 results.  But I can defend Iowa’s pole position no longer. The state party had four years to develop and work out the bugs in its new triple-result caucus vote/ delegate count reporting system, and it  failed us all.Much to the despair of marginalized would-be Democratic voters and the disgust of independents elsewhere; and to the cynical  delight of GOP talking heads everywhere. I can only imagine how Trump will work this fiasco into his State of the Union address. And it will revive with new vigor the perennial debate about the fact that even record caucus turnout would be easily surpassed by a middling primary participation rate. Time to surrender your first-to-vote status for the good of the nation, Iowa; as much as I love my Hawkeye heritage, I love my country more.

An entire year has been devoted to a caucus in a state that is not representative of this country. Incredible amounts of money, time, and attention has been spent on a caucus that in its best year had just under 250,000 attendees. 

Iowa owed the country an efficient operation that  would provide a quick, credible return on that investment. And what did they do? Put all its marbles on a poorly tested app that crashed when put into production. 

Iowa blew it.

I got rid of my Dish subscription a few months ago and even more certain than ever that it was the right choice. I was not tempted in the slightest to stay up all night watching this latest mess. I have finally decided who I will vote for when North Dakota’s turn comes around but there are too many candidates, too many positions and, I suspect, there will be no clear winner. I also think Trump has a fairly good chance of winning re-election because the Democrats will split the vote.

Iowa is certainly not representative of the city where I live - there is almost no diversity and few young people.  I am ready for their outsize say in politics to go away.  Their elections are quaint, but do not necessarily speak for many of us.

But my biggest fear for this election is that we are starting a long cycle of never being able to trust the election results.  I think the current Administration has tainted election security with the blessing of the full GOP.  I lived in FL during the Bush/Gore election.  Have things improved since then?  I doubt it.

Part of the reason we have such low turnout is because bizarre primaries like this one discourage people from participating. For our primaries, why not just let everyone in every state vote at the same time? We need a system where people aren’t confused, and where they know their vote counts for something. When Iowa (which shouldn’t even have special treatment) looks like an undemocratic mess in full view of everyone, enthusiasm for political participation suffers.

Since Trump was elected we are seeing Trump-like governments get installed all over the Western world.  Companies selling themselves as offering Cambridge Analytica type services to right wing candidates will run misinformation campaigns on social media for the right price - see Topham Guerin 

When they get elected and are found to be corrupt, instead of resigning as they used to in the past, they take a leaf out of Trump's book and brazen it out - because it works for Trump and the GOP.

 If democracy and Western civilisation is to survive - we need the Democrats to depose him. The would be dictators need to get the message.

 Given all I have seen transpire over the past 3 and a bit years, I find it hard to believe that both and app and an entire state's phone system could go down simultaneously without some sort of hack, DOS attack, etc. 

I live in a country with an infamously bad telecommunications network. Even here, 1700 calls taking an entire state's phone system down would be unhread of. That didn't even happen when half the country was on fire for goodness sake. I hope the Democrat's refer this to the FBI because it seems like something highly criminal has occurred.

If I had stayed up all night in hopes of hearing the results as soon as they were announced I would also be grumpy in the wee hours of the morning. Fortunately, however, I would not have been in a position to condemn the whole system because of technical delays.  Since I am reading about the delays after a good night's sleep, I can see how much better it is for the Iowa Democrats to hold back the announcements until they can sort out all the temporary problems and deliver accurate results.  If only the Republicans in Florida had been so prudent in 2000.
Our political system to our Federal government need to be modernized.   Modernization should be a priority for the country.
People need to have confidence in the electoral system for the electoral system to function. This is catastrophic.

To have a caucus system means being OK with a “guesstimate”.  Trying to apply modern technology and statistical rigor to it was likely doomed to failure.  How many discrepancies are there between the original vote totals and the 2nd and 3rd rounds, when hand-counting and white-board tallying at over 1600 sites?  Probably a ton, which in past years went blissfully unnoticed, but now are flagged with flashing red lights and sirens in the new app system.  

They either need to stick with the low-data guesstimates, or move to a primary.

The silver lining in this cloud would be if this debacle gives impetus to the Democrats to finally take the action needed to address the outsize role that the Iowa caucus has in selecting the Democratic presidential nominee. Besides the fact that Iowa’s electorate is disturbingly unrepresentative of the national Democratic party, Iowa’s outsize role in distorting energy, trade, and agricultural policy because of the prominent role that the ethanol boondoggle and factory farming has on the state’s economy makes Iowa a uniquely bad choice for having disproportionate influence on the nomination process.  

Can anyone legitimately argue that if a nominating system for the 21st Century were being designed from the ground up, that system would start with the Iowa caucuses?  Change would do the Democrats good.

At its core, a Democracy is built on some level of trust and social cohesion. Nothing works without it. The Democrats have built their party on mistrust on divisiveness. They can’t make their own party work right. Why should they be trusted with power over the nation?
If you want to see a really broken system, look at the result of the other Iowa Caucus: reason’s demise.

Pelosi timed this perfectly. In less than one week Trump wins a caucus, gives the state of the union speech and succeeds in the Senate impeachment voting. 

Moreover, it appears that the winner of the 2020 Democratic caucus in Iowa is Donald Trump. 

It is only the first week of February, folks!

There is absolutely nothing “intricate” or complicated about this system. You count; you divide; you multiply; you round off; you send to a central tabulating place, and they add. A first grader can do it without any technology beyond paper, pencil and phone. Which makes it all the more infuriating that once again (yes, once again - how quickly we forget) an election of some kind in the US ends in chaos.

This state should not be first anyway--at more than 90% white, it is not representative of either America or the Democratic Party. And despite knowing for four years that they would continue their "first" status, they could not come up with a system to count delegates?

Obviously, Iowa loves the economic benefits it gets from being first (political and comms jobs, hotels, restaurants, car rentals) and that every presidential candidate wannabe has to spend years developing a voting record that Iowans will like (in favor of ethanol subsidies and other Ag programs). But for the rest of us, this permanent "kingmaker" status for Iowa makes no sense.

Iowa is why gasoline is sold with 10% of effectively inert ingredient in the name of a cellulose-based fuel industry that never developed. It reduces the efficiency of direct-injected engines. If you can find pure gasoline, buy some and see the improved fuel economy for yourself.

Perhaps the timing is right to start a discussion to reconsider relying on the Iowa caucus, as one of your Opinion commentators suggested yesterday, and move the "first in the nation" status to a state or states more representative of the country's demographics.  Also, I have to say, I was dismayed hearing on NPR that some caucus voters (perhaps in the past - I can't remember) had been persuaded to change their positions by the offer of a plate of cookies.  I would like the recipe, though...

Iowa has gotten way too much attention as a supposed bellwether of the campaign season. Iowa has a very white, older, largely rural population and is a state that sends outliers like Steve King to Congress. Far more important and telling will be the future results from states that actually look like America and represent more of our population.  In the meantime, I hope Bernie supporters can get past their own version of “deep state” conspiracy theories for the Iowa debacle; irresponsible and unfounded talk endanger our chances of unseating Trump as much as anything else.

"Maybe there’s just a terrifying repeat of the party’s awful luck in 2016."

Awful luck?  The 2016 election outcome was about many things, but luck was hardly one of them.  For starters, it was about taking for granted wide swaths of the Midwest.

"The harder I work, the luckier I get."
Samuel Goldwyn
Democracy is undeniably messy, and Americas is often uncannily similar to a food fight. But that is freedom sometimes. But Iowa caucus is just complicating the complicated.

How hard can it be to look more competent than the Trump administration? The perception of competence or otherwise is immensely important in an election process and was a major reason for Labour losing so badly in the recent UK election.

Democrats need to recover quickly from this mess. It's not just the future of the US that's at stake, but the viability of the planet.

America, Iowa, Florida, Democrats, Republicans, ... perhaps it is time to look at other countries and see how to run elections? For a country that sent men to the moon and where the NSA collects a multitude of data on millions of people it should not be an insurmountable challenge to reliably collect its citizens ‘  votes, should it?

Some European countries report their first results in nationwide elections about 20 minutes after voting booths have closed (and these are not exit polls.) Possible range of variation at this stage is usually at +/- 0.5 percent and almost 0 just a few hours later.

Wow!  I have been asking for years how did we possibly get into a situation where by choosing our possible next president begins with a year of campaigning in Iowa and then the election there is decided by some antiquated caucus system.
Really? ...and then we move to New Hampshire. I have nothing against Iowa and New Hampshire but it seems ridiculous that those two states have  been chosen to set the stage for the political year ahead.  Other countries laugh at us when they see our process￼￼￼ of choosing a presidential candidate. 
Why can’t the parties involved just get four or five super primaries in some logical order and let the best man or woman win.
Imagine we go through this whole process and no one has enough delegates to get the nomination and then we have a brokered convention.
Our system is clearly broken but no one seems concerned to fix it.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼
Everybody just relax. The votes will get counted. The world won't end if you don't hear the result until later or tomorrow.

Taunting IS Trump's favorite sport.

50 Years ago I did the sales tallies for Alexander's department stores by Telex.   We got them in, on time, every day.    Although punching ticker tape is not high tech, I cannot believe that the people in charge could not figure out alternate means of communication.
Watching the process last night, I think that Smoke Signals might have been a better plan.    This is why Bloomberg is running.   He sees the amateurs in charge of the Democratic Party and feels at lease one grownup has to step in to defeat Trump.

My takeaway? Anything is possible at 50, and we won't be put in boxes. I'm not Blanche or J. Lo, and as much as I admire Dorothy, I'm not her, either. In some ways, I'm all of them, and in some ways I'm none of them.

I think that the joy of being 50 is that I'm defining myself instead of letting others define me. I dress to please myself; I'm getting better at defining what I want and not what the world wants for me. I hope that J. Lo is getting what she wants, too.

As a 60 year old woman who has been athletic most of her life, I see J-Lo as both a reflection (with somewhat better hair ;-) of myself at 50 and an inspiration at 60.  At some point joints wear down, hormones wane, and the effort of staying in-shape escalates.  And granted, Ms. Lopez has a lot of incentive and no doubt a stable of support to help her stay athletic and limber and in performance shape, but you can't deny that she is a force and an example of what's possible. Does she look great?  Yes. But it's the grace and range (of motion :-) and dedication that inspires.  Do women feel intimidated by female marathon runners? Distance swimmers? Those women at the tennis club with worn and sagging skin in their skirts who can still serve an ace at 70? Don't think so. So get off Facebook and get onto the treadmill, to the yoga class, on the bike, on the horse, on the skates - whatever - just get moving.  And thank the women who got you moving.

So before the game they play the national anthem and it's all serious as if some great patriotic event were about to occur. Then at half-time they turn things 180 degrees and it's all erotic dancing girls. Football is a fascinating and addictive game to watch but imagine how bewildering it would all be to an extraterrestrial who happened by.
Are men also permitted to publish what “women think”, without the fear of a “sexist” label? I thought the writer captured it all well!
You really should be watching the Puppy Bowl with the kitten halftime show anyway.

Looking like that is Jennifer Lopez's full time job. If it were your full time job you could probably approximate it. Do you feel equally judged because your tennis game isn't as good as a professional player's or because you can't cook dinner for 100 people at a time the way a professional chef can?

Jennifer Weiner seems to be living in 1957. Her whiny, ridiculous comments about basically "giving up" as she turns 50 are appalling; I assume she lives in 2020 and knows that women are remaining sexy and vibrant and groomed as 25 year olds...I find all of her columns to revolve around her own issues of weight and aging, etc. and she's mired in ancient dogma. Which is why I've never read her chick-lit light books. Jennifer Lopez' job is to maintain her body and face, and she's had ample plastic surgery, injectables and body work that bear this out. She's a lazer focused performer whose ambitions are outsized....bravo to her but for Weiner to whine about how she's making "real" women look bad is just pedestrian and the equivalent of "mom-jeans"... Ugh.

Take heart, though, good chance that at 50 most of us will be/are secure enough not to need to wind ourselves around a stripper's pole wearing a leotard requiring double-sided tape to stay in place. It's impressive to look so good at 50, and dance so well at 50. But what's more impressive is being secure enough not to feel the need to be an exhibitionist.
Nobody will be watching.  ;)
