Either way it is her job people to maintain that body, to live up to that image she has made for herself and to the people that pay her. For me I found it inspirational, here is a woman who has worked hard and achieved her goals and loves what she does. I am trying to do the same thing aren't we all? Why do we as women compare ourselves to other women. We are each unique and have a special gift to offer this world, so let's celebrate each other.
Do not despair.  Unlike most women who have compassion, wisdom, tolerance and other great qualities, we men are just oblivious to the surroundings, including but not limited to athlete body shape...
You too can do it.  It just takes a lot of really hard work and discipline.  And, of course, desire.  That is not for everyone.

Latina women in general are gorgeous and non-apologetic about striving to look good. 

More power to them. 

Maintenance is good. Taking care of  yourself is good. I was never a Michelle Obama fan but did applaud her encouragement of getting exercise and eating right. 

Diet and exercise do not require one to be rich to achieve desirable results.

I’m struck by two things:

(1) This performance demonstrates how long women’s careers can be: they can remain center stage, strong, glamorous— but only when they are their own executive producers, not limited by an expiration date imposed by a male-dominated industry. 

(2) Ms. Lopez is extremely physically strong, doing moves that would be hard for fit people at any age. Stop judging her outfits and body— get inspired to be so fit and strong.

Actors, male and female, are always atypical of the average body build.  The football players we watched at the Super Bowl are also very atypical of the average male.  We all know this.  So what?  My wife just turned 80 and is as attractive to me as she was at 24 when we married.  Fact.

Why do women compare themselves to other women? I respect J Lo for being the consummate professional. She has to take care of herself and as an entertainer, she supports a lot of working men and women. She is a professional. Comparing yourself to her is like comparing your writing to a famous bestselling author. You both write. End of story.
We have so much more important things to worry about right now.  This is totally lightweight.

Why does everthing have to be so political?
Beautifully toned and trained body with energetic dancing are her telent and business commodities to sell and she sells well.
Is it wrong to admit that not all people are created equal?
I can't run 100m dash at 9.65 how hard I try.
I can't paint like van Gogh. I cnannot compose like Morzart or Bethoven.
Ballet companies select certain types of body for their future dancers. Is it a body-shame?
I have no problen to admire certain talented people in various field. 
In this politically correct era, I wonder how the statues by Michelangelo be judged?  
I have a firm belief that politically correctness is not always a good thing for the arts.

Did any of Superbowl halftime show encourage younger women to "empower" themselves via advanced education in law, physics, biochem, computer science, accounting - avenues likely of much greater long-term value, as would be same for fellows comparing themselves against the gridiron atheletes?
I sort of miss the marching bands. I understand one can do marvelous things with a tuba.

Must the NFL subject us to stripteases when we are merely trying to watch Football?  Cheerleaders are fine, they have been a fixture for decades or longer and most fans mostly ignore them.  It is not puritanical to ask for a little decency in a nationally televised program.  Must we tell the children to leave the room if we don't want to subject them to a striptease?  

And also, must we subject Jennifer Weiner to all the judgement coming from JLo's 50 year old body as she alleges in this "article?"
You only have to look like JLO at 50 if you want to, or it's your job. It takes some serious dedication.

Actually, JLo's body is unaware of your existence. That body is the result of years or working out and controlling impulses, plus, probably, tens of thousands of dollars in professional help. Her body is one of the ways she evaluates herself, and it's also a professional investment. I feel personally judged by Brad Pitt's smile. Is he supposed to stop smiling to make me happier with myself?

I think articles like this really make women sound like the overgrown 14 year olds they have been fighting to prove they are not for so many years now.   What happened to all that blather about not being judged by the superficialities of youthfulness and what other people define as "beauty."  Can't you make up your own minds whether you are beautiful or not, inside or outside.    All articles like this seem to evidence is that for all the aggressive feminist talk of the last 40 years, many women are still that 14 year old girl with braces wondering if a handsome boy will find them alluring.  

I'm 67 and male and I do not for a moment think negatively about myself when I see a picture of shirtless young actor with six pack abs.  I would be embarrassed to realize that I thought about myself in such superficial terms.   So should you. 

PS:  what do you think the reactions would be if a male had written about how great J Lo looks at 50?  The cries of "sexism" would be ear shattering.
It is a giant step backward for women to compare themselves to other women-especially regarding their appearance.

Hey, this is America! Free will, thought, speech etc. U all decide for yourself whether u want to be healthier or a touch overweight. U decide whether ur body is worth the 30 minutes or 1 hour daily to exercise or even just take a walk. Of course in addition to raising Jr and the little gal or putting in 40 hrs at work. But they would probably enjoy that walk as well, they in a carriage if needed. Live in multi-storied housing? Use the stairs if unencumbered by packages or groceries and its a few floors. You'll find that after a while, you'll be able to tackle more floors easily.
Too many obese people here, all ages, gender and race. 
Here's to a healthier America. (I don't work for health products or food).

I'm no prude but I thought the SB halftime show was unnecessarily raunchy. (And no disrespect to the performers' talent.) This is one of the few times when families watch TV together and I thought of my brother trying to explain what was going on to his granddaughter. Seems hypocritical to celebrate women's empowerment (in the person of Katie Sowers) and then stage something so exploitative in terms of both costuming and choreography. (And yes, I know Adam Levine performed shirtless last year...)

Nobody's body is judging your body.  That is ridiculous.  You are projecting.  I am also 50.  I can hike 10 miles and run a half marathon.  I am strong.  I have never worn make-up and I have never dyed my hair.  I have never worn heels.  As such, I never looked at a number ending in zero and thought to myself, "I can quit trying."  Why did you even begin if it's so arduous?  (I don't have the time or interest to wake up that much earlier to put on make-up, and I'd rather read a book or go outside.)  I thought that performance was awesome, I love their music, they look like athletes, and it was supposed to be a visual spectacle.  Go find your own corner of the world and inhabit it with your passion.  I do, and so do these women whose bodies are not judging you simply by the act of their own existence.
Great write-up with a smart, dazzling ending paragraph!
Jo Lo's act was a lot like the new truck commercials.   Just another shiny object I'll never be able to afford.

Ms. Lopez, like all females, is in bad trouble if she thinks she has to compete with 20 year old physiques for sexuality.

One of the nice things about Puerto Rican culture has always been that older woman are allowed to flaunt their sexuality (if they wish).  They don't have to achieve false cosmetic, surgical, and chemical youth.  They are accepted as sexual beings without any necessity to demean themselves with contrived appearances.

Did you look at the little icon of Jennifer Weiner's face, people? She's having fun. She's kidding. She's happy and smiling and making wry observations about all of it. What fun that halftime show was! How beautiful, strong and talented are JLo and Shakira. I loved the messages -- subliminal and in-your-face -- that I loved and let the rest go as I shimmied my way to the guacamole. Well said, JWe. Waka Waka, people. Let's (all) Get Loud and sing and dance while we can!

Yes!!!! Women are our own worst enemies! Was thinking about how to write the preamble to my post when I shared this article on social media. I kept wondering, do men react similarly to the Super Bowl, by demeaning the athletes who somehow “make them look bad” in their middle agedness!? You hit it on the head here. If it were Steven Tyler shirtless or the Boss in his tight jeans, no doubt men would’ve shrugged- good for him - and then dipped a chip!

I can not allow myself to feel judged by other women with the means to employ retinues with the sole purpose of enabling their aspirations to all this.
However I will point out that my thighs look fabulous once encased in pantyhose ( ie no cellulite!) and J Lo is wearing a body stocking...
Then again if I attempted to slither on a pole with her get up I'd be flat on my bohunkus!

I saw that meme:

50 years old in 1985- the star of a funny, successful tv show. 
50 years old now- a surgically-enhanced sex object swinging on a pole during a violent, male-dominated sporting event.
I'm not sure this writer's angst really justifies a column in the NY Times. If she doesn't want to look a certain way that's fine but why is she putting down those that are fit and fashionable?
When the Superbowl halftime show devolves into pole dancing and shaking female rear ends into the camera, I'm really done with it.  Pathetic.

Jennifer Weiner (“I feel personally judged by J.Lo’s body” 02/04) only has it partly right. She also fails to mention J.Lo’s facial surgical enhancements.

It’s NOT just how she looks…it’s what she chose to do. Vulva thrusts and crotch-grabbing are truly not necessary when everyone knows how sexy you are.

It’s 2020…yes, women are empowered to do what they want…but is this what they should be  inspired to do?

Interesting to point out the difference between how women and men look at such things differently... I suppose the question is whether this is a result of what expectations have historically been put on women vs men, or if it points to something deeper (kind of psychological by design)?

At the same time, I don’t think I have seen a male performer perform (more than) half naked at a nationally televised (and huge) event like the super-bowl, but even if one did, I agree with the author that the larger majority of men wouldn’t react the way this article indicates women do.

All that being said, what is this article about? I actually can’t figure it out... why is this is NYT?

PS: If a male author wrote “judged by dat ass” on JLo’s performance he would be labelled a sexist & racist..

Last year, after my wife resumed going to gym following a 7-year break, she and I had dinner with a couple, the wife half of which had recently placed second in a bikini contest, post three kids, at 43. I said "Why not you?" to my wife, expecting a slap. No slap came. Instead I got an intrigued smile. Then she started grilling the woman on what was required. It was huge.

She asked if I'd support her bikini adventure. I said "100%." 

Now, it's an online trainer, body-shaping gym 6 days a week, cardio boot-camp twice a week, a food app and Fitbit. She weighs each gram of food, has a perfectly balanced diet, no sugar, nothing deep-fried or boring (hot peppers, herbs and garlic have few calories). 

She has never, in our 15 years together, been so happy, funny, confident and lovey-dovey with me. Her energy levels are nuts and men are flirting at her again -- which she loves, as do I. 

My wife is 50, has J-Lo's hair, body shape and size, skintone and is fast approaching her level of fitness. Some 7-8 months ago she was 25lbs heavier, had a bad knee, was getting regular asthma attacks and eating crap. She runs upstairs. Knee and asthma self-repaired. 

I'm 60, always been fit because I love the feeling. A year ago, I told my wife she was opening herself up to scary illnesses being unfit at 50, not to mention that she was miserable and tired all the time. She bought in on that and went for it.

Being sexy is but one of many fitness benefits. Do it for the health buzz above all.

On Sunday this paper had a big spread which spent plenty of ink drooling about the bodily perfection of 56 year old Brad Pitt in Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (video clip of shirtless Brad included). The clinical parsing of his torso by the female writer (eg. The use of spray bottle to help glisten his torso in Thelma and Louise) was met with Considerable delight and much objectification, both cheery and lascivious, from a perspective of the delighted female readers who commented.  And little to none of the tortured agony which is documented in the current article was on display. 
But when the blithe and utterly off base comment that men, basically don’t give a damn that they are nacho eating slobs even when confronted with visions of gorgeous Adonises who the ladies happily leer at, I wonder how women reach such sexist yet painfully predictable conclusions. 
Feel free to be haunted by JLo. But don’t appropriate my right to feel the same when women are openly drooling over Brad Pitt’s abs. 
In short, women:  please stop appropriating the male voice and telling us how we feel. Or than we are too emotionally blunted to feel the exquisite anguish you feel.  
It’s offensive and sexist that so many women think that most men are not only physical lumps to be ignored, but are incapable of the exquisite anguish that you superior females are so capable of.

Hey - if you want to look like Blanche Devereaux, that's up to you, but own it and stop complaining. I just turned 50 and I'll be damned if I'm giving into that "it's over now" attitude that so many of my aunts had growing up (hair cut short, permed on the top so they no longer had to do anything with it, no makeup and basically all of them looking like Pat from SNL). I get that everyone has busy lives, but nothing is stopping you from eating healthy, donning a pair of sneakers and going for a walk during the day, doing pushups and situps to tone (if you don't want to purchase cheapy weights), but to say she's making you feel bad about yourself...it's only because you are letting her. Granted, some of it is genetic - I will never have JLo's curves and most women won't - but if you've gotten to 50 and are unhappy with yourself, that's on you. I'll take 50 in 2020 over 1985 any day...own it.

As a woman the same age as Jlo, I can't believe this article, as witty as it was, was even written nowadays. 

Firstly, I was blown away by Shakira's talents. She has an outstanding voice, dances like a pro plus plays the guitar and drums! As for JLo, she looked great and did her thing. So what if she is 49? Sure, she has some good genes, but I am pretty sure she works out, eats healthy and takes care of herself. You have to do work to look good as you get older. I don't get the feeling Dorothy Zbornak did that.

Finally, as a woman (I am not a Latina), I felt proud of Shakira and JLo for dazzling and entertaining the crowd like they did. Why does their shaking their asses and expressing their sexuality with confidence pose any sort of a problem - stripper pole or no stripper pole!? Articles like this one feel to me like we are back in the Golden Girls era.

It's time for a different conversation about age and female power!

The performance sent two mixed messages, one of which ultimately got lost:  (1) it's okay to objectify women; and (2) the disgrace of what is the government's policy/actions on 
 immigration and towards Puerto Rico.  It's this second message that got lost because of the first.  Lopez begins in a Lolita type outfit that she immediately sheds to reveal a skin-tight leather body suit.  She dances and sings, there are multiple crotch and ass shots, and she then disappears, to reappear in the closest thing to a skin tight transparent body suit that she could get away with on broadcast television.  More aforementioned crotch and ass shots, and the pole dancing. 
Meanwhile  there are a lot of songs sung in Spanish, kids appear in cages to the refrain, "Born in the USA!" and the Puerto Rican flag is displayed on the flip side of the American one.  What's the message here?  I don't know.  Did J-Lo make some Faustian deal with the devil - the NFL & Fox - to be able to slip in subliminal rants against immigration and Puerto Rico policies?  I don't know.  What I do know is that it's the J-Lo at fifty that has won the (next) day.

Can we just celebrate JLo for being HER best self and breaking down stereotypes of what aging should be. She IS, as a dancer, an incredible athlete, which always seems to get lost somehow, because she makes it look easy. No doubt her glam squad is unmatched, but so is her work ethic and drive to make it to this big stage in the first place. For someone that is so bored by the traditional narrative of decline that comes with aging, especially for women, I am grateful for her halftime (and half-shirt) inspiration. Shake it sista (all the way to the damn bank)!

Honestly, most ppl can look like J Lo at 50 .. You don't need millions for trainers and nutritionists. Three or four 30-40 min fairly intense workouts/week. Some stretching, a moderately healthy diet, good rest and consistency. Not particularly herculean compared to the 60 hours many americans put into work every week.

I wish people would get a grip about how great she looks.  She is in the entertainment business.  It is her job!  Like any other profession she has to work at it to get better.  I'm sure she hears her attorneys and thinks, "my god, how did they learn all this" and doesn't feel judged.  The entertainment business is hard work. They make it look easy because you are seeing the end product of  their hours and hours of work.  JLo probably spends hours on the stair master and is very careful about what she can eat.  It's part of her job! We make choices in life.  That's hers and there is no reason to be bitter because we made the choice to not look like her.  I made the choice to read, read, read, study, study, study.  I try to look my best, but I am content with the choice to be a psychologist and wouldn't change a thing.  Would I like to look like Lopez?  I guess, but I don't see how it would change anything.  It wouldn't make my husband love me more, lust more maybe, but not love.

So where is the line drawn between objectification and empowerment of the female body? Is there a line? Many men are confused about this. It seems women are too, which makes it further confusing for men. We (men) will need some help with this.

J lo should be an inspiration and she is,  just as my female dental hygienist who is bench pressing a 245 pull weight is--inspring me to do my 12 minute - 5 pound barbell arm sculptingregiment every morning - because it feels good and I want to have a gracious old age.

The phrase personally attacked is pretty funny to me. As a woman, I don’t feel attacked or less than because not everything revolves around me. More power to the celebrities and women who want fit bodies and Botox. More power to the women who would rather age naturally.

 Perhaps we need to focus on more substantial things rather than the celebrities dancing around on television. Perhaps we as women need to stop shaming other women for what their bodies look like.
Maybe we should all worry less about superficial things like how hot we are at 50 and more about real problems like how hot the planet will be in 50 years?

She did amazing and I didn't see any reason to envy her. She advanced that women can keep their careers, re-invent themselves, gain the love of a fellow star in his own right, and will lift people like her daughter up to do well. Why hate when you can love?! She's still Jenny from the Block.

I am over 50. My husband and I just returned a few weeks ago from a holiday cruise. Seventy-five percent of our fellow passengers were not from the US, and many were from Latin America. The older Latina women's faces had the lines of women who lived and loved fully, their bodies had some wear and tear, yet many totally rocked halter-top dresses and more. Confidence and happiness with yourself is something that all the nutritionists, physical trainers, and cooks in the world can't give you. Those Latina "women of a certain age" inspired me! As for J. Lo and Shakira, they get paid to look that way, and they outdid themselves. I did not take their beauty as a personal affront.

Did you look like this at 40? 30? Even 20? 

I think women feeling and looking fantastic at every age should be celebrated, not used to bludgeon ourselves. It’s her job to look great. 

I’m 46 and work pretty hard to eat well, workout, stay social and active with my friends and pursue travel and other interests. Not because seeing celebrities like JLo pressures me to do so, but because it feels good to feel good.

Ugh, I just turned 51 and I don't identify with this piece at all. I'm the same weight and health that I was in high school. I work out, I eat right and I enjoy my life. It's my privilege and honor to keep myself fit and looking and feeling good. I don't understand why this writer just wants to give up on her body and appearance? I don't feel like I look great everyday, but I make the effort. Most people think I'm 10 years younger. I don't dye my hair but it's not grey yet. Haven't tried cosmetic surgery or injectables yet, but I plan to because I am getting some bags under my eyes. Why is it just a choice between being JLo or a Golden Girl?? Just be you. That's who I was, am and always will be. Why has America made 50 old?! My friends from college look the same, too. Don't give up on yourself!

The only thing difficult about looking like J-Lo is ignoring all the commercials before after and never ending that are telling us to eat and drink poison. My friends and I, all about J-Los age, have cut out all man made food: anything processed or with a chemical names in it including most bread, packaged anything and especially SUGAR. We all have body fat in the 7-17% m/f range and feel great now. If one need to drop weight then stop cooking food as it requires 40% more calories to digest uncooked food. Keep to fresh meat, vegetables, and 20-30 minutes intense daily work out (anaerobic) and most people will get there. The key for us was to realize that most of this processed food in normal times is poison and we put it in our Pavlovian rejection CNS poison pathway. This may be the only way to ignore the marketing inundation and ubiquitous nature of the poison around us. Processed food has its place in nuclear war, climbing Mt Everest or feeding starving nations but not in normal times.

J Lo has always been a beauty and will be a beauty until the day she dies. Me? *Maybe* I'm a 6 on a good day. Even when I was 20 no one mistook me for a model. Still, I rock what I got and if there's a dance floor I hit it HARD. I feel good. Living in a world where J Lo and Shakira can bring a Super Bowl stadium to its knees makes me happy.
Yep she looks great. But then again if we had her millions for plastic surgery, facials, personal trainers, and a costume, makeup and hair team like she does then maybe we'd look pretty good too.
For those who wonder why we women compare ourselves to such paragons of beauty:  it's because we know that's what men are doing.

Relax she does this for a living and she can write everything off as a tax deduction. She will eventually pay for this as she gets older. Look at Madonna. She has to stop her tour because her body is failing her

Any person can attain a fit and healthy body with proper nutrition and fitness. Saying a woman who clearly takes care of herself is "shaming" you because you feel ashamed of how poorly you take care of yourself is NOT. HER. PROBLEM. 

I'm obese and disabled. JLo is beautiful and I can appreciate her enduring beauty without belittling my own body or appearance because it's different.  

Comparison is the thief of joy. Just try to be happy.

I have a different take. I find the the rabid obsession with professional sports sad. My thought is, if Americans admired scientists half as much as overpaid professional athletes, our educational system would be vastly improved, kids would do better in school, and they would be better equipped to support themselves as adults.
Can anyone name even ONE of the Nobel Prize winners last year? Most of us can't. But we sure know who won the World Series or Super Bowl and likely watched most of the games. How important is throwing a ball across a field for $20 million/year? How important is finding a cure for fatal diseases? So, as a generation X woman, am I concerned with looking like J Lo? No, I'm not. I'm not that shallow and I'm not as rich as she is. It's all about science for me, and always will be.

I do not get the title.  Why do you feel personally judged? These artists and dancers have been able to maintain great shape, and BTW does not require a personal trainer nor thousands of $$.  Just a little self-discipline in eating, and some exercise. If the artists feel like flaunting their physique in addition to their artistic abilities, why not?  Those who feel they shouldn't, simply don't.  It's called free choice.  I am 67 and my wife 58.  My wife has an athletic body, just as I, before she had our two children.  After they were born, my wife maintained an athletic body, just as I. Neither one of us have gained weight. At 67 I still have my six-pack. No trainer, nor expense.  Just self-discipline and self-respect.  Am I supposed to feel guilty because my peers have developed a beer belly when they could have very easily stayed in shape?  Almost 40% overall obesity rate in the US.  And those who criticize the scantily clad? I respect people's right to cover their bodies if they wish, but those who wish to celebrate their physique by showing it...reminds me of the movie Footloose of 1984 where the pastor found dancing to be abhorrent.  Kind of like Isis who find music abhorrent, but then go chopping off people's heads and pass their wives around for other men to abuse.  I guess that's the definition of conservative, meaning to conserve the same customs of thousands of years ago.

Being a woman age 65+ if the sub title had said 'Are we really supposed to be this brilliant at 50 now?', wouldn't we be asking 'what a  stupid question'? 

Sad that some feel being a fit and healthy woman age fifty or older is a negative?  One does NOT need a personal trainer, private chef to be fit and healthy.   One just needs a deep desire to put in the boring, hard fork to become fit and healthy.

We live in an  area of California (not wealthy), where women age fifty and older who strive to be fit and healthy are the norm here.   Yet I have family and friends outside of California in Seattle, Portland, Denver, NYC, Boston, Minneapolis/St Paul, Hawaii, who say the same about there areas.

Marathons have fit healthy women age fifty and older.   Areas with large numbers of women who simply walk, jog, ride bikes have fit healthy women over the age of fifty.   Fitness centers have fit healthy women age fifty and older.  

Want to be fit and healthy at age fifty or older, then make it a priority rather than find something negative to say about folks  who show they do the hard work to be fit!
Madonna was 53 when she performed at the 2012 Superbowl halftime show. Why are we just talking about this now?

I watched the show and thought “Good for them!” They clearly have put a lot of work (and time, and money, and blood, sweat, and tears) perfecting their craft. I was happy to cheer them on and celebrate their achievements even if I’m 15 years you get than JLo and look nothing like her. Why not celebrate other women instead of making things about yourself? This article points more to the writer’s insecurities than anything else.

I have a secret to reveal about women, American women in particular. It is this: they want to be noticed. They want to be thought of as attractive, in the fullest and limited sense of the word, which boils down to sexiness. They don't want to be stared at in public as if a man were judging a prize cow at a county fair, but, as one confessed in the Times, they want to be thought of as "hot". This desire is part of what motivates this column, which is a public fretting about what being sexy, attractive, means after a certain age.

One distant cousin confessed to me that, after 50 to 55, women "become invisible" in public. This brings up the saying (true or not) that the only thing worse than glaring at a women in public is to ignore her completely.

All of this serves to illustrate our general social confusion about sex and attraction. We hide many contradictions behind the facade of lifelong marriage, but women still want to be viewed as desirable by others than their husbands, perhaps to know they can still attract his attentions, perhaps for hedging their bets if the whole thing goes up in smoke.

Through this maze feminism sought to tell us how to live without resolving the glaring contradictions. So, here we are.
50 isn’t that old. A lot of it comes down to genetics, but taking care of yourself and making the effort are equally important.

Jennifer Lopez is not the only youthful looking 50 year old. 50 just doesn't look the same as it used to. I'm surprised that so many NYT readers fail to know this. New York City is full of 50-year-olds who look to be in their mid/early 30s. People keep pointing to artifice to explain how she looks, and it's kind of insulting. The basis for a healthy, strong and youthful body has always been good diet and exercise. People need to be honest about some of the habits they engage in that potentially age them before their time.
Was there a round of agonizing after Lady Gaga's equally excellent performance at that Super bowl a few years ago?

Both Shakira and JLo are dancers. And dancers are athletes, and should be applauded for the lyricism and athleticism that they showed us on Sunday - just as the athletes that played in the football game were. At 54, and someone who loves to dance, and has done so my whole life - Soca, Reggae, House, Salsa, Jazz - I can still rock a leotard - and a bikini! And to the pearl-clutchers who have a distain for the music and dancing that was displayed during the half-time show, I say get over yourselves - that music is a part of my Caribbean-African-Latin culture. It keeps us vibrant and alive. As evidenced by 40+ year old Shakira & 50 year old JLo. Never stop dancing!!

While I understand the constant pressure placed upon a woman regarding her physique, I always find it extremely unproductive to trot out the view that as a man, I don't feel judged in the same way. Men, too, are inundated with celebrity platonic ideals of body type on a daily basis. I can certainly attest to the fact that even as a man in his late 20s with above average fitness, there is not a minute of my life that does not go by where I am concerned about my appearance. I can agree with this entire article up to the point where I am told that as a man, I don't think about this - I do, and we can all tackle this together.

JLo looks fabulous at 50 (quite an understatement) but if you didn't look that good at 20, you won't look that good at 50. But-(say I at 66 and still trying to lose 10 pounds) you can look as good as  you can at 50 -maybe not JLo good but perhaps your best self. As far as her outfit and performance- it's a costume and a performance, shes an actor-singer-dancer-entertainer and this was a show, not reality- not even reality TV.

Don't be too impressed. If I had a costumer, lighting director, hair stylist, specially designed body suit and personal make up artist, I might look gorgeous at 60+.

J Lo doesn't even look like J Lo when she rolls out of bed in the morning. It's all false, and it's all in an effort to attract attention and sell more beer to men and beauty products to women.

I question the premise that anyone or anything MAKES us feel any particular way around these ambiguous social issues.  It’s all about how you deal with things inside. We all have countless opportunities to feel less than everyday and will have more every year as we age. We all need to find our own refuge. 
But really, SHAKIRA was who the men were looking at. WHOA!
Lopez merely represents what's possible if you have drive, and her level of discipline. Being in that line of entertainment requires it.
It is just another  “woke culture”  complaining. They complain about almost everything. Don't want to work hard.

Sad when someone measures their personal worth by how they compare to Jennifer Lopez in physical appearance. 

You shouldn’t take it personally! It’s just business. Most of Jennifer Lopez’s business depends on how she looks in public. And she takes her business seriously if you measure that by the number of professionals on her staff whose sole job is to make her look good physically. 

They obviously did a great job. But what does that have to do with anyone else??
Shakira was Magnificent. Dancer, Musician, Singer. She was Phenomenal. Jennifer Who? Didn't really need her....

American women seem to have developed a defeatist attitude toward maintaining their bodies and keeping fit.  

We all know that pretty much any entertainer like J Lo or big name movie star has any number of embellished aspects to their appearance - plastic surgery, fake hair, photoshop, make-up, access and design of the most flattering outfits, etc., etc. - but that's not what this is about.

For an average woman (and man) to keep fit, eat right and exercise, should be considered normal, encouraged, and generally seen as a good thing.  Spending time on personal care and dressing reasonably well within your budget should be too.  

But for too many, they've given up - become overweight, wear dumpy clothes, don't care how they look - and it shows.  This is a sad development.   

Beauty and appearance may be only skin deep, but it is also reflective of a personal attitude that seems wanting.   Not everyone is beautiful, but doing the best with what you have is good practice and a good thing.

It's interesting that women from other countries don't share this behavior and attitude as much as American women.
No, we are not supposed to look this good at 50. This is the culmination of hard work (outs) and discipline, awesome genes, and loads and loads of money. But...are you not entertained?

Look. Jennifer Lopez’ profession is to look good, and to perform, which requires her to look good. She is a professional artist, and as a dancer, a professional athlete. Her training regimen costs millions. Her wardrobe and accoutrements cost a literal fortune every year! Remember- she cultivated her natural gifts utilizing the services trainers, diets, chefs, plastic surgeons, stylists, designers, etc. Her body is not natural. It is edited. That is her profession. I don’t compare myself with her anymore than I would compare myself with a male professional athlete if I were a man. There is no competition.
She is her own brand.  She is paid to look that amazing and has the back-up to help her:  a personal trainer, a personal chef,  perks from corporate sponsors, etc., etc.

I agree to some degree with most of these posts; positive or negative, there is some truth and basis in all. But I also think of all the young girls reading these comments. Whether 13 or 50, we can always compare ourselves to someone else and find excuses why something is better or worse. Regardless of the circumstances (wealth, good genes, designer clothes, or other), I think we women need to set an example of supporting one another and celebrating our strengths and successes...famous or not...it’s all good! The world is divided enough. Let’s put our pettiness or jealousy aside and be happy, for ourselves and each other.
Age is more a state of mind, not so much a state of being....
People get over it! It was entertainment. Women stop judging; that is NOT what feminism is about.
Never mind the invidious feelings inspired by her body. What about the feeling of being ripped-off by her lip syncing? I feel personally defrauded and insulted by THAT!

Rue McClanahan was beautiful her entire life. 

And Shakira is a far better singer and natural (and seductive) dancer than Jennifer Lopez (an excellent actress when she gets the opportunity) who is really an athlete when it comes to dancing. Jennifer works at being sexy; Shakira just is sexy. They're both lovely.

I applaud JLo for being able to get such a gig at 50. Since turning 50 and trying to re-enter the workforce after a break (after 14 years of having a successful professional career) to raise my children, I have found my age a huge barrier. I have sat through job interviews with 30 somethings and could almost see a thought bubble that said "why would I want to hire this "old" lady?" I was too experience but not experience enough, or "not the right fit" and overlooked for so many jobs that I was so well qualified for and would have gotten 30 years earlier. I don't even look my age and certainly avoiding dressing in a way that gives it away but hard to hide these days with electronic job applications that make you put in every date. The sad thing is that JLo regardless of her singing talents, wouldn't be hired for gigs like that if she didn't have the smoking hot look. That criteria was not applied to male singers such as Mick Jagger when he performed at the Super Bowl.
I enjoyed these comments so very much.  Great discussion. Thank you.

So if Facebook makes you feel inadequate, quit participating in it and move on.  Perhaps that should be the message you spend your time writing about. 

There is nothing more inconsequential in life than what gets posted on FB.  The sooner we all learn that the better.
I read that these celebrities like JLo or Gwyneth Paltrow spend 2 to 3 hours a day exercising with well paid personal trainers. Those habits are not sustainable for the rest of us.

No, we're not supposed to look/dance like them at ANY age.  They are super performers, unbelievable dancers, beautiful beyond belief and gifted with glorious talent.   We should no more compare ourselves to such super stars than we would to Kobe or Obama or Oprah.   It is for us to admire them greatly.

It’s sad to see so many comment without reading. The piece is good - it’s getting harder and harder to age, but women typically put that onus on ourselves. And why? What benefit is there to being stared at and harassed for a few more years? I am looking forward to blending in with the sidewalk.

It's always been about genes, not jeans; and, you should ALWAYS dance as if no one's watching and sing as if no one's listening.

To borrow from A Poet, "One's reach should exceed one's grasp, or what is heaven for?".

JLo and Shakira looks great.  I failed to look like them 25 years ago, and I've failed again now.  Of course, endless money to spend on personal trainers, plastic surgeons, nannies, and hand-crafted designer duds specifically tailored to make the most out of every curve make a difference, too.

In my day it was Tina Turner who had everyone saying how   fabulous she looked at 50.  

Be yourself everyone else is already taken - Oscar Wilde

At the risk of sounding like a MRA—I appreciate that women have much tougher beauty standards imposed on them—I think it's dangerous to generalize masculine-identifying people as ignoramuses with no risk of encountering body-image issues. Eating disorders can affect all sorts of folks, and to imply that no masc people suffer from them is to minimize and ignore those who may be suffering from deadly illnesses.
Given the state of the world and the US right now, I can't, I just can't.

Simply put, top screen actors and pop cultural stage performers don’t do this alone. Fitness trainers, nutritionists, plastic surgeons, make up artists, clothes buyers, etc. help actors/performers stay in the money-making game. We should never measure ourselves against women or men who maintain their youthful appearance through these measures. This is part of performers’ job readiness. It has nothing to do with our jobs, family commitments, communities, or values. Ignore or enjoy these beauties as you like, 
but get on with your own very good lives.

Women shouldn't feel pressure to look like celebrities. Men know it's personal trainers and nutritionists, makeup and duct tape. We honestly don't compare them to the average women. My wife is younger than JLo. I know she doesn't have her body but she is always the prettiest women in the world to me!
Let's be fair, most of us didn't look as good as JLO when we were 25.  So...point being, if you're one to judge yourself based on how others look, you're apt to be a big disappointment to yourself.
Forget nachos and "looks." Why isn't her health the inspiration?

You do you!  Years of patriarchy have taught women to compare and compete with each other.  Don't fall into this trap - J.Lo can look how she wants to at 50, and you can look how you want to at 50.  She's not 'making' you feel bad; you're doing that to yourself.

These women are professional narcissists who must keep their bodies young to make all that money and have all that power.  Would you want to make your own life a full time pursuit of "beauty".  This just plays into the hands of the decadent late capitalist beauty industry, cosmetic surgery industry, etc.  Natural is beautiful and I could care less if I look like J-Lo or any other actress, model, or celebrity.

It was the best half time ever.  I am in awe of the hard work these performers put into training and preparation.  It really showed off their talents and if YOU want to show off yours (whatever type) you have to work hard too to excel.  Don't know why people make such a fuss.  I saw well trained dancers who have been preparing long hours for their performance.  I saw beautiful well designed and executed costumes and props.  I saw excellent choreography.  Well done!

If MY livelihood depends 100% on my looks you can bet your bottom dollar I'd demand MY CONTRACT to include paid-for EVERYTHING for super high-end products and services to maintain that look including personal trainers, nutritionist, facial, massage, hair colorist/stylist, cosmetics, skincare cosmetic surgeries ..... you get my drift.
I'm 58 and look 50 times better than her !!

BRING ON the summer Olympics! Something for our youngsters to aspire to. Not sheer body garments revealing a body competing w youth. Probably the most pathetic TV show I thought possible in this day and age...
And this type of "halftime" show, Superbowl or otherwise,  will vanish from advertisers' playbook when  sex no longer sells.
I thought I had switched channels by mistake and ended up in a men’s club.

Ehh....Speaking as a man who passed the 50 year mark some time ago, I can't say I've never felt regret at seeing an older man in very good shape, let alone a younger athlete, but then again, even in my youth I was never the picture of athleticism. I certainly don't beat myself up about it, but I don't allow myself a pot-belly (the balding and the gray hair I can't *tastefully* do anything about). But I don't follow the show- and sport- business idols, anyway, so I'm not subject to as many "influencers" telling me what I should aspire to.

We are now in full cultural evolution mode.  Just as much women as men are watching porn.  In this "me too" age, women realize that the "turn on" that their men get from porn, can be provided by them. Just adopt the techniques of the porn   girls and you will keep your man. If you can't beat them; be them.
More power to the freaks

No you’re not supposed to look as good as JLo. Why? Because that is not how you earn your living. She’s a professional public figure and sex symbol, part of her job as a popular singer, it’s something she works hard at.  Do you beat yourself up for not playing tennis as well as Serena Williams? Do you want to throw yourself over a bridge because you don’t sing as well as Renee Fleming? Get a grip. Enjoy her achievement.

Wow. While we're being all "judge-y" here: this made me feel like I fell into a wormhole to the '50s. What kind of feminism makes an "issue" out of a professional female entertainer's body? Why is it important how it made an opinion writer feel about her body? If this is a review of the performance, I missed the part where you talk about music, dance, or cultural references. And speaking of putting things out there under "the male gaze", how is this an op-ed issue worthy of discussion in the New York Times? Seriously.

I would hope, whatever your body shape, you have more dignity than  either performer showed.

Sleaze like this is not feminist nor empowering of women.
You don't have to be judged by J Lo's body at 50. Many 50 year olds let themselves go, that's on them, not on nature. Any one can exercise if they get off their duff.

Kudos to both JLo and Shak for putting on such an extravaganza.  Looked good, sounded great and diverted us from our greater worries for a few minutes.  JLo and the pole?  Her performance was worthy of the Olympics.
Yes.

I don't think you have to be labeled a "pearl clutcher" to wish that J-Lo's costumes at the half-time show covered a little bit more skin.  The show was verging on the vulgar (stripper poles?) and could have been so much better.

Not at all pleased with Ms Weiner's description of women who were uncomfortable with JLo's performance as "pearl clutchers." I'm no pearl clutcher but I am saddened by the never-ending sexualization of women for the male gaze.

I'm 65 but people think I'm much younger.  I haven't had botox, a tummy tuck or butt implants.  I'm not rich and probably wouldn't spend money on making my body look perfect anyway.  The pole dancing is...I have no words.  What has happened to half time for the Super Bowl? Is there anything about football to really enjoy now? Players that assault their wives/girlfriends, being part of  murder investigations, drugs...the list goes on.  Not my kind of entertainment.  I should have read a book!

I didn't have that body when I was her age, 20 years younger, or ever, come to think of it. I'm in awe of what she can do, at any age. But it has nothing to do with me, or ever did. As I get older (73 now), all I ask for is good health. Without it, nothing else matters.

Ms. Lopez looked fine, but no better than any height/weight proportionate 50-year old person would with similar makeup, lighting, and clothing. The U.S. is just used to seeing its overweight and obese citizenry, made so from cheap and readily available high energy content foods, and thinking that's normal, while the real normal for our species should be thin and fit.

It's complicated. For so many years, I had to tolerate movies with ugly or fat or old men starring alongside beautiful 20-something women. But I have begun to notice that more movies and more multiple-episode shows now star or feature older women - 40, 50, and beyond. So I think that JLo helps us all by saying, we are not to be dismissed just because of our age.

Let's not forget that Shakira and JLo 'need' to stay looking good to stay where they're at.  In no small sense they are trapped by their own image.  Regardless, they both still look fabulous, and more power to them.

There is another aspect to Jennifer Lopez's fitness which is not discussed: the possible use of performance enhancing drugs.  

Of course, there is no proof like a failed drug test.  Nor will she likely be part of a criminal investigation since PED's are often legally prescribed as anti-aging medication.     

However, PED use is well known in celebrity circles, like the aging but muscular Sylvester Stallone, who was caught with HGH.

I find when circumstantial evidence starts to add up, PED use is likely.  That was the case with Lance Armstrong, who passed all his drug tests but there were so many signs.

From Lopez' improbable fitness at age 50 to her partner, Alex Rodriguez's drug scandal, it seems very possible she uses PED's.  

There is no public proof of PED use, but I don't look to her as an example of clean fitness.
Blanche Devereaux WAS hot at 50 . . . and she didn't need to wear a Versace bodysuit to prove it.

Men watching 20-something athletes running around is hardly like me watching my same-age peer dancing in nearly nothing and looking hotter than most of us ever had at any age.  Bad analogy.  Good article though!

I know plenty of 50 + year-olds who look, maybe not pole dancer perfect, but still pretty terrific. There is nothing mysterious about how to do it. Exercise regularly and watch your diet.   That being said, I thought the bumping and grinding was pretty tasteless.

Thank you. This is lovely. As I move— at the end of this very month to my 71st birthday (!!!) —- I can however sadly assure you that Letting go of the self judgement  remains the light at the end of the tunnel. Sigh.
JLo is not an anomaly - there are many women over 50 who look better than they ever have in their lives. I'm one of them!

Why take what J-Lo does with her body so personally? She's a singular talent, like Ann-Margaret, who looked pretty darned good at 50, too.  Comparing ourselves to entertainers should go out the window as we become more confident and happy with ourselves-- which should be when we're in our 50s, if not sooner. So, good on J-Lo and her trainers and otherstaff that help her get that way.  If I looked that good, i'd show off too. But I don't, so I do the best I can with what I got: no trainers, no staff, and a wardrobe from Old Navy.

oh, and believe me, some of the old men bemoan the days when they were young and hot like all those pro athletes. I know more than a few guys who admire the health and physique of 40 something Tom Brady.  But some simply admire, not get all upset that they aren't like that anymore,  if they ever were.   Maybe we should be more like men: appreciate, even admire, but if we want to, eat those extra nachos, too.  Really. Who's looking anyway?
Janet Jackson must have been absolutely dumbstruck by this spectacle, after all the grief she went through over her Super Bowl performance.

Why belittle her talent? 

She looks great. That, and a good voice and dance ability, made her rich and famous. Why shouldn't she make full use of her gifts? 

No, she'll never sing as well as Barbara Streisand, act as well as Meryl Streep, talk as well as Elizabeth Warren, or be as smart as Ruth Bader Ginsburg. 

But she's magnificent to look at, and I have no doubt she works as hard as the foregoing to be the best at what she is.

Oh, and by the way, Jane Fonda looks marvelous for 82!

If you look at the rest of the bodies in this photo and compare to Géricault's "The Raft of the Medusa", there is a striking similarity and you will get an entirely different message.  The story of the painting (see Wikipedia) is the captain left the passengers to die. Like the Federal response to recent Puerto Rico disasters, the painting shows a contemporary tragedy on a monumental scale. The painting's notoriety stemmed from its indictment of a corrupt establishment. Sound familiar?

J-Lo goes through a lot of work and effort for something so shallow and impermanent. I know that sounds preachy but at my age, eyeing the grave far more often than noticing those eyeing me, I need more to hang onto.

Am repelled by the sheer America-wide mass and density of it.
It says it all, including searching for weapons of mass destruction.

If you feel "personally judged" by someone else's appearance, it is likely because you are judging yourself. You can stop doing that anytime. You don't have to place so much value on how you look - you can focus on who you are. It is unlikely that others obsess about your appearance nearly as much as you imagine. Be neat, clean, healthy and enjoy yourself.

It's not "I Feel Personally Judged by J. Lo’s  Body", I think the author is judging herself by how she feels others would judge her.  She seems to be looking at herself externally in the same way she is looking at J Lo.  But, what really matters, is she happy, healthy, in a good relationship? Be good at your craft and stay healthy for yourself and your loved ones not because 43 yo Shakira and 50 yo J Lo are physically exceptional.

I know this piece is satire, but still:

"If there was one thing the Shakers and the Clutchers could agree on, it’s that Jennifer Lopez looks amazing. At 50, she is a force of nature, a woman who looks so amazing it’s like evolution took a tiny step forward, just for her."

Who cares about her looks, at any age? What did Madame Curie look like at age 50? Or Mother Theresa? Golda Meir? Eleanor Roosevelt? Anne Frank didn't make it to 16.

We judge people by their deeds, not the packaging they arrive in. This is why I generally get up and leave the room during the Superbowl halftime shows. For years now, they have been generally vulgar, tasteless, and lacking in artistic merit. 

Hardly the setting to demonstrate "empowerment," or anything else.

Dear women, stop comparing yourselves, this to a degree, is self inflicted.

My lovely wife is almost 50, struggling with busy issues in the same way I imagine many others are. Here's the thing, I find her incredibly attractive.

You can choose NOT to buy into some artificial standard set by marketing tupes, accept yourself as you are, and that your significant other can and often does as well.
50 is the new 40.  In ten years, 60 will be the new 50.

if you have had for the last 25 years;  fitness trainers, massages, expensive skin treatments, personal Chefs and " good genes", plus nannies to raise your children- no doubt most women would look like Jlo at 50. I give her credit, she maintains at the top of the entertainment world, however she too will fall to "mother nature."  Just ask the Material Girl.

It's sad so many women agonize over their bodies and feel that society puts an unbelievable amount of pressure on them to measure up.

But the truism that "if you want to make a change, start with yourself" certainly applies here.   And by change, I don't mean your body; I mean your outlook.

Own your feelings.

JLo is not the standard bearer for anyone but JLo. She works out and trains like an athlete & sticks to a very stringent diet. Her whole brand for decades now has been about the RomCom personas she occupies as well as Jenny from the Block professional dancer and diva. She's also known to be exceptionally vain when it comes to her appearance and while she's been blessed to have been born as a gorgeous woman she works nonstop to maintain that raw genetic gift.

I am not jealous oof Jennifer and Shakira. I am in total admiration of their athletic ability. They remind me that growing old doesn't mean you have to ascribe to the notion that you become a gray couch potato as you age.

Make gaze? Really?

The pelvis thrusting Shakira show treated men like fools. Well, we are fools at times about such matters but that doesn't mean our brain lock-ups are rightly celebrated in the biggest television event of the year. "Entertainment" these days must be slavered with hyped up sexuality.

I have attended one regular season Redskins game in my entire life, the ticket was a hand off from a friend with season's pass. I was insulted by what I called the "sex-leaders" on the sidelines. Their apparent purpose was to fill those lagging 40 second gaps between plays. They leered into the crowd as if they wanted to hear an immediate bedtime story, followed by the story.

These public displays of excess sexuality do, however, serve a purpose. They remind all of us that we are a society undecided about what to do about the sexual impulse, whether to highly regulate it through marriage, let it fly lose through multiple, occasional partners or suppress it through religion. It's a mess and so are we. We haven't solved this problem.

The jiggly dancing reminded me of some women dancers for Ethiopia I saw performing once. Their dance was a clear celebration of female form and function, no apologies. Some day, perhaps, we can be so advanced.

Give it a rest.If you're not willing to follow a regimen like hers then don't complain.Not everybody has the genetics and devotion to training like some people do.Most men don't judge women no where near as harshly as women do.Few lbs. here,few lbs. there most men don't care.Women worry about things that don't really bother men.

You wrote that at your 50s your would start to "treat my body like a place I could exist without apology"
-
always do that, always help others live like that.
-
then you don't have to write the rest of this opinion piece.

finally, I gift you one of my favorite quotes:
"love is not comparing".
"You get what you pay for" -- whether it's money or effort.

I didn't see any of the show.  I'm not a football fan.
How about we all age in our own way and live in our own skin.  
Maybe if women stopped obsessing about how they look, the world will stop judging them by how they look.
If the most significant take away from her performance was she looks like someone younger, then simply have someone who is young.

One of the most egregiously misleading headlines I’ve seen in a while. As one of those “pass the nachos” 60+ men who hangs around women who don’t get hung up on all that marketing crap, I anticipated (based on the headline) responding to this piece with an eye roll and a “sheesh, have some self-respect”. I was happy to discover the writer is indeed getting there. Do the editors really think they need to trump (word intended) up the confrontation angle to get people to read their articles? Oh well, maybe it did get me to read it, I’ll admit - but I’m sure a “get over looking like JLo” tag would have intrigued me just as well.

The Ass Shakers commented, "shout out to brown female superstars." The Pearl Clutchers replied, "shout out to insecurity and white privilege." Then I said, "shout out to both groups for watching the Super Bowl with me."

How dare this woman be my age and in better shape than me!!!

That you take offense at a professional that has spent countless years on her craft and put in the work of taking care of her appearance, says a lot more about you than it does about her. The success of others doesn’t diminish your accomplishments in any way. 

Also beauty, health and intellect are not mutually exclusive traits. Stop treating them like they are, especially when it comes to women.

A beautiful over 50 female friend of mine often has that very same concern. I always remind her that women like J. Lo have an entire team of people devoted exclusively to nothing else but making her look that good. And that she would look even fabulously better if she had such a team tending to her every heath need.

How active are you physically, and how active have you been in the last 20 years?  If the answer is not much, then it is no surprise you may think this is not natural. However, JLo's performance did not strike me as particularly superhuman, she is a certainly a great dancer with a fit body, but nothing out of reach for any 50 year old with decent training over the course of years.  You too can be an athlete, it is never too late to start.

Why are you comparing yourself with a woman who wakes up exercises, eats (maybe), drinks blended something, eats a salad, exercises, drinks more blended something, then exercises again? Her life is performance and acting. Other the majority of womens lives is not that. Be thankful to be alive, healthy and relatively happy.  That is all.

Looking this good is her job. She has an unlimited amount of money and time to spend on staying this way, Almost any woman with a good start (born pretty, nice proportions) could look like her if they had that amount of time and money to invest in the project.

The clothes, the hair, the makeup. the surgery, and don't forget the lighting which is tested to the tenth degree before the show goes on — this is entertainment people, it's supposed to be bigger than life.

Entertainers are not role models. I don't fully understand why so many people think they are. Singers, models and actors are asked over and over by the media about their politics, what they think about scientific phenomena like global warming, their fashion sense, biographical details etc., as if somehow only that small slice of the population, not chosen for wisdom or intelligence (though a few are) hold the key to happiness on earth,

We even favor politicians amd their spouses who look most like entertainers and applaud them for looking great (the Kennedys, the Obamas, Melania) instead of their policies which will shape our lives.

Pop culture is a beauty pageant. It is not a source of role models. Fifty year old women —enjoy it and go to sleep at night knowing that it's not real, anymore than the change you can believe in was.

I just want to point out that there are plenty of women, myself included, who don't let this dominate too much of our mental cycles. Once in a blue moon I see someone looking AMAZING and wish I could. More of the time I'm actually quite proud and happy of my ordinary and healthy 36 year old body. I could not agree more that we live in a misogynist society, but you don't have to let that into your interior life.
Her surgeon does good work. Why feel bad about that?
There was one thing missing here: dollar bills.

The half time show is over. A good distraction from the real world. I’m going to admire Elizabeth Warren, in her seventies, who can go like the energizer bunny running for office. The woman is physically fit and mentally agile. I’m betting she can whoop Trump in a foot race.....and hopefully elsewhere.

It's interesting how this piece begins. Every morning the writer's Facebook feed is 'chill', just the casual Trump-related problems like kids in cages, black people being killed by our police, mass incarceration...But somehow JLo's body causes a firestorm? I think one thing to consider here is race...and priorities. All of the negative reviews of JLo or her performance that I have seen are being posted by white women. I don't recall this happening when Lady Gaga, Madonna, and Britney performed in similar clothing. I can only remember controversy over Beyonce. For me this phenomenon points to white fragility and racial prejudice. Something needs to be said about how women embrace sexuality and power differently in Latin America (and most of the world). Less plagued by leftover Victorian traditions of female censure. Jennifer, you don't speak for women. You speak for a select group of fragile white women. There is nothing wrong with JLo promoting health, curves and sensuality to other women. It's a good antidote to the drug addict look young girls had been fed by white supermodels and white fashion designers for decades. For many people JLo's excellence symbolizes hope, and a very Latin reminder that we can live joyful, passionate, full lives at 50+. Nobody is saying you need to get out of your mommy clothes, that's virtuous too. Don't feel personally judged, the performance was not about you or your insecurities. It was a Latina celebration, for once.

Agreed that both look amazing...look up close however and the barely there clothing is an illusion. JLo is wearing the equivalent of my grandmother’s all-in-one foundation garment...it’s probably as tightly engineered as the olympic speedo leggings...any doubt? just look at the seaming.

Still...they both look amazing.
I'm 74, my wife 73. I think my wife looks great. She doesn't have What's her Butt's bod, and doesn't need it to look great anyway.

I am 40-something mom who talked obsessively throughout the halftime show (and the rest of the game) about the fact that J. Lo and Shakira are both approximately my own age until my husband said,  "I'm confused. Are you admiring? Are you disapproving? Are you feeling inadequate? What's happening here?" All I could do was shrug...and then try (and fail spectacularly) to impersonate Shakira's shimmy in front of my mirror later. (I'm pretty sure her hips DO lie!) Two days later, I'm still thinking about it. Thank you, Jennifer, for explaining me to myself. You nailed it.

I was getting my hair colored and reading the magazines that I love to read at the salon. I came upon a "article" with J.Lo's top ten beauty secrets. I told my hairdresser that the list should be 1-9: look like J.Lo. 10: good skincare.

Too bad women can't see women and thing, "I need to step up my game.", cause you do - we all do.
Physical fitness is important. Aside from the health benefits, we all want to look good in the clothes we wear and take off.
Look at 50 year old women from shows just in the 1980's. "Golden girls" anyone?
50 is the new 30. I just had mine in December.
Embrace it and go for a long walk. Often.
No, not all of us are expected to look this youthful forever. Just the female half of the population. As always.

It's interesting how this piece begins. Every morning the writer's Facebook feed is 'chill', just the casual Trump-related problems like kids in cages, black people being killed by our police, mass incarceration...But somehow JLo's body causes a firestorm? I think one thing to consider here is race...and priorities. All of the negative reviews of JLo or her performance that I have seen are being posted by white women. I don't recall this happening when Lady Gaga, Madonna, and Britney performed in similar clothing. I can only remember controversy over Beyonce. For me this phenomenon points to white fragility and racial prejudice. Something needs to be said about how women embrace sexuality and power differently in Latin America (and most of the world). Less plagued by leftover Victorian traditions of female censure. Jen, you don't speak for women. You speak for a select group of fragile white women. There is nothing wrong with JLo promoting health, curves and sensuality to other women. It's a good antidote to the drug addict look young girls had been fed by white supermodels and white fashion designers for decades. For many people JLo's excellence symbolizes hope, and a very Latin reminder that we can live joyful, passionate, full lives at 50+. Nobody is saying you need to get out of your mommy clothes, that's virtuous too. Don't feel personally judged, the performance was not about you or your insecurities. It was a Latina celebration, for once.
It's all she has to do all day really, work on looking good. Nice job if you can get it.
Point taken We usually don't expect this level of perfection from male celebrities.

I totally enjoyed the the performances of both JL and Shakira.  It was purely entertaining.  I am over 65 and have NEVER looked that good.  I never had any desire, discipline, or talent to put in the effort it obviously takes on an ongoing basis.  She was entertaining us, not shaming us.  You can always walk away and heat up the hot wings.

But, let’s be real.  JLo’s body is her career.  Her performance talent, including her acting, is the basis of her wild success.  She has to work hard to look and perform the way she does.  It is not all cosmetic.  
I applaud the trend in younger women who want to be strong as they age.  My 90 plus mom agreed as she struggled to get out of her chair, after Halftime.  The bathroom break had to wait.

I think JLo is awesome and talented, but I regret her decision to objectify her own body to such an extent, thus encouraging the vast Superbowl halftime audience to do the same. Women have been fighting against objectification for millennia, and JLo's exhibition has done those efforts no favors.

There's a another reaction besides pearl clutching and "you go girl"; that is, the disappointment that every public display like this both sets up an impossibly unattainable (I won't say "high") standard for superficial female beauty and trivializes women's more substantive attributes.

Um, I think these women are not just beautiful but talented and still workin' it! My kind of inspiration! 

I've got nothing against the Blanches' of the world but thank god for J-Lo. Thanks to her I can still rock shorts. I'm 50...

I look in the mirror and see wrinkles and a body that amply shows the effects of gravity.  On the very occasional days that those things bother me I think of the people I love dearly who didn't make it to my age - the voices I'l never hear again, the meals we'll never share, the loves and lives forestalled.

Ms. Weiner, are you serious?

1) Stop judging yourself. That’s your own issue. Own it. 

2) Football is a daft sport played my millionaires for billionaire owners in arenas largely funded by tax dollars. There’s so much wrong with the entire football/pop entertainment culture. I find it comical that you and so many others are critiquing one little part of it. If you watched it, you participated. Stop participating and it’ll go away.

I missed the whole Super Bowl -- the game and the halftime show -- but at 1:30 PM on Monday I googled the halftime show, and found that the youtube video had already been seen by more than 32,000,000 viewers. 

Just about 24 hours later that number is over 67,000,000 -- and this is just people who've watched it after the fact, not counting the many many millions who watched it live. 

For any of us 50+ who were cheerleaders back in the day, we know how much work and practice went in to our relatively simple routines, compared to the astonishing tour de force of athletic choreography displayed by both Shakira and Jennifer Lopez and their dancing crews. 

Do you remember last year's Super Bowl, where Adam Levine stripped off a piece of clothing each song til he was down to his tattoo-covered skin? 

Yeah, me neither.  

JLo and Shakira's halftime was one blazing hot minute after the next. They knew the show would be scrutinized second-by-second, and they delivered powerful images mixed in amongst all the booty-shaking that have inspired many to take a second -- and third and fourth -- look.

Not since Esther Williams have women in entertainment inspired the rest of us to get off the couch.  

Thank you Jennifer and Shakira!
Great job on this opinion!!!! Very well put and tastefully done.
If I could move like that, I would look like that!
great writing !!  wonderful sense of humor!!

I found halftime provides the perfect opportunity to make popcorn, clear out the pizza boxes, get another couple of beers, discuss the first half, channel-surf to see what’s on PBS, get to the bathroom, and reclaim my seat. I’ve hated these blitz, glitz, bling, and sing extravaganzas and avoided them for years.
Hey, goddess, do not define yourself by some one else's baggage.  J.Lo is a full-time t&a worker, gets paid a lot to be that.  She exists in a universe of her own.

Why would any woman compare herself to Jennifer Lopez? She's not normal. It's her JOB to look like that. She has all-the-time access to consultants who assist her in looking that way, whenever she wants the help.
The SB is now over-the-top-stupid with special gee-whiz events, effects, ads, and this ridiculous halftime "show". Consequently, it's nearly always an anti-climax. No thank you. And no, the halftime show is not "entertaining" or "uplifting". It's just a salute to modern excess. That's all.

Why would any woman compare herself to Jennifer Lopez? She's not normal. It's her JOB to look like that. She has all-the-time access to consultants who assist her in looking that way, whenever she wants the help.
The SB is now over-the-top-stupid with special gee-whiz events, effects, ads, and this ridiculous halftime "show". Consequently, it's nearly always an anti-climax. No thank you. And no, the halftime show is not "entertaining" or "uplifting". It's just a salute to modern excess. That's all.

Unbelievable half-time show. This Boomer loved every second of it. but I feel zero pressure to look like this amazing women. Just like I felt no pressure to look like Ann-Margret 40 years ago or Marilyn Monroe 50 years ago. These women were never attainable to me and I didn't desire it. I knew I wasn't going to starve myself or put countless hours into the gym plus I have horrible genetics that do not lend themselves. Then there is having given birth 4 times. Not gonna happen. And I've always been fine with that because they are in the rare earth or time, money, desire, and genetics. So I pulled on my yoga pants this morning and proudly went about my day, loving these women and what they offer but also loving myself and my own wonderful place in this world.
Forget nachos and looks. Why isn't her health the inspiration?
Personally, I find Amy Klobuchar, Nancy Pelosi and Elizabeth Warren far more impressive and empowering role models for my daughters than JLo, beautiful as she is.

C'mon, get over yourself--you're a successful writer with family and friends. Based on this alone you have have more than most. Should I compare myself to you? No, and I'm not sweating it. Power comes from within. It's a fool's errand to measure a woman's worth against what is basically a manufactured, endlessly hyped illusion of beauty. Sure she looks great, that`s the show. Want to feel better? Unplug and go outside.

Feeling personally judged by J.Lo's body is your projection. It's sad that at 50 you're not happy with who you are as a person.
It's time for self respect - that brings true happiness and satisfaction.

You  know what? It's part of her job description to remain in the best shape possible.  She, no doubt, devotes hours of her day to training and other regimes to keep herself fit and young looking. She must spend hours with stylists and estheticians.  While she's doing that, most women are at work or at home doing their jobs.  Her job performance has nothing whatsoever to do with me.

I say to all women, please do not judge yourselves against an anomaly.  JLo does look great and so do other women her age and older.  But they are a very small minority blessed with both extraordinary genetic makeups and workout ethics that are unsustainable for mere mortals.  And women, don’t feel alone, the same thing is true of the male of the species.  Are you good, caring, loving people, embrace that.  Live a good life, be kind to one another, enjoy your favorite meal, and curse your parents DNA as I do mine, LOL.
As a woman about to turn 50, I loved this piece. Brava, Ms. Weiner.
Glad we all see how being healthy, fit, and talented to make a living. Tell your gymnastics daughters who spend 20  hours a week half naked to be half naked as a professional athlete.

I feel personally judged by Monet's brillance as well!
You will get over it.

You know? I feel personally judged by J. Lo's body too. And I am an 80-year-old man with a distorted spine, toenail fungus, artificial quad tendons, six bypasses, a missing tooth, abdominal hernia repair mesh in my gut, and a prostate gland sitting in a formaldehyde jar on my mantelpiece with a label reading "oh, to be 70 again!"

And you think that you have it bad. Cry me a river!

J Lo is not an accurate representation of the average woman in Miami in any age group. Our local newspaper ran a cover story warning residents of the influx of sex trafficking surrounding the big game.  They should have issued a warning regarding the halftime show. I’ll go back to shopping online for Eileen Fisher separates now...

There is this thing called liberal democracy. People enjoy freedom of expression. Some of what gets expressed is terrible. Disgusting. Demeaning. Really. 

But as a society we have been through this and decided that, for better or worse, freedom of expression is more valuable  than censorship. 

We are free as individuals to express our revulsion, too.  But some of that is no better that what got freely expressed. 

When it comes to 50 year olds looking half their age and hot as  Australian bushfires, feeling bad is minor league play. . 

Part of liberal democracy is freedom in advertising. Glamour ads are all about selling people on the possibility of what is out of reach. It is intended to make us feel bad -- bad enough to spring for their expensive and useless garbage of a product. 

Being a grown up is coming to grips with this stuff, and instead of feeling bad about yourself, feel angry enough at those playing with our emotions to boycott their products. 

But JLo is only selling herself. She's the commodity. If she makes you feel bad, why watch. But you might wish to invest in therapy to get to the bottom of why it makes you feel bad that some people look better than you do. No matter how good we are at just about anything, there are legions of people who are better. Anyone who can not live with that has a narcissistic disorder.

So what is J-Lo supposed to do? Let herself go like everyone else? LOL.  Please...the comments say more about the writer than J-Lo.  Look, I'm going to be 59 in two days. My body definitely does NOT look like it did when I was 19 or even when I was 29. There's wrinkles, gray hair, cellulite...but I've never felt sexier in my entire life! I've learned to love the skin (and fat) I'm in...and I'm actually getting more attention from guys now than when I was young and thin. At first I was baffled and thought they were mocking, but I'm actually turning away fellows 30 years my junior who seriously are interested! I wouldn't trade my body for J-Lo's or anyone else. I'm fine just being myself, and all of us ladies should just let J-Lo be J-Lo and we be OUR 'best selves!" It's not a competition, and it shouldn't be.

Who said you're supposed to look like that at 50?  You told that to yourself.  I'm catching a whiff of victim mentality here.  Or jealousy?  Someone else's accomplishments are not a judgement on you.  One can like or dislike Sunday's performance.  But to personalize it?

I'm within sight of my 50th birthday (in a matter of weeks).  This age is prompting a lot of contemplation. I am firmly in the 'shaker' camp.  Go J-Lo.  And Taraji Henson. And Mariah Carey. And Heather Graham! Hot mamas, all. 
 What choice does Generation X have but to skew young, when the boomers refuse to go away? They force us into this prolonged middle age (which I'm totally cool with), and the millennials cornered young adulthood, so we are just playing the cards we are being dealt. And we make it look good!

Ladies, women, my Sisters in the Struggle, please wise up.  Unless you're in the entertainment business, no one expecting you to look any certain way.    You have always had the power and choice to look any way you want to.

If you think you need to wear make up, dye your hair, wear the modern day version of the girdle, and uncomfortable high heeled shoes to be attractive to men (or others), please take a step back and think that perhaps you're trying to attract the wrong kind of person - a person who wants the 'fake' you, not the real you.

If you feel you're overweight, then do something to change that.  If you're satisfied with your appearance, don't change a thing.
