But please stop making yourselves miserable by thinking you have to live up to some ridiculous standards set by someone who is not you.   Don't waste your time and energy worrying about making 'someone else' like the way you look.
Always look at the mother!

Jennifer, with your delicious smile you don't need to worry  !
You look 100 times more appealing than Miss Lopez !

Seems that people should just be praising JLo for her physical fitness. The people criticizing her would probably be the same people criticizing Coke and McDonalds for making people fat.
?????

Well done to the author for including that unflattering reference to "balding men".  In an era in which it has become inappropriate to denigrate someone on the basis of race, religion, sexual orientation, etc. it's good to know that there are still soft targets out there that we can insult on the basis of appearance, even in the New York Times. And how great that we can get away with fat-shaming, at least when that target is a stereotypical "lumpy, balding, greying, potbellied man".

Hey all...this op ed made my day!  Thanks to Jennifer Weiner for wonderful insights and a really good laugh!  

...and thanks to the NYT for finally adding comments.  (I checked in on that this morning and was sorely disappointed that I couldn't comment...and sent them a note.)

We need all the humor (and access to nachos) that we can get these days.

It's my hope that Jennifer Weiner didn't write her own headline, as the idea that she feels " personally judged" in some way by Jennifer Lopez's physique is a cringe -worthy example of narcissism using a method of self-proclaimed victimhood as an excuse to issue this toothless wallow. Suffice to say that Lopez is a professional celebrity and she needs to keep up appearances to remain an attractive commodity to audiences, producers, directors, songwriters ; it is both an occupational necessity and hazard at the same time. If Weiner believes that JLo's fifty-year fitness regimen makes her look bad in comparison and to feel bad about herself as a consequence, the real issues here are better taken up with a therapist and not an op ed page.
Yay to Spanx, body stockings and lycra !

Why do you feel entitled to lump all men in a box about  how they respond emotionally after watching elite athletes? Imagine your pretentious shocked reaction if a man had written those words about women. 


And why does another woman’s body make you feel any different about yourself?  Maybe disconnect from Facebook for a few weeks and reconnect to important things in your life.

wow - if you feel bad about yourself by watching TV - might be time to think about how better to spend your time. 

they were styled a little funny - and their male co-performers were weak and creepy. 

but let’s not dismiss these women as people who get their hair done all day - jennifer lopez would be in her way to EGOT if she were a man; shakira songwrites in two languages, plays guitar and drums. why aren’t we talking about this?
I didn’t think she looked THAT good. I mean, really, Spanx and a million dollar workout regimen and trainer? Who couldn’t look similar? Even Joe Namath looked good in pantyhose

J.Lo looks fantastic at 50.  That's simply awesome.  Jennifer Weiner feeling threatened by J.Lo looking fantastic seems to be a simple case of jealousy and judgementalism.  Other people can do fantastic things and this doesn't diminish me at all.  I have no idea why Ms. Weiner seems to think it diminishes her.  Perhaps she needs new friends.

The responses to this article are fully of people judging J.Lo. and looking for ways to tear her and Shakira down.  If anyone should be feeling judged right now its those two awesome women who put on a great show.

They are incredibly successful and put on a great show.  I have no idea why Ms. Weiner and so many others feel the need to find flaws with them.  Its a sad commentary on humans.
What on earth would a professional entertainer's body have to do with you, or anyone else?
I'm insulted by this article and that it was given space.  Be good with yourself, and that is all that matters.  Yay for JLo, Yay for Shakira, and yay for you.

Come, come JW:  with oodles of money to spend on trainers, cooks, plastic surgeons, make up people, and other flaks and handlers you could look like that - if you submitted to the incessant wheedling and pressure.

When my wife of 48+ years was 50 (a mere twenty years ago) she looked better than this woman - and without intervention. 

To this day she looks better (literally) - and still wears no face makeup and doesn't dye her dark hair.

The reason men can watch other men with zero body fat and feel no shame or inadequacy is precisely because our culture does not objectify the male body in the same way it does the female body. Men are not portrayed largely as a source for female sexual gratification. And so they can be fat slobs and eat another chip and not think that somehow society will judge them as less inherently valuable than the fit studs on the screen. So the Pearl Clutchers are on to something.

What difference does it make what her age is? JLo is dancing, twirling, having FUN. She's a particular type of entertainer as well, so it's her job to look this way. She's much more fit and physically active than lot of teenagers in this country from what I can see. This costume is 80% powermesh spandex BTW, designed to shape and enhance. However, if you want to see how truly fit and strong she is without the 'enhancers", find videos of her training for Hustlers; no makeup, hair in a bun, in sweats. Pole dancing is very difficult and takes major upper body and core strength. This is another reason, besides excellent genes, she looks the way she does.

Jennifer Weiner or is it whiner exposes the perplexity and conundrum, if not schizophrenia, regarding the women’s movement messaging from Me Too to wherever it is headed. Jennifer Lopez mimicking strip club porn gyrations is lauded and applauded leaving exactly what as model for female behavior? Using the young girls also known as children as backup during the performance doubles the confusion of message. The question of “What do women want? begs to be answered clearly and coherently without excuses. When the message is completely focused on the surface with body parts oozing sexuality what is the take-away?
Or — and I’m just suggesting this — you could deal with your issues.  Because what other people are or aren’t has pretty much nothing to do with you, and never did.
Please, everyone! Love yourselves as you are. What celebrities do is of no importance!
Tempest, meet teapot.
Forget about J. Lo's body. You should worry about being judged because you think life ends at 50.
Four words, Charlize Theron & Helen Mirren   <3

The title of this article was designed to be click bait I'm sure but I am so annoyed by the entire notion. 
J Lo is and was a professional dancer first then singer and actress who's business requires her to be a fit as she can be.

Stupid title and I only came here to comment on that. Wouldn't bother to read it with someone else's eyes.

If you truly feel personally judged by a professional in the entertainment business who spends hours and a small fortune maintaining her competitiveness you should ask a therapist. Not us.

Why do people.. namely women, make these comparisons? 

Genetics, how we care for ourselves , how and what we eat ( along with how much) bad habits ( smoking, excessive drinking, drugs) all factor in.. so YES, there are many of us who look this good or better at 50+. 

Stop making celebrities into something they are not..better than the rest of us...that's part of what dimishes ALL women.

I think we look better! Our bodies bear the scars of a life well lived though battle worn! We look and feel alive, not like a wax model out of Madame Toussad’s! Frankly she did herself injustice and cheapened herself and created or reinforced a stereotype of Latina women as fast and loose! It was all demeaning to women, Latinas and women of color!

J Lo has an infinite  amount of money and time to spend on her body, the appearance of which (enhanced by some very well designed spandex ), must be a very high or even her highest priority.  Good for her,  really. This happy feminist in her 60s (no pearls) would rather work out, eat well,  and enjoy the game. Sans the glitzy sextravaganza.

I respectfully submit that I have always believed Latina women had so much more to offer than their bodies.  How quickly the #Metoo movement evaporated in Miami with the help of two women who don't have to earn a paycheck in a man's world.

It was sad.  Shame on you Roger G for not supervising that display.
You missed the point of the show completely and indulging is white middle-aged self pity based on euro-centric/captilist/priveleged sensiblities.

Major "yikes" at your invocation of "lumpy, balding, graying, potbellied men". Feel free to judge what you see in the mirror in such a materialistic way and have it published it as Opinion, but why take potshots at the appearances of others? What would be the response if a man was complaining about being categorized alongside "wrinkly, wire-haired, smelly old maids"?
The only issue I have with the half time show is this article.

It's important to realise that public figures like this use personal trainers multiple times a week, some even almost everyday. That alone would make a massive difference, not to mention having a nutritionist and a chef as part of a larger fitness and weight plan.

The best, I mean the best, cultural artifact on how 50 year old women's looks are treated is the now-overlooked 1937 film masterpiece "Make Way For Tomorrow" (as to whether you should go out of your way to see it, Orson Welles raved about it as an absolute tour de force which "could make a stone cry).

Its theme is the veritable disposal of elderly parents who lack the resources for self-sufficiency and that are regarded as too burdensome by their adult children, busy with their own lives and children. (It's a truly magical film that should be seen by absolutely everybody.)

But what brought it to mind now is that the old, discarded granny character is (magnificently) played by a 48 year old Beulah Bondi (and apparently played naturally, not aged by make-up or other artifice for the part). Her son is played by Thomas Mitchell (familiar as the uncle in "It' a Wonderful Life") was only 5 or 6 years younger than Bondi, yet is in the prime of his life as his (6 year older mother) is being sent off to pasture.

So if you want a really interesting comparison, watch 48 year old Beulah Bondi in that (again, utterly spectacular, an all-time connoisseur favorite) film to J. Lo at the Super Bowl. Then you'll really know how times and women's aging have changed.

Um, that body, or a reasonable approximation, is readily available to anybody willing to spend the money on trainers, spend 20 or 30 hours in the gym or in the clutches of modern cosmetic science and an endless supply of money.
But even without the above, it's relatively easy to stay reasonably fit so we really don't have a problem do we?
No, she looks that way because it's her job and she has to work at staying in shape. She's an entertainer, and one that's built her persona around her on-stage energy.

Interesting that the chattering class has so little to say about the superb choreography, the skill and beauty of it. All about the bodies, which by the way were hardly a rarity  . It was about the music and dance, which were breathtaking.

I've been going to physical therapy for a few months to strengthen my left ankle and the muscles in my left foot.  My therapist gives me many resistance exercises to improve strength and balance.  Many people have commented on Shakira's and JLo's outfits.  Those were hard not to notice, for sure, but I spent a lot of time focused on their feet.  How do they, and all those talented backup dancers move them so quickly and gracefully?  They are miraculous.  More power to them all.

A violinist works relentlessly on their art. They listen, dream, practice, breathe, refine and refine and refine then finally make music.  They do this for beauty. They do this to find the very best of what human beings can do.

I see no difference between the violinist's art and the beauty of the human form combined with movement. Our form refined, practiced and cultivated. To see this at the very peak, at our very best is not for nothing. It's inspiring. I went to the gym on Monday for the first time in awhile. Felt great afterwards. I'll go again tomorrow.  Maybe I'll see a ballet next weekend. That would be something.

I think the conversation shouldn’t be about judging J Lo’s body or our own bodies. 

It should be more about how awesome it is that this person does something that she loves — her dream job, her passion — and she is GREAT at it. 

It’s not surprising J Lo did that amazing performance at 50. She been dancing and performing for decades, and the time she’s spent perfecting her craft has paid off. 

We should all applaud people who pursue what they love, succeed at it, and then become so masterful that at 50, they are making the whole nation talk about their work. 

I’d like to see more of that in our world, especially for women, who face so many obstacles in the workplace, especially as they get older. 

J Lo is an inspiration to anyone who has a creative passion or dream that if we put in the work and dedicate ourselves that someday we could be as good at what we do as she is at performing.

I am 81. I married my 63 year-old "trophy bride" 17 years ago and feel incredibly lucky that she chose to share part of her life with me. The joke between us is, we used to say, 'I can still do this as long as I don't pretend that I am 20. Now I say, I can do this as long as I don't pretend I'm 60!' " 
The beauty of getting old is one can choose to stop judging oneself by others. What really matters is how much love and caring one is willing to risk sharing with others -- even strangers.

I watched the Super Bowl 1/2 time show, and for the life of me I can't remember a single song or phrase of what were supposed to be singing and dancing. I much prefer Talent that is apparent and not lip synched. As such, Lady GaGa comes to mind. I watched her 1/2 time performances and was completely in awe of her talent. That woman can sing and her voice knocks it out of the park. Her performance of  " The Star Spangled Banner" was the best rendition of a very difficult song, to sing. Lady GaGa has so much talent, she doesn't need all of the  excessive production to prove it either. Maybe I'm off subject here but I prefer talent to glitz and glitter.

For J Lo and others like her in the entertainment world their body is their business. Cosmetic maintenance involving surgeries and other interventional procedures and treatments are a necessity that has become a way of life. The same goes for those non-celebrity out of the public eye figures with high income who have both the time and money to self-indulge in this way. To feel intimidated or deficient in comparison is unreasonable.

Im a 60-year-old man who saw the Rue/J-Lo meme on my own Facebook feed and thought Ms. McClanahan in her own way every bit as beautiful and alluring as Ms. Lopez. Beauty comes in many forms for many tastes.
As I was marveling at J Lo and Shakira's age-defying feats, I was stuffing my 59-year-old body with my sixth pizza slice.  It must be fun to be them but to each his own.

It's true.

Watching honed and polished world-class athletes do what they do, and look how they look, all i really care about is if I had made a bet on the contest, and naturally . . . where are the nachos.

Being honed and polished is a lifetime, full-time job; a brutal job lived inside a life of spartan meals and constant muscle crafting.

We're each given the sands in our hourglass, and no more.

How are we each going to spend those grains of sand?

-C

I think its also really important to note that J-Lo's body exists as a measure and standard of beauty for women, while the players' bodies on the field exists as a standard of strength. J-Lo's body is being flaunted while the football players' bodies are covered with protective gear. Societally, and evolutionarily, that "physical" beauty is far more desirable than success at a given sport.

J Lo and Jennifer Aniston, genetics and wealth aside, are manifestations of a new reality that science has given us.  What's the difference between 2020 and 1985?  An enormous amount of data on health and nutrition generated by clever and curious researchers concerning what is good for us and what is bad for us.  I know quite a few non-celebrities who look 20 years younger than their actual age.  

Also, I am a man and I don't eat nachos.  If I watch football I'm imbued with a restless feeling that I should be playing the game instead of watching it.  When Michael Phelps won all those Gold medals in 2008 I bought a pair of swim goggles and took up swimming.  I still swim regularly.  Elite athletes, musicians, and most exceptional human beings are inspirational.  That's on you if you can't see that.

I think you’re missing the point of being in shape. You feel better! Or, as the old saying goes, nothing tastes as good as being in shape. Everything improves and it makes it easy to return to that gym or workout.

I just enjoyed and admired a wonderful performance--including  the sexuality of the artists. Art allows us to feel, imagine, reflect, feel pleasure or pain--it can send powerful messages, motivate us to act, or just inspire us to dream. Their performance accomplished all and more :-)

"The answer, I think, is to watch these types of performances like a man."

Precisely. Men watch the Super Bowl without thinking about themselves.

This article is old fashioned and defeatist.  Women in good health can absolutely maintain their health and physical fitness through middle age and even when they are elderly.    I’m 8 years older than J. Lo, and I look pretty good overall - I can still rock climb and I can still rock a bikini. No plastic surgery, fillers, or botox needed. Just eating right, exercising regularly, and taking care of my health.  My stepmother still runs marathons in her 70’s.   It doesn’t take a lot of time to take care of yourself.  I raised a family, and worked full time and had a great career while doing it.

There is no way that Jlo can make me feel bad. I didn't look like her when I was 30, and won't look like her now. I definitely look at her with the male gaze according to the writer, because I would never in a million years see her as any sort of reflection of what I should or could look like in 3 more years. she's just all sorts of amazing!

I commend you thoughts and as a man at 58 I feel the pressure. However, many years ago, I came to this thought: I am pretty enough. It may seem simplistic, but it has helped me shed any conceptions or feelings by others of what I should look like. Our reliance on the opinions of others for our self worth is a cancer. If we speak up for ourselves, imagine that this is the best we got and that that is more than satisfactory I think we soar above the clouds. Safe and secure in our look and own opinion of what is important. Looks fade. Self confidence and wisdom need not.

I know this probably won't seem like any consolation, but Jennifer Lopez is a media celebrity, so it is literally her JOB to look "hot" AND be incredibly fit.

And not only that, apparently its her job now to defy aging as well.

I'm sure that both "jobs" are basically 24-7.

And I know it may seem hard to believe, but a lot of men know all of this too, and so they don't really think of her as anything but a fantasy.

And in one sense at least, that's what she is. There really is a kind of dichotomy in our world between "fantastic women" and actual ones, and part of being a man is learning how to recognize the difference.

Sooner or later, most of us DO learn this!
Gyms all around the world are filled with gorgeous 50 (and 60) year old women who are at the peak of their conventional beauty -- and staying there. Takes work though.

The author misses quite spectacularly the truth about men and their collective relationship with extraordinary achievement.  We all dreamed in our youths of being the next Gretzky, Jeeter or Jordan.  Dreamed of lifting the Stanley Cup overhead to the roar of a crowd, wearing gold at the Olympics with the national anthem playing, a champion, for all to see.  I am two years older than Sidney Crosby, but I didn't grow up to be him, only he did, and I got to watch and realise that my time had well and truly passed when at 20, I saw someone younger ascend to the pinnacle of athletic achievement.  The author complains about the constant pressure on women, the promises to them, to be attractive, and laments and complains that J. Lo seems to have pushed the envelope on what is possible even later in life, chasing something so many of them can never have.  It is not that men did not dream of unachieveable goals, it is that we knew before we reached high school that it was something we would never have.  How men deal with their looks, or how they age, was never the correct comparison.
She's an entertainer. It's part of her job to look good. The costs are even tax deductible.

This made me laugh out loud: Their inner voice whispers, "Are there any more nachos?" 

So true.

Though in reality we do have insecurities about our bodies - just perhaps not to the same degree because of societal norms.

The lesson learned: dance is a wonderful, fun form of exercise for all ages. 

Get up off the couch and move.

You're just catching up to what many older women have been experiencing in our youth obsessed culture. I'm 62. Will I ever in my 60s, 70s and 80s look like Jane Fonda? Nope. And I don't want to. I love and appreciate how women like Betty White, Blythe Danner, Isabella Rossellini and many others have aged naturally, gracefully and beautifully. They are my role models.
Are you supposed to look that good at 50? Only if you're a celebrity who can afford all of the procedures and maintenance required.

So, 65 y/o man here, and totally loathe the premise here. Unless one actually *wants* to be an eyesore, the older one gets, the harder one needs to try. A 16 y/o can grab an oversize, promo tee out of a free box, put it on, and look totally great. That is decidedly *not* the case for most of us on the downside of 30. Nothing quite as depressing as those elder couples one sees at Home Depot, identical khaki, elastic waist pants, identical mannish haircuts, matching white sneakers. Hey, I watch plenty of football, but I also live by Kate Moss’ dictum: “nothing tastes as good as skinny feels”.

I think J.Lo looks fantastic and I aspire to look as good as she does when I hit 50 (recognizing I don't have the endless hours to train the way she does).  Within my own power, and the time I have committed to working out, I will be as strong, toned, fit and healthy as I can be. For me it is about not giving up mentally and physically. But to each their own!

I don’t understand what the author is trying to communicate.  I’m a 50  woman and I have not given up trying to look my best.  Being fit and healthy makes me feel good. I’m not doing it for others. I’m doing it for myself. I certainly do not feel judged by women like JLo who look amazing. That is how she makes a living, from her looks and her artistic abilities. I don’t expect to look like her and I don’t feel feel the need to. I resent the implication that once you turn 50 you should give up as a woman. I think the author needs to focus on other priorities. The reality is no one cares what she looks like.

I will point out - because I've seen several people comment on it - that article writers frequently do not write their own titles or bylines, and I don't know that this one really captures the essence of the piece. I would be very interested to know if Ms. Weiner wrote it herself.

I have a family photo of my mom's aunts at a family party in Pittsburgh circa 1935.  They are women of an indiscriminate age -- forties? fifties? sixties? -- in flowing floral print dresses. The lovely dresses show that they cared about their appearance, but nothing in their faces or posture showed that they took any confidence or pride in it.  And why should they? Back then they lacked social currency and were relegated to kitchen tables or church basements. My grandfather called his sisters "the beef trust."  As a famous author and columnist you might not have the noticed that women past a certain age are made to feel invisible.  For those that have noticed, and for the memory of my great aunts, women like JLo are a gift.

I'm out of my ;lane here, but as a guy:  "Their inner voice whispers, Are there any more nachos? "
Nailed it. Great piece.

The narcissism of our era is fully manifest here. I'm reminded of the scene in Pride and Prejudice, wherein Lady Catherine de Bourgh declares with self-reflective hauteur, "If I had ever learnt [to play the piano], I should have been a great proficient."  The author of this piece cannot see J. Lo as J. Lo. It's all about the writer, how she feels, what she might have become if only her genes, character, life choices, and talent had allowed. The injustice, inequality, and downright cruelty of the world is not to be borne. Welcome to the teenage years.They last and last.

I’m 47 and have been THRILLED since that halftime Show. I feel empowered, stronger, more beautiful — and trust me, I don’t look like that. JLo turned 50 from frumpy to gorgeous and this middle-aged white mom who hasn’t hit the gym in over a year is grateful. You go, girl.

I’m well past 50, and regret, too often, not having the means to hang out at my dermatologist’s office, bemoaning my wrinkled, “crepey” skin and becoming ten years younger (-looking). I think I’d look great in a flesh colored body suit, if prepped beforehand with costly, transformative injections and laser treatments. Yet there’s something vaguely weird about a person looking (and acting) ten or twenty years younger. Maybe I’m thinking of the “age ghost,” a musty, crepey tag-along. Still, good for you, JL.
Love this! Masterfully written.

Being 50 is realizing that what  Mom said when we were anxiety ridden teenagers  is actually true.....everyone is special in some way.  

Being 50 means we are proud of our own accomplishments, and we stop looking at everyone else to rate what we should and could be doing with our lives. Stop looking at Facebook and Instagram.

Being 50 means (for most) having a significant other that really likes me for me, not for my six pack abs. 

OK, now really more of a twelve-pack.

This whole Super Bowl halftime show fracas is another example of how the media, by weaponizing “controversy-for-profit” click bait, have trained the population to exist in a perpetual state of outage.  

No longer can we just exist as a passive viewer of an event; we are now conditioned to search for a reason to be outraged, offended, personally slighted, and then to amplify our alignment on social media. 

How do we break out of this habit?

My wife is 70 years old and she is much more beautiful than Shakira or JLo.   Her eyes and her smile melt my heart.   I watched the half time show and I couldn't wait to just hold her tight and thank my lucky stars.

Listen, if you feel personally judged by someone else's actions that are in no way a connected to your appearance, that's your problem.   Staying in shape and looking young is part of J'Lo's career and business strategy.  It is what it is and that's her choice.  Same with beauty magazines, etc, etc - you're going to have to deal with it.  Obviously you have priorities that are different than J'lo's.  I would recommend examining the internal thoughts you are having that are causing you to feel bad about this.

Tina Turner looked great in her 50's, 60's, 70's and now 80's long before J-Lo.  You don't have to be perfection.  Just be healthy and take care of yourself. Women should stop comparing themselves to other women. Age gracefully and accept who you are.  I have friends who go the full beauty routine in the 50-80 years of age spectrum and others who do nothing. They are all beautiful.  Right on Shakira and J-Lo!  Women do not have to adhere to an outdated template of what they should look like when they age.

My awesome wife is celebrating her 53'd Bday today.  Every day she looks awesome to me.  I tell her everyday and celebrate her.  I do not compare her to anyone, even to pictures of her from our honeymoon, post-child birth x3, or yesterday.  Life is hard, motherhood is hard, marriage is hard.  One thing both men and women do not need, nor should women do, is try to compare themselves to someone who works so hard every day on her appearance.  It is a false sense of self and self worth.  Love who you are everyday for all of you, not just the surface!

If you're not a singer/dancer/superstar/celeb, then no one expects you to look like JLo. It's her job to look that good, unfortunately. Also, Blanche at 50 IN THE 80S is different than JLo in 2020 because culture is different. You should feel good about how you look and that's it.

If you had watched like a man, you wouldn’t have watched at all. I’m there for the game, not the half-time show. And you’re wrong to generalize that men have no remorse about not being young and in good physical shape anymore. Getting old is no picnic in the park for anyone—regardless of gender. As they say, it’s not for the feint of heart.

Of course staying in shape is a full time job for J Lo--well, not entirely full time, since I suppose her day job (for which she does this) consumes more of her time--but Jennifer Weiner is so female-obsessed that she fails to notice that what she writes is true of men as well. How many of us look as good or run as fast as Tom Cruise? Both of them are good role models for those who want to keep fit as they age. I'm a man who's older than both of them and am filled with admiration for their physiques. (Football holds no interest for me, so I didn't see J Lo in Super Bowl 2020, but I recently saw her in Hustlers and Tom C in American Made. Keep up the good work, or the good work-outs, sez I.)
Jennifer Lopez looks better than most 20 year olds!  Timeless gorgeousness.  PLUS talent!  She’s amazing compared to women AND MEN of any age!!!!
This made me laugh.  And I needed that!  As a cusp Gen Xer, I have to say it also blew my mind that Shakira is 43.  Her spirit of fun is what I found inspirational.

It's definitely not healthy to see J.Lo and feel personally threatened. I don't see why the writer couldn't make this point without resorting to insulting the opposite sex, presenting the idea that men don't feel threatened by the pinnacle of athletic achievement the players embody as if it were because "their inner voice whispers are there any more nachos", and how "it wouldn't even occur to them to feel bad." Regardless of their sex or the gender, most well-adjusted viewers of professional athletes and musical performers actually don't feel bad about or threatened by the spectacle they're enjoying, but instead delight in the elite accomplishment.

When J. Lo came out on stage my three-year-old grandson asked, "Is she the winner?" 
Oh yes she is, we said.
Lighten up everybody.  I'm as strident as the next feminist, but she and Shakira deserve props for being able to do what they did at any age.
(and please pass the nachos....)

In all that is going on in this country and the  world, what does I matter that the Halftime show showed off beautiful people just like a fashion show.  I am sure they were paid a ton of money and if your job is to be a dancer than they were successful. Entertainment is what sells and is money in the bank.

It just doesn't matter in the bigger picture. Its fun to have an afternoon of relaxation  and then we go back to the true terrors of the real world.

> Women watch a 15-minute show featuring elite entertainers and, in some cases, end up feeling bad about ourselves.

> Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter.

Making a lot of stereotypical assumptions there about both male and female viewers.

Weiner says "Men see entertainment, athletes who exist on a different plane than mere mortals. Their inner voice whispers, Are there any more nachos? I don’t even think it would occur to them to feel bad, or try to emulate what they saw."

Wow. Either she knows no men, or those few she knows do not open up to her about men's issues with their bodies. Its worse for women, but nearly all of us guys wish we had those perfect athletic bodies too, but we do not admit it out loud, in public. Most of us grew up painfully aware we lacked the strength and beauty of the school jocks. 

Look at the lead male actors in any American movie and tell me how many are chubby or short. Those who are short are cleverly filmed to appear taller. Talk to any American man who is less than about 5 and half feet and ask them if they can get dates with women taller. 

Its true that there is a wider band of acceptable appearance for men, especially if one's flaws are mitigated with wealth or social status. Thus you see men like Trump or Jeff Bezos with a partner or succession of trophy wives far more physically attractive than they are. As Henry Kissinger said (married to a woman taller and prettier then he), "power is the best aphrodisiac". This does not seem to be as true for women as for men, but realize that the number of men who have wealth, power, and social status is a small minority. Most of us are low status schlubs in the mold of Rodney Dangerfield and we "don't get no respect" either.
A 50-year-old woman who makes her living by dancing, singing, entertaining, yes, should. She gets paid for that. And good for her! Most of us don’t. And we don’t need to feel pressure to.

I felt personally judged by the red blur I thought most likely was Tyreek Hill. I would call that some unrealistic speed. Yet he still possesses it, I do not, and people watch him and not me. 

And yet everyone is none the worse.

Actor Kumail Nanjiani's hot new buff body had Twitter and late night T.V. abuzz. I remember on Colbert that he made a statement to the effect that his results were a function of his employment. He had the best trainers, dietitians and other resources that most people can't afford and don't have time for. I rather appreciated his self-effacement. As for J Lo, looking great at 50 is the substance of her celebrity appeal. After all, it's certainly not her voice or her 'dancing'  which in any case I can see at a local Dallas club that goes by the name of "Baby Dolls."

As far as I can tell there was no live singing, so this was essentially a dance spectacle. My brother turned to me and said "this is completely A.D.D." and I agreed. That's what expensive entertainment has essentially become. Flash bang boom. Which has its place as spectacle but eventually your mind doesn't really process it anymore because there's no CONTRAST with more subtle sections. 

Physically, as dancers, Jennifer Lopez and Shakira are skilled and appeal to my lizard brain. But 12 minutes was plenty. As music, it was really non-existent. The best super bowl performance in recent memory was Prince; saw whatever else you will, but vocally and musically it was far superior. 

I would also agree that Lopez/Shakira was highly sexualized. But so is the whole culture. Physical attractiveness can neither be denied nor escaped. It's part of life as animals. The male gaze is real, but so is the female gaze. Otherwise Bon Jovi would not have a career either. haha.

Dear Jennifer,
some people are born with better brains, some are born with better bodies, some are born with both.  No amount of exercise and no perfect diet I'll every do will make me look like the other Jennifer you write about.  Get over it, accept yourself.  Most of us are average all the way around.  I appreciate beauty in people and in nature, and I am  especially thankful for those with big brains and those who have big brains coupled with good consciences and morals.  Don't compare yourself with others, just be thankful for your good health and the people who love you just the way you are.
Exercise, eat a very disciplined diet, focus on  mental health and you will look great at 50.
Thanks for writing this. My thoughts exactly.

I remember when a friend of mine pointed out that Playboy bunnies and Martha Steward were equally damaging to women. 
Sometimes it is hard to remember that no one feels the oppression more than the J-Los of the world.

The analogy of out of shape men watching athletic men play football and not judge themselves doesn't quite hold up. In addition to lean, low percent body fat, wide receivers making diving catches, you also have very heavy offensive and defensive linemen who are very muscular, but also carry significant body fat.  Men don't watch the game to compare themselves to the athletes, they watch the game because of the competition.  J Lo on the stage is all about how J Lo fits a female stereotype of beauty and how she moves, as well as her singing.  The only competition here is if women decide that they need to compare themselves to her to see how they measure up to that stereotype.
For goodness sake everyone...she is an entertainer. THEY ARE PAID TO LOOK THAT WAY!

As a man who's approaching 50 and takes care of himself (and has a body that shows it), I don't understand why anyone finds it shocking that a 50-year-old can be fit. It doesn't take a ridiculous amount of gym time; my wife and I work out about 2.5 hours per week and eat reasonably Monday - Thursday (and whatever we want on weekends). Like the obesity epidemic, it's a sad statement about the eagerness with which our society embraces a sedentary, gluttonous lifestyle.
Relax and take a look at the 50 year old guys around you.
Oh Please!  Madonna and Cher has been showing women that age is just a number for years.  Stop with the pity non-sense and join the other active ladies snow skiing, sailing, and rocking it out daily.
If you haven’t already read “The Joy of Cooking Naked” elsewhere in this paper today, head on over there and feel better about your body immediately.
My wife is 54.  She looks a LOT sexier than J. Lo.  My wife is thin, shapely, sexy.  J. Lo is way, way overrated!
Why must people make everything about themselves?

Lots of judgmental and critical comments from NYT readers about two inspirational women who have worked incredibly hard to master their craft and appearance.  Your insecurity is not on them, or the male species.  You own that and it's your choice.

Ms. Weiner’s use of the term “pearl clutcher” seriously lowers the tone of this discussion — or I should say any possible discussion that might spin off from her “lite” essay. The snideness and diminution that lie behind that label are rooted in the worst kind of internet trolling behavior. 

Call me whatever you wish, but I am turned off by the entire, raunchy, tasteless spectacle of Super bowl halftime shows. Lopez’s pole dancing is cringeworthy, regardless of her gender so skill as a dancer. I posted this in a comment that has gone missing, so I will post it again: Aside from Lopez’s high level of physical fitness, nothing about her artificial look is anything to aspire to, be intimidated by, or be jealous of. Hers is a highly curated and corrected image. It is her job to look like that.

SB halftime shows are twerking and pole-dancing now.

This is more fuel for the Evangelicals to reelect Trump...SAD
The article raises important issues-I almost passed it by due to the terrible headline.

Stop. She's not real. Your job is opinion writer. Her job (HER JOB) is to exercise and diet so she artificially looks "as good" as she does. Where she falls short, magazine editors air-brush her image.

Not to diminish her hard work that she's put into her career, but the only thing J.Lo's body is "judging" is how pathetically superficial our "popular culture" is...

Frankly as a man , a husband and a father, I was embarrassed by the half-time show.  Between Shakira and Jennifer, it was a soft-porn extravaganza that has no place on prime time family sports shows!  I applaud J Lo and Shakira for their continued physical and artistic prowess, but a TV sports show is not the outlet.  Shame on Pepsi and all the folks leading that charge.

I totally relate to the depression that sinks in when seeing the celebrity bodies - male and female - when compared to us mere mortals.  It makes it really tough to raise "normal" anything.  Why some of us want to have this alternate reality in our faces is just as confusing to me as someone liking fake news and being lied to by elected officials.
Absolutely, yes!

We shouldn't be lulled into the perception of the body perfect J'Lo, because when I looked more carefully at her outfit I saw that it was designed to give the appearance of narrow hips and thighs.  However, she wore a sort of spandex arrangement to girdle her thighs and hips with a darker fabric running vertically on the outer portion of hips and thighs to give the illusion that the flesh colored narrower spandex was her actual body shape.  Sooo, in reality she is pretty hippy with wider thighs.  And, do you suppose she was wearing a wig?  My point is, girdles, wigs, and strategically designed clothing can give you a much improved appearance.  I still wonder about the singing because it was barely audible and could never be considered real talent.  

I will concede that J'Lo is an attractive woman and she can do some athletic dance moves, but why the need to be a sexual object.  Is that your highest calling as a woman?  And why isn't she ready to embrace her maturity in a respectful manner.
You should at least try. If that's what you're into.

Well, if 50-year-olds worked out, and pole-danced for a living you might have a great body too. J.LO'S talents far exceed just dancing, her recent and past movies are a tribute to that fact. Don't be envious ,just  get off that sofa and move your body more.
Too much sitting causes middle age spread. Parks, gyms  are waiting for you, and just walking around the block is great excerise.
Can a woman of color do anything without having a white woman comment on it, For All Women?

This is ridiculous.  JLo and Shakira make a living at performing.  They are the best at what they do and should NOT be shamed in any way.  If you can handle the excellence in their field, don't watch them...and if your jealous, get out of your chair, work out for 8 hours a day, and manage every single morsel that goes in your mouth, and be prepared to perform in front of millions of people...Oh and by the way, JLo and Shakira are not working to chastise those who have taken career paths in journalism...though perhaps they should.

Women, move on. If you want to look like JLo, do the work. You can’t possibly believe that she looks like that without hard work and sacrifice, correct? Yes she has all of the resources available to her (money, fame) however, it would be my guess that she worked really hard to attain that as well. 
Do I think she should have pole danced in front of the world (young children)? No, I think she should have taken a more sophisticated and honorable way to display her talent.
Where was all the outrage from mom’s last year regarding shirtless Adam Levine? Funny

When men come and shake their Spandex-enhanced booty at women's sports events, perhaps I will feel vindicated.

Or perhaps I will feel sad that they have no better judgment than the women who rush to get this attention.
J Lo's body has nothing to do with yours. Why compare?
As they say, money don't crack.

I turned off the half-time show as soon as I realized this was just another sexual bonanza that, as is so pervasive throughout the world, just commoditizes women as objects of male fantasies.  What world-class, extraordinary, Super Bowl-worthy value did this performance have that couldn't have been seen at the local men's club?

I'm 52. My daughter, 29, teaches pole. She has pretty severe kyphosis and it's taken her over 6 six years to be able to do that. It was hard work, hard and slow and awkward and she didn't look like a dancer at all in the beginning. It didn't matter that she was in her early 20's. I would assume, from your piece, that you haven't taken a pole class or exotic dance class lately. If you had, you would see all kinds of sizes and abilities. You would see cellulite (yes, on 20 year olds) and all those terrifying things that women aren't supposed to have. You would also see all those regular looking women cheering each other on, literally cheering. 
But the most important thing is what you would feel.
If you want to feel judged, that's quite unnecessary.  But you could feel power, freedom and a body that belongs to you.
How about getting excited for her?
How about signing up at your local pole studio and experiencing what it feels like to dance when awesome women ARE watching?
How about ditching the old stereotype that other women are your competition and taking entertainment personally?

Wow - am I grateful J.Lo's & Shakira half-time show didn't induce any negative thoughts, like inadequacy and/or envy in my psyche.  Could it be that, because I'm 10 years older than the writer here, and therefore came of age as a woman during a high point of the Feminist Movement (capital "F" intentional) in the 1970's, I've avoided that trap?  While I was captivated by their Half-Time performance what did worry me was, "Are female vocalists now EXPECTED to be over-sexualized? Fifty years ago we adored Grace Slick, Aretha Frankln, Barbara Streisand, Janis Joplin and their peers for their musical abilities alone.  Madonna ushered in this overt sexuality - but her intention was to EMPOWER women to take pride in their sexual desires - to own it and enjoy it.  Unfortunately the music industry was and still is DOMINATED by men. The good news is artists like Lizzo are expanding our expectations of female sexuality.  Still - was Mick Jagger expected to perform barely clothed?
One more stab at women as only being sex objects. So stupid. What a set back for feminism. Men do not have to respond to feminism, because women will do the hard work for us.

I didn't see the "performance" as it aired but when I caught the highlights on the morning news shows I stopped in my tracks. Expected much more outrage in these pages and on social media about the content of the "performance" what with #MeToo, Epstein, Weinstein, sex slave trafficking, we're more than our looks strong women take us seriously, etc. Not for one moment was I thinking that's how I or ANY woman is supposed to look (at ANY age!) I am sad for little girls AND BOYS viewing these "performances" as role models. sigh....
The Super Bowl is a high value, low brow spectacle that scratches an anti intellectual itch. Are you not entertained?
The show was thrilling. So what if the performers look great. That’s their bread and butter. But, the crotch shots were weird regardless of age.

J Lo has money to pay trainers and chefs to cook. If you had that much money, you might be in her shoes. And spandex smooths out bumps; all that hair consists of extensions. Don't be taken in by the spectacle, which is admittedly gorgeous but took a boatload of preparation. Props to J Lo!! But more important: acting as if 50 means tunics and bifocals signals something other than a worry about physical appearance. It's that attitude that women over 50 are already old and sexless -- disposable and on the sidelines in shroud-like garments. Check out the That's Not My Age FB page and podcast - a huge rebuttal to all of that. Women our age don't need to wear only black (it really bothers me that so many of us dress like every day is a funeral, bc it's "slimming") and try with each encroaching day to take up less space, and I don't mean our butts, I mean our voices, our inner lives. Why do you have to dance in private? Before you capitulate to J Lo standards, get comfortable in the body you have. Be glad it works. Take some joy in movement - walking and yes, dancing. I suspect that even if you looked like her, you'd be hiding. Don't.

J-Lo and Shakira represent an obsolete and archaic definition of beauty. Being nearly naked on a stripper pole is not viewed as empowering or something to celebrate, but being a healthy, athletic woman is.  The performers played into Fox TV's looking for crotch shots.  I think the performers did women, especially latino women a disservice if the message is this is where empowerment comes from. My wife is a very athletic and very health conscious 55 year old who is very beautiful and very accomplished in her own right. Thats what sexy is in 2020.

I read yesterday that it took TEN (10!!!) hours for her makeup and hair to get done.  Seriously, we would all look that good if we had her resources, "glam team", in-home chef, personal trainer, et al.  I'm 52 and have never been this happy or this heavy in my life.  I'm so glad to be sitting on the couch watching her spin around than even attempt to hold my body weight up on a stripper pole.  She looks amazing and I have no interest in denying her the moment she had on Sunday.  Good for her!

Consider me a Pearl Clutcher.  I find it utterly pathetic that women with as much talent as J Lo (though admittedly better on the screen than behind a mic) and Shakira, at their age, after all of their success and power, STILL have to shake their butts in lingerie to entertain.

If the two of them had come out in jeans and t-shirts, and we could have just focused on Shakira's amazing voice and musical talent, it would have been a far more meaningful show.  

It is just pathetic how these women sell themselves short.

A very important conversation undermined by an incredibly offensive title. J Lo's body isn't the problem. Her body isn't anyone's damn business, and the fact that we obsess over it is itself an element of misogyny. 

The final paragraphs about how we watch 3 hours of athletic men on the field without a single comment about their bodies is well-taken. 

Men and women must stop policing women's bodies. Whether positive or negative, the constant barrage of conversations about women's looks is exhausting and regressive.

We're really just whiffing right past the casual & reductive sexism of assuming that men can't be bothered to notice the fawning over whatever actor just got sucked into the Marvel universe and went through their body transformation regimen?  You think the audible gasps in theatres when Brad Pitt took his shirt off on that roof didn't land on any of our psyches?  I would never make the argument that men face anything like what women face when it comes to expectations of our bodies, but please don't assume we're too busy inhaling nachos and drinking beer to ever think about this.

Well done, Jennifer. You speak to a broad population of women whose mental outlook has been self-molded by buying into the marketing whipped up around it. It is not easy and takes courage to just be. To accept who we are, what we look like, without the barrel of marketing and the insanity of the selfie crowd staring down on us. I was hiking Torrey Pines, CA last Thursday and I noticed two things: overrun with people was the first and the second was how many selfies were being taken. Seriously, the walk is about nature and not another damn selfie. Me, me, me.....

What a perfect article, both about how older women feel and the vile way our society regards women in general.

One of the great benefits of being 70, I find, is not giving a damn anymore!

This is all very surprising. Two professional singers, dancers, performers, and in Shakira's case, drummers, guitarists, and belly dancers, put on an incredible, artistically and technically amazing show and all anyone can talk about is How Dare They.

So, JLo, this is her pathetic "Madonna Moment." 
Coming from one who loved Madonna, until an old woman started obviously, desperately, trying not to look her age.  The heavy makeup, the poor lip synching, the over-exhibitionist nonsense "routine" that is supposed to be "sexy" or "challenging" by a person on the wrong side of the half-century mark.  Its repulsive, not risque'. Painful stuff to watch. 

It's sad, actually, and one should feel sorry for JLo that she feels compelled (and this was her OWN choice - make no mistake about that) to do such a "performance."  It is no secret that societal mores have evolved quickly in the last 25 years, but JLo made a deliberate choice to look and act like a tramp on international T.V.  Pole-dance routine, for a 50 year old? ... uh, okay. But yuck. 

Does anyone remember what she sang? Does anyone actually care?  Yeah, didn't think so. 

The author is correct that such things set an awful example. It is a gross commentary on the state of society. 

And don't misunderstand:  when past-it, has-been male rockers (e.g., the Rolling Stones, Guns n Roses, etc.) squeeze bloated, out of shape or even in shape guts & butts into leather pants, and sing and dance likes it 1989?  Even more ridiculous. 

Where are the new, young, exciting talents?

First of all, a middle-aged white woman writing "dat ass" to refer to a latinx woman in an NYT column is, sadly, a much less outrageous sight in 2020 than it should be. 

Second, I hope the columnist can take some solace from the recent photos of Kumail Nanjiani that the actor posted, and the letter detailing the pain, commitment and *financial cost* of his fitness transformation. 

To wit: JLo, Nanjiani, they both underwent/undergo a fitness regimen that costs close to a million dollars a year and at least as much time weekly as a part-time job. If you were rich, you could do the same. Most of us could. 

JLo is not "a fifty-year-old woman in incredible shape." 
JLo is "A fifty-year-old career millionaire who is incredible shape because after a lifetime of having her looks and body professionally managed, she was paid by the hollywood machine to develop expert-level pole dancing skills for a movie." 

If the columnist wants to feel bad about something, she should feel bad for being a middle-aged white woman referring to a latinx woman's butt as "dat ass." BAD LOOK. 

But she should not be comparing her human self with the contracted fitness of a hollywood celebrity in 2020. That way lies disorder.

So help me to understand this new kind of shaming women are now subject to ! First of all, most of us normal human working women (of any age )  were feeling inadequate after watching those two women 'perform', and now we are called "Pearl Clutchers"  for feeling that way ( whats wrong with pearls, too classy for you? ), and for feeling that the entire performance, the scanty costumes, the pole dancing and the explicit moves were inappropriate and uncomfortable to watch during a football game !  Please also help me to understand how after we normalize and glorify that kind of performance, women think they can still demand to be treated with respect and not be viewed as a sex objects? And then ( some cases are justified ! ) these women cry 'Me Too " when men respond to this behavior ??  I am a proud " Pearl Clutcher", class ( and brains ! ) will always win over crass ( and ass ) in the end !
Do men think the same way? Get over it. You are what you are.

I'll give up trying to look like a goddess when Madonna does. Ladies, she's 61 years old! Jlo is a babe compared to her. A super hot babe and yes I want to be able to strut my stuff like that, unapologetically!
Someone pass me those Cheetos.

Would somebody please tell me why two highly talented and successful women, aged 43 and 50, are required to wiggle their bottoms and flash their inner thighs to an arena filled mostly with howling men.

With all this fussing, my sex is showing their insecurity. I'm already in my 60s, I loved the show, enjoyed both but especially Shakira, and didn't feel any pressure or envy. Get over yourselves ladies, it's not about you.

67 year-old female boomer here, yes, I’m wearing Eileen Fisher... right now. (I love looking chic and being comfortable simultaneously.) I I can admire JLo’s athleticism and talent, but crotch-shots and pole-dancing, no thanks. We’re sending the message that sexuality is power, and that’s what (when men wield it) got us into this whole mess in the first place.

Oh, and by the way, you can’t fight gravity, everything droops eventually ;).  It will be interesting to watch JLo age.

"... the Shakers and the Clutchers ..."

As usual, the self-appointed cultural analysts oversimplify. Even a cursory viewing* of the half-time show finds that:

1. J. Lo has a muscular bicep noticeable when she holds the microphone. Meaning she works out.

2. J. Lo is variously accompanied by dancers who are men, women, and children. Meaning she advocates diversity.

3. J. Lo performs with Shakira, as Weiner notes, and with two MALE singers, J Balvin and Bad Bunny, both of whom Weiner ignores. Meaning that there is no sexism in the casting. 

"... come sit back here, with me, in your Eileen Fisher tunic and the newish bifocals you haven’t quite mastered."

And be a passive spectator. Instead, Weiner should learn to watch closely and thereby improve her critical skills.

* On Youtube.

"Are we really supposed to look this good at 50 now?"

That's only the start.  To keep up, you will also have to learn pole dancing.
Just curious how many women were in the room when the decision was made to put J-Lo on the strippers pole.

J-Lo? She looks great. Then again if I was worth 400 million dollars, I assume I'd look great as well, but I'm going to keep doing what I"m doing. I had a physical last week and my numbers are good. My pre-diabetes seems to have gone away and I have excellent blood sugar.  I do yoga, Pilates, I walk everywhere, I ride a bicycle, and I lift weights. Also, I'm a man. I'm 70 years old. I'm around 20 pounds overweight.  Around 1/3 of my hair is gone down the drain. I wear glasses. My right knee has had four operations. I sprained and broke my wrist last fall.  I'm learning how to play the violin, I read a lot, and I like a glass of wine at the end of the day. Elvis shook his hips. The Beatles had long hair (sort of). Marylin Monroe wore a tight dress for President Kennedy in 1962. Michael Jackson grabbed his crotch whenever he liked. Madonna was, Madonna, and Janet Jackson had some clothing problems. So what? Lighten up, campers. Life is too short to worry about this nonsense. We're all doing what we can to get through it. So, let's look at it this way. I'm alive. I'm healthy. I really don't worry about what anyone else look like - good, not so good, and so forth. The whole thing is a mysterious trip, so why worry? My grandfather made it to 84, and my dad to 83. I'm just going to keep on rocking until this dance is over.

Good for J-Lo!  She's fit and stunning at 50.  She showed us what a great body she has.  She shook that thing and slid down a stripper pole so we wouldn't forget she was in "Hustlers."

We have an unrealistic ideal of beauty and what a 50 year old woman should look like.  Most of us don't look anything like this.  

If you've lived your life well, had some babies, or not, and you don't look like J-Lo, don't worry about it.  It's a manufactured concept to sell us all kinds of stuff and keep us dieting and struggling to fit into clothing we have no business trying to wear.

Real beauty has nothing to do with how you shake your rear end and bounce all over a stage.  It comes from within and has to do with how you comport yourself while walking through life.

This is all smoke and mirrors.  I see naked bodies all week long as a physician, and no real-life 50-year-old looks like that.  Creating that image is a full-time job, and requires a great deal of intervention.  If J. Lo wants to be celebrated for still being able to proudly display and shake her booty at age 50, that's her perogative.  I like to think many of us have greater gifts to offer by the time we reach our 50th birthday, and better ways to spend our time than trying to preserve or re-create a youthful appearance.

I am so confused. Why would any everyday woman compare herself to someone with millions of dollars, a nutritionist, a nanny, and a make up artist? Why? It defeats the purpose.

In addition, as an "Ass Shaker", as you so disrespectfully labeled us, I am proud of the Caribbean/ African/ Indigenous  rhythms that blend to create my music. Salsa, merengue, bachata and cumbia are felt in our blood and danced with every ligament in our bodies. It's called culture.

Hopefully, Eurocentric, Puritanical people will come to appreciate the non-European standards of beauty and culture. And if you, don't, we will continue to happily shake our asses.

This column is predicated on the belief that looks are the primary thing that matters about you. How sad. Forget about whether you look as good as a trashy "entertainer" and focus on your inner self. Read some interesting books. Learn to paint, or to photograph (and I don't mean the ubiquitous selfie). Or even (gasp!) deepen your spiritual life. When you've left this earth, those are the things people will remember you for, not whether you looked good at age 50 with your crotch wrapped around a pole.

I miss the more innocent  times where a fully clothed  dancer known as Left Shark earned Super Bowl  half time show immortality  as a total  klutz  who didn't know the dance routine.

In the interest of fair play  male entertainers have given their share of cringeworthy  performances.  I remember when Adam Levine  looked as though he was auditioning  for Chippendales when he ripped off his shirt at the halftime show.   Ugh.
I wish I could write fiction.  Sigh.

My 62 year old husband looks in the mirror and thinks he's hot.  He may even dance around naked sometimes in front of me just so he can bless my eyeballs with his hotness.  I look in the mirror and.....well, you know the answer.......

So ladies, let's change the paradigm.  Embrace our inner J Lo and don't forget to pass the nachos....

We seriously need to stop celebrating this kind of salaciousness. It tells women that the only way to be successful (read sex-cessful) is if they wear revealing clothing, spend oodles of time dieting/exercising, and when given the opportunity dance ultra suggestively (hello crotch shots and stripper poles!?!). Have you seen Bollywood dance moves? Those moves are impressive without being suggestive. America's entertainment is going down the toilet and I am disappointed in anyone who thinks that's the route we should continue down.
In other news, I'm really offended that I don't have the body of Tommy Brady or Brad Pitt. How many women at 25 looked like J Lo at 25??? Not many I would say.  This is just silly.
I'm 68 years old; and heck, to me, Jane Fonda still looks great!

Women can be so catty. 

I'm writing a memoir about being a stripper in 70's and know the power of being an attractive sexual  performer. I was just a dancer. I had many sexual encounters with both men and women, but I never got paid for them. I gave sex away.

Women have many powers. One of the powers is what Jennifer Lopez looks like. That's great!  She's also a great singer and dancer. Her appearance  doesn't have anything to do with how I feel about my body or myself.

"If you are pained by any external thing, it is not this that disturbs you, but your own judgment about it." or, as Marcus Aurelius might say today, "Stop with the social media.  Stop judging everything."

Part of the issue, I think, is the sexiness of the choreography.  Normally I don't like pole dancing as an aesthetic choice, but with the hypocrisy of the Trump folks (supporting an admitted sex offender who is probably responsible for several unwanted pregnancies in his lifetime)  I really liked the display of those gorgeous bodies, all of them.  I also wandered over to the fox news on twitter,  and boy were people mad.   A lot of people did not let their children watch the show!  They were offended!  I'd rather be on JLo's and Shakira's side of modern dance (such that it is!)  than live in fear we are moving towards living in the Handmaid's Tale.

I didn't watch the entire Super Bowl halftime show because I thought it was stupid, but I did watch for a few minutes in order to keep my hand on the pulse of American mass entertainment.  For one thing, all that noise was about as far from music as noise can be.  The dancing was cheap and tawdry, almost pornographic.  How this stuff passes for entertainment is beyond me.  But, of course, I realize that in matters of taste, everyone is different.  I prefer Swan Lake to this sort of nonsense.  I suspect many others do as well.

Ms. Weiner, please do the vast majority of us a big favor and join us in not paying any attention to the scandalous and over sexualized antics of Ms. Lopez, the Kardashian crowd and other 'influencers' who have seemingly taken over the public media with their fake identities.  Many of us tuned out this rubbish at half time, took a walk etc....thanks for calling this distorted worldview out, you have many supporters

So, Jennifer W., if you need to compare yourself to others in order to feel good about yourself (OK, guilty here too), compare yourself to the 300-pound lineman who in no way is 0 percent fat, whose body will be plagued by the aftermath of countless injuries and whose mind may be destroyed by dementia at an early age.
If it’s any consolation, Jennifer, I wish I could write like you do.
Betty White! Betty White! Betty White! (That's a cheer, in case you're wondering.)

This say it all!

"Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter.

Women see inspiration or goals we’ve failed to attain or a pretty stick to beat ourselves up with. We hear a voice (sponsored by Weight Watchers and Revlon and Planet Fitness and Jenny Craig) whispering This can be yours, if you just work hard enough. Men see entertainment, athletes who exist on a different plane than mere mortals. Their inner voice whispers, Are there any more nachos? I don’t even think it would occur to them to feel bad, or try to emulate what they saw."

Onward Ladies!!
At least those ladies won't get CTE from their Super Bowl participation

J Lo is a dancer, and quite a good one, whether you like her choreography or not.  That’s why she looks this good. Dancers use their whole bodies and they treat their bodies like vehicles to be well maintained. While there are a number of other celebrities that dance on their videos, the vast majority of them are not actually good dancers.
All I kept thinking was the final lines in "Hustlers": "This city, this whole country, is a strip club. You got people tossing the money, and people doing the dance."
Say anything you like about salacious, admire them for ability, and notice that made in the USA or not, the world was watching.

Simple solution: 

Don't watch these cheesy spectacles and you won't feel "judged", you won't feel inadequate and you won't feel as though you've missed anything.

And lay off the cheese and crackers while you're at it.

Do we have to have a finish line? Youth is not only expressed in Physical characteristics.  Ruth Ginsberg's forever progessive ideals will keep her young forever.  RBG does not have a finish line. J.Lo not only has a fit body; She has a creative mind that will  choreograph dances for the rest of her life.  J.Lo does not have a finish line. At 59, I do not want to see afinsh line.
This article has me laughing out loud and reading the extra clever lines to my husband.  Well done!  Your writing rivals any of those shimmies!
Actually Rue McClanahan looks gorgeous and glamorous in that meme - sparkles, plunging neckline, taut décolleté, those cheekbones!!

Do you think part of the problem is our culture, that constantly tells women their decisions are wrong or misinformed; wrong size bra and wrong sized pad turns into do you have the wrong sized body. 
Unacceptable for anyone to size shame these women, they're every bit the athletes that the NFL players are, we should be embracing each other, not casting aspersions!

In order to understand the JLo phenomenon, you have to understand Latino culture. If you go to San Juan or Bogota you will see many JLos walking around. Women take pride in their appearance. Some can call it anti-feminist but it is what it is. Many of these women are doctors, lawyers, and businesswomen. In 4inch heels... 
Even if these women don't have the JLo body, their hair is done, the heels are on, and the fashion is hot. As a Puerto Rican woman, I was in awe and proud of the performance but not shocked by how good they look. I can literally pluck 10 friends of my childhood in Puerto Rico in their 40s who defy the American standard  of aging.
I can only speak for myself.  To me, Jennifer Lopez half naked at 50 is like a  50 year old guy in a Speedo.  They are trying to hang onto the past and should know better.

I think this is the real reason why many didn't like the halftime. If Lizzo had performed in the same manner, there wouldn't have been as much backlash. We need to be honest with ourselves and find where our discomfort is really coming from.

jennifer.
in answer to your question, the answer is yes!
if you want to wear that bodysuit, writhe above the half-dressed crowd of dancers on a pole, win an oscar, have alex on your arm, spend hours at the gym and walk versace in THAT DRESS. YES!

Why do you care so much about celebrities? Don't beat yourself up so much. Jennifer Lopez probably has nothing on you. She's a mediocre talent at best and she's been primed, pushed, sprayed, lifted, pinched and pulled in order to look good for one performance. Believe it. I didn't watch the Super Bowl and I'm glad I didn't. It seems to have inflicted a lot of harm on women, and that's not good. What has Jennifer Lopez ever done, aside from preen around the stage? Has she marched for any cause, spoken out for her ideals, taken a stand on anything except herself? Not that I know of. She was doing a pole dance, for heaven's sake. Hello! It's 2020.
You denigrate the Me Too movement wit this article.  Shameful from a young woman.

Forgive the nitpicking but I find it strange to describe Jennifer Lopez's body as "bronzed" and "tanned." Far from part of an "impossible" package, she was born that way—bronze and tan. Using past participles (bronzed, tanned) rather than adjectives (bronze, tan) subtly turns Lopez's natural qualities into part of the titillation scheme. Let her skin color be part of what makes (white?) women feel bad or better yet don't...but don't turn her skin color into a barb on the pretty stick. Word choice like this sexualizes and objectifies women of color (who don't just put their skin color on as part of a costume) more than any stripper pole (a woman chooses to swing around) could.

A few of the comments here got me laughing. When I hear women  of a certain age stating that they look great and can out sexy any young thing in yoga pants, I say good for you for thinking that. “Thinking” being the operative word, because self image is all about attitude. I know a woman who is in her mid 40’s and thinks she is the bee’s knees. She looks a decade older than her calendar age, but she feels a decade younger, and she truly believes she is hot. She tells me how fabulous he is, constantly, and how random men flirt with her. I don’t see it, but she does. It makes her happy. It makes me laugh, inwardly. Everyone goes home with a smile.

It's a fantasy TV show and nothing matters but the ratings, which are up from 2019.  The opinion, good or bad, of any individual viewer, is not important.

There are millions of pretty women in their fifties and beyond.

First thing in the morning, before all the paint and powder, Shakira and JLo may not look any better than your wife or your girl friend or that hot little retired lady next door that does her yard work in short shorts and sleeveless bare midriff blouse.
As a male, your comments about what passes through our minds when watching football is 100% spot on.

There's a subtext here that women are judging other women against the J. Lo's professional level of fitness, beauty and age, but I don't see it that way.  

I see the "J. Lo" standard being propagated at the highest level advertising, products, movies, TV, news etc. by male powerbrokers who want a fantasy woman.  Take Harvey Weinstein, no woman would give him a second look if he didn't have power to make or break careers in Hollywood.   Les Wexner who built Victoria's Secret  catalog on the premise that 'any woman' could wear reasonably priced lingerie until VS stores reached critical mass acceptance then came the Miracle Bra, the Angels on the runway and the diamond encrusted bra.  VS was no longer about empowering the customer, the customer had to meet the VS standard.  (You try looking that good 6 weeks after giving birth with staples in your stomach.)  No surprise that the VS mentality fostered monsters like Jeffery Epstein and Ed Rasek. 

My point is that, yes, woman can feel empowered by pole dancing and wearing lingerie - but each woman should be judged by her own size, shape and appreciated at standard of health and fitness that is appropriate for her own circumstances - not judged some impossible fantasy unless working out is her full time job.   If she works - in or out of the home, cooks, cleans, raises the kids, etc. then her body will reflect it, yet that is what should be valued about her appearance.

My girlfriends and I spent the first half ogling the two QBs and discussing who was hotter: Garoppolo vs. Mahomes, and when the halftime show went on, we ooh’ed and awed spending the second half polling J Lo vs. Shakira. I suppose you can call that the right to have an equal female gaze impressed by all sides. From this perspective there was lot to enjoy, what a show!

I am not a fan of the latest pop music craze where athletic (gifted) singers shake their booty and flip their hair while other athletic dancers do the same around them.  I would much rather watch Annie Lennox belt out her soulful tunes, fully clothed.

That being said, I marveled at JLo and Shakira and their bodies' abilities to do all that they did.  It really is hard work. Having run track, played ultimate frisbee, and danced through the years (still dancing, thankfully), my arthritic knees have said no more and I couldn't even have contemplated the knee slide that JLo did across that stage. ("Ouch" I said as I marveled at her glorious fully-functional knees.)  

I do get it.  The patriarchy, the male gaze, the pole. But have you ever tried the pole?  It's really hard, people! Can you blame JLo for wanting to show off her rock-hard inner thighs? 

The glory of choice is that we all get to choose.  JLo and Shakira have chosen their paths. Is it for everyone, or for just us anyones? Probably not.  Can I enjoy the wonders and beauty and yes, envy, of a fit, slim, athletic, coordinated dancing female body?  Hells yeah.  Pass the wine!

Both JLo and Shakira probably trained and starved themselves full-time for months before this production!  If you think that both JLo and Shakira couldn't WAIT to get out of their Spanx-tight outfits, think again!

The fact that J.Lo and Shakira look so amazing has nothing at all to do with anyone else. This isn't a competition that they have won. As many others have mentioned, their bodies are a business that they, like elite athletes, have put tons of time and money and effort into. Some people have that as a priority. Other people spend the time meditating or getting a PhD or raising kids or being a different number of artist or whatever. One isn't better then the other. It's just where we put our priorities. No judgment, folks!

I am 50 and have had my priorities elsewhere than on being incredibly fit. I loved the halftime show, and perhaps took a bit of inspiration from it, not to look like these amazing ladies, but to walk a little further and do a few more minutes of yoga.

When we compare ourselves to others and feel bad, we're letting the patriarchy dominate us and create divisions. When we judge others to be good or bad, all we're doing is hurting ourselves. Let's let Jennifer Lopez and Shakira be Jennifer Lopez and Shakira, just as they are. Then let's let ourselves be ourselves too, in all our glorious freedom.

I enjoyed the show and admired both JLo and Shakira for the amount of work and talent that went into their performance.

The only concern I have is that celebrities--most celebrities, not just JLo and Shakira--start making it seem normal to look like that at that age.  Gossip magazines and TV and movies tout how great So-and-So looks at her age, but never mentions the plastic surgery involved (not to mention the personal trainers, chefs, spray tans, hair extensions, etc.).

It takes a TON of money and work (and surgery!) to look like that at that age.  I don't begrudge anyone for choosing those things, but I don't want it normalized.  I don't want to set the expectation that I should look that way at 50 because I am unwilling to get plastic surgery, and I can't afford personal makeup artists, hair extensions, and the like.

I remember long ago when I was in my late 20's and one of my colleagues who was in her early 40's (and very attractive) said to me: "I don't aspire to do anything more than look as well as I can for the age that I'm at."  

I think that is a healthy point of view -- I've always remembered it at embrace it...even now at 59.

Perhaps some people look at this issue more  with logic than emotion.   In my late
20’s and early 30’s I ran marathons and completed trathalons and was in darn good shape

But once kids and work and life intervenes, the only people who get to keep in that kind of shape are those who are paid to eat well and stay fit: athletes, stars and the ilk.  

My argument is that if my job was to be in the best shape possible then that occupation also pays for personal trainers, private chefs and and the time to make yourself look great every day.

So good for Jay Lo.   She gets paid very well to stay in that kind of shape and she clearly earns  for money, just like every athlete on that field on Sunday￼￼.

I watch performances like that, in many areas of the media, and think get depressed about the values of our society.

I would rather see extraordinary athletes, like Serena Williams and Megan Rapinoe. There’s much more to admire.

The great challenge it seems, determining the comparative dignity of what we value.

How about shape your own life and let others shape their's.
It is self evident what is important to J Lo, good for her. 

The key in my view is to decide for yourself and not let others influence you into being someone you really aren't.

The world has a lot bigger problems to solve, too. It helps to try and not react emotionally to the world, also. You can rarely if ever change it. 

We can change ourselves however, maybe that should be our focus. Just being kinder for example, maybe more forgiving. To each their own of course.
