I am sure that JLo and Shakira both work extremely hard to perfect their looks, athletic abilities and choreography routines. These things probably take up the bulk of their days. They probably also employ a huge team of skilled and talented hair-stylists, makeup artists, trainers, assistants, choreographers, wardrobe designers, coaches, and private chefs, because none of this comes by accident. Besides, it is JLo's and Shakira's jobs to look and act and dance and sing like that, and the better they do it, the more money they make and the more they are admired.

The rest of us are not in the entertainment field. We don't have the money, the time, the talent or the resources. We are also not followed by paparazzi or have to live up to some lofty standard. I compare it to the freedom that comes from being a commoner versus the tightly-controlled restrictions of being a princess. Yes, princesses are beautiful and admired, but would you want to be one?  Nope. Seems like an awful lot of hard work to me.

From the article:

"I have always tried to tell myself that celebrity bodies are a little like art galleries. I can appreciate and be inspired by their beauty."

I would feel much happier if your viewed your own body as a work of art and be inspired by your own beauty instead...it may be a cliche but it is 100% accurate that beauty emanates from within.  If it is an empty shell then it soon collapses into irrelevancy.

Good for Jennifer Lopez!  I really, sincerely believe that it is anxiety, stress, our over reliance on pharmaceuticals, our complete embrace of the fact that at a certain age we decline into oblivion, that ages us.  We were never meant to age the way most of society does.  We are the ones that have let our beautiful bodies down, no matter what we look like on the outside, not the other way around.

We need to re-frame ourselves.

One has to wonder what the majority of the Chiefs and Niners athletes will look like at 50 and whether or not they will be as culturally relevant as J Lo and Shakira. I saw two amazingly talented singers produce one of the most entertaining half-time shows in a long time. Singing "Born in the USA" while wearing a jacket patterned with the American & Puerto Rican flags was a particularly nice touch. That the two of them are stunningly athletic, poised and, yes, beautiful, at an age that our society traditionally considers well past prime made the show all that much better.

Ultimately, we are watching championship games because we are watching the best of the best compete while they are at the top of their game. We just saw two middle-aged people who have been at the top of the game for several decades.

This is a wonderful articulation of what it feels like to watch the half time show from the perspective of a 50-year old woman.  However, I will quibble with a single paragraph near the end where you state that "Men...watch elite athletes...and won't feel a single twinge".  Believe me, this 52-year old feels pangs of longing and regret, knowing that my once athletic body will never again participate even in a local pickup basketball game.  I enjoy watching sports now, but it is bittersweet at best as I deeply long for the days when I could participate in the sports I loved.  Aging is difficult for all of us.

Man, all the internet traffic about the half time show.  I'm sorry I missed it.  Went to an album-opening show by a fifty-something singer/songwriter who is also a drummer in my marching band.  By the time that was over the game was into its stunning fourth quarter reversal of fortune.
I many not look like that, but I think it makes people take a second look at how we view old age (now middle age, I guess!)

I find the idea that it is unusual for a 50 year old woman to be super fit and lean very disturbing. At 50, a person may live another 30-50 years. If you work out regularly and eat healthy there is no reason you can’t be in amazing shape. And you don’t need hours in the gym to do it. (Yes, I know from personal experience)

I think she looks fantastic!  She puts a lot of work into looking that great at 50.  However, I am also pretty certain medical intervention has helped shape that body (twins!) and wrinkle free face.  Hair extensions?  Money and quality technicians help a lot.  So, maybe the average woman shouldn’t compare herself because her tool kit is probably a lot less full.

Great topic and observations. As a man, I've noticed cultural changes with respect to men and their bodies (and no, I am certainly not suggesting that they face remotely the same judgment as women.) Many younger men in locker rooms seem to get dressed under towels or in bathroom stalls. A gym I had been going to for years decided to make the showers individual stalls with barriers and curtains instead of the communal setup they'd had for years. Whence this quest for privacy? Are the judging eyes everywhere? Has technology made us all 9th tier celebrities with audiences we need to cater to? Why is it looking "good" not looking "fit"? Why is one's fitness level a signifier of something beyond fitness? We all know that no matter how smart you are, there is always someone smarter. No matter how attractive you are there is always someone more attractive. Or, conversely, no matter how bad you've got it there is always someone who has it worse. It's one thing to aspire to be fitter and healthier, and to see images of fitness and beauty, but the climate that puts our very identity is at stake is profoundly unhealthy. Maybe I go to the gym because I like it, not to make a statement about my looks, which is in turn a statement about my inherent value as a person. Maybe a read because I like it, not to make a statement about how intelligent I am. We could all do with a little less self-reflection and dispense with the task of proving we are worthy of taking up space. It's tiring.

There will always be people (and animals) who are exceptional.  I can't compare myself to that person, which can be really hard for some people.  Humility comes from the fact that there are healthy 40-year-olds that eat well and exercise, and die of cancer.

I'm 58, eat fairly well, and exercise.  I'm in really good shape by any standard of people my age.  But I'm not egotistical enough to presume it is all due to my hard work.  The reality is I'm from a family with a very favorable genetic history.  That matters more than anything else - it's just my responsibility not to waste that gift.

I'm half Cuban, by the way, so maybe I have a little JLo mojo in me.

Thank you for this. I have been trying to figure out my new reading glasses situation and laughed out loud when I got to your last sentence. Such an interesting point about the way men watch sports (and eat nachos).

Just try to stay reasonably fit and to maintain muscle strength.

Good advice for getting-older women. For getting-older men, too.

As a man I can say that I feel a strong urge to do push-ups and sit-ups every time I watch a sporting event. 

Also, at 37 I realized I was succumbing to dad-bod and started working out 4 times a week and eating better. It’s about priorities.
My daughter and I felt the Secrete commercial showing women and girls playing football to more memorable and inspirational.

Oh, please.  If I were getting paid to look good, have the resources and time to work out (along with personal trainers and nutritionists), my body would would look like hers, too.  But I have a full-time job, care for a teen, and manage to squeeze in a regular workout, and I am very happy with my body the way it is--strong, allows me to do what I need to do, and is healthy.  Period.

Good point in your article. As a 56 year old woman I am told, by my boyfriend, that I have the body of a 20 yr old which is nice to hear. I work out almost every day, eat right, and generally go outside and stay in life. That’s my choice and I don’t do it for his praise but because that’s just me. So you be you, and I’ll be me (Sorry for song lyrics) and we’ll all just be fine. Ok?

Ok, while I do contend that men don't seem to care all that much about their looks as a larger trend, I do want to say men also face that sense of comparative mindset. Eating disorders in men is a serious and often ignored problem (I can attest to that myself), as that gender is taught to self-silence. That being said, I also know plenty of Nacho Grabbers. 

I don't mean to take away from the issue at hand, but I think that last part about men could do better to acknowledge the complexity / fullness of the issue.

I didn’t watch the Super Bowl: a corporate bonanza if there ever was one and thus anathema to me. But I can well imagine the spectacle of the half-time show.

And as a feminist who came of age in the 60’’s-when natural everything was in fashion, which let’s face it, was very affordable-I am just so depressed that women now are spending time and money to prove that aging isn’t inevitable. Not if you’re a highly paid celebrity with the time and money for trainers and surgery.

Here’s an alternative: why not just aim to look and feel good for your age-without any expensive intervention? That’s my approach: easy and affordable!!

The truth is that when I look in the mirror I see just a bare hint of my 25 year old self. 

But I see something else that has replaced my youthful bloom, and that is wisdom and confidence.

These are my gifts now: and I wouldn’t trade them for anything

It is not that women are supposed to look that good at 50, it is that it is possible to look that good if one wants to put in the time and effort necessary to do so. But unless you are a professional dancer/entertainer it is not necessary.

As a 75-year-old woman, I don't get into comparing myself with the J Los.  Maybe I did when I was younger, but not much.

My feeling - and it is fleeting - is pity for her.  As Gloria Steinem said, 'we are all female impersonators,' and for some of us it's a full-time job that robs us of the time, energy and will to be human beings.  

Fifty is a beautiful age in itself.  So is 75.

Don't feel judged; she's a multimillionaire with the time and money to uphold her "brand".  Lots of other agents, directors,  and impresarios are also invested in the success of her brand. If we all had personal trainers, cooks, leisure time between gigs, and an army of hair, makeup and wardrobe specialists, we'd look pretty good too. (We could even learn to pole dance, if we wanted.)

I think it's a potentially harmful misconception that men don't experience the same sort of angst over body image that women do. I'm certainly not going to argue that they feel it to the same extent - or anything close to it given societal pressures that indisputably judge women more harshly on their physical appearance - but I know plenty of men who feel a similar sense of self-loathing that women do as they reach for another nacho, or as their waistline inevitably expands over the years. And plenty of men feel physically inadequate after walking out of a comic book movie seeing 50-year-old Paul Rudd's ripped abs and ageless face, to say nothing of Chris Hemsworth's or Henry Cavill's chiseled physique. However, for better or worse - and I truly don't know which it is - it's not socially acceptable for men to talk openly about those types of insecurities.

In the 80s entertainers used cocaine to look active on stage  (and probably still do). 

Considering what it takes to look fit now I'm not sure which is worse, illicit drug use or extreme surgery and dieting plus restrictive body armor.

I'm not old enough to have drunk coke when it used to be said, "hey bartender, give me a shot in the arm", but I do know that it was lot more fun before the US became so mesmerized by the illusions of youth and money.

The synthesis of cocaine by chemists had been accomplished in the 1920s. Another one of those golden ages.
She looks amazing, but she's also in effectively a full body Spanx, which doesn't hurt. Compression garments do a lot to shape and even out.

It is not our job at any age to look like an athlete or Jennifer Lopez. It is, however, our job to take care of our body, at least if you want to inhabit it for some serious amount of time. So no, you don't have to work all your working hours to look like your 25 self after 50. But, even more no, you don't have the right to completely let go at any age. Your body is a temple.

As for other people commenting on what constitutes power and empowerment, I think you first have to define power. I suppose there are people who wield power in a conventional sense (Harvey Weinstein comes to mind) who have zero inner power. In case of HW, if he had his own power, true power, he wouldn't be a criminal. But in my view power comes from within. Personally, I celebrate JLo's effort and work ethic, but I wasn't moved nor offended by her performance. Shakira, on the other hand, actually brought me to tears. I didn't see a sexualized performance; I saw a woman who was confident and with that confidence expressed her inner authenticity with seemingly no effort. That, to me, that's the only kind of power that matters. JW, I love you and I love Dorothy, and good for you.

Sure, Ms. Lopez looks great. At 50, she is quite lucky that she is able to practice and be paid a good wage to perform her job.
50 is a typical number that American firms use to eliminate staff. In countless cases, women and men in their 50s are suddenly thrust to the pavement. The fact that this practice is illegal means nothing. The fact that these 50 year old women and men have much to offer means nothing. Try finding a job at 50+. 
So, sure Ms. Lopez looks great. More power to her.  We look great, too. But, it does not matter. At 50 plus, with mountains of energy, experience and credentials, few firms will consider hiring and paying us.
Honestly, I still consider myself very lucky. I know many are much worse off than I. But, a job with health insurance would be a welcome change.
But, hey that Jennifer Lopez sure looks great.

Take it from an art director that’s pushing 50 herself, you CAN look that fabulous at 50 - especially on camera! J. Lo definitely has the genes but she also has talent and a lot of practice. And then there’s makeup, hair, wardrobe and the camera.
No, of course not, but we also don't need to judge her because she does.

I feel no compulsion to compete with other women's bodies or abilities. JLo has a job to do and apparently does it pretty well. My job is (I'm a decade older than her) to stay healthy & fit enough to live MY life.

Has the author missed the rise of the Fit Dad? Compared to 20- and 30- something dudes who are more out of shape than ever, I feel like it's very common for me to see Gen X men with dentist bikes, good haircuts, and trim bodies. They're the age of Sam Rockwell or Beto not Archie Bunker.

Opinion pieces like this remind me that the world would be such a better place if people would stop worrying about the things they can't control.

Physical/sexual attractiveness is something which we exert some control over in our choices and actions but is also largely a product of our genetics, essentially a flip of the coin, as well as our age and other factors we can not control.

If you care more about making yourself more physically attractive and enjoying more of the benefits derived from it, do what is within your power to do so.  Exercise, eat well, get enough sleep, develop a sense of style.  If you don't, then stop worrying about it and enjoy your life and invest your time in the other areas in which you derive your personal power and fulfillment.

Each person's body Is Theirs to do what they want with. If it is not a priority to you to be in fantastic shape, or you do not have time or will power to put in the work, then just be as healthy as you can given the constraints of your life. 

I recently saw the Peking acrobats, the Chinese Ultra fit Ultra flexible group who are selected at age three and work out hours everyday. J-Lo can dance because she has made it a priority and it is her job. The human body is amazing. Let us rejoice. But it is also the Temple of the Soul. So every person needs to take a little responsibility and at least stay healthy.

J Lo is an entertainer. One of the world’s most known and recognized. She’s an elite athlete in her own right and works out like one. And, she's able to spend a metric ton of cash on keeping everything intact and “upgraded”. Why make her the bar for where you should be when this is both her job and public persona?

"Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter." Hmmm. It's obviously true that there is an appearance double standard. But I'd suggest there's a big difference between what men feel and what they'll admit.

By 4th grade, nearly all boys have realized that hard cold fact that only a few kids will be gifted athletes (maybe not anymore now that schools are getting rid of dodgeball). Women, on the other hand, apparently believe that they can "have it all", even though this completely defies all logic (bell curves, anyone?). Very interesting.

Loved this piece! My favorite part, “ And so, my fellow Gen-X ladies, if you want to be J. Lo, more power to you. If you want to be Blanche, be Blanche. But if it’s always been about Bea Arthur, come sit back here, with me, in your Eileen Fisher tunic and the newish bifocals you haven’t quite mastered. We’ll wait ’til the crowd goes home, and we’ll dance like nobody’s watching.”

Oh, please.  She's a professional entertainer.  It's her full time job to look good.  She's no doubt endured multiple painful cosmetic surgeries, starvation diets, 4-hour hair and makeup sessions, grueling rehearsals, has many dance injuries that hurt more and more all the time, and will suffer from crippling arthritis eventually, too.  

Applaud her or not, what she looks like comes at a very high price.

Really? OK, so you feel better,  yes if you want guys to notice you, after all isn't that the reason you want to, look as good as JLo. I find it interesting that people are not secure enough in their own skin to have to compare themselves to celebs who are in process all the time. In my personal opinion she embarrassed herself and diminished the incredible talent she has by not evolving in a good way.

The photo in this article is somewhat reminiscent of Botticelli’s “Divine Comedy.”  It is not surprising that the value society places on being thin and “flaunting it” can impact those already at risk for eating disorders.  From Kindergarten up our young people are bombarded with media messages that in order to be happy, successful and “accepted,” they must be thin and fit.  It seems like nothing has changed in our world with its obsession on looks and appearance; and in this case, for many of us, an unrealistic look at age 50.

The problem, of course, is the patriarchy that pushes women to feel that their appearance is what matters about them.  I know it isn't going to happen, but I wish we could have half-time shows focused on women who've won science and math prizes.
I must confess that when I was 50...hubba hubba. It was a fine time!  JLo at 50 is not in a category by herself.

Seems to me Lizzo wore an equally scanty outfit at her recent Grammy performance.  But she won only praise because she was unabashedly proud of revealing her - let's be honest - less than svelte frame.  Interesting that folks seem to overlook the dazzling performance that JLo (and Shakira) put on and instead seem to resent her because she's committed the unpardonable sin of being beautiful while doing it.

I think that this type of article holds women back more than anything, especially when written by a woman.  We don't see articles exhaustively fretting over a man whose well maintained or lucky.  Ultimately, if we have body image issues, it's up to us to fix them as best as we can rather than decry someone else because that person makes us feel bad.  

Good for you Jay-Lo.  You've raised a bar.

Ha! So perfect. Thank you for saying out loud what most of us 50-year-olds are thinking. Even my 6 months pregnant GenY daughter was in awe of JLo’s body. I needed this laugh, today of all days (husband cracked up too)! Hit the nail on the head!

Good grief!  Only a few women have bodies like that at any age just as few men or women are going to be gifted professional athletes, or musicians or artists etc. 

We should try to do the best with what we were given, whether it’s looks, intellect, extraordinary ability.  No, more time at the gym will not achieve a body like that for most of us.

As a 76 year old woman, I find it very odd that those under 50 today - and I’m including high school and college girls, want to be seen as independent, powerful women, but also aspire to always looking “hot”.  Which is it?  How do women truly want men to see them?  

I think it’s a fair guess that most men will see the “hot” first.  Perhaps we could all just go back to looking nice/pretty/attractive and drop the attempt to look hit and trashy.  We might just get a bit more respect.
I am sure your body is beautiful, accept it and enjoy life!

The writer might note that while men may not shame their own bodies while watching sports (I don’t), most of us have our own deep insecurities.
That said, any article that winds up with Maude is Ok by me! Well done.

I guess my overwhelming reaction to this much debated show (just YouTubed it) is a kind of sadness. Is there not more than just spectacle and sexual spectacle at that. I think the kids in cages is completely lost in the frenetic jumping, thrusting and pole hugging.

Nevertheless, for a gladiator sport in a gladiator stadium within the context of the decline of our empire the show is perfect for its time and space. In terms of our Universe I'm sure its a singular occurrence and an apt reflection of us taking our place.

The author (presumably) works hard at her craft. JLo works hard on hers. The author’s craft shines and glitters on pages of paper and on computer screens. JLi’s craft appears on stage and on screen. 

Both can excel at their craft without comparing themselves to the other.

Glad you ended the piece as you did. I have always accepted my age and who I am. I never liked heels, and never thought they were appropriate with jeans. I never wore makeup, though a did dabble with dying my hear for a bit (not worth the bother).

That race never ended for me for the simple reason that it never actually began. Maybe it's because I never had a TV, and fell into a social circle that had other things on their minds (husband included).

Honestly, the last thing I care about is what J Lo wears.

Frankly I thought jlo was kind of rote and boring until the kids came out.  Shakira has a certain effortlessness and naturalness to her I enjoyed.  The sound quality on JLo’s songs was mushy and hinted at her vocal limitations. I’m 60 and don’t worry about competing with people with clear genetic and financial advantages. I’d rather have seen Lizzo up there with Shakira but oh well.  But Keep doing you ladies!

Some of us spent ourselves breaking into new careers, demanding to be included and to be taken seriously.  Countless still do and still face the same barriers we sought to erase.  There is no contesting the talent of JLo or Shakira as athletes, singers and dancers.  Yet as long as we portray women as sexual objects, we will never gain the essential human dignity we seek to claim.  What is our message to children?  A girl's booty defines her?  Women must be physically perfect to be appreciated?  Sorry, but no.  Just no.  Yes to equal opportunity, equal respect, equal pay.

Do you have any thoughts on last years half time show? The one where Adam Levine ripped off his shirt to reveal his ripped and fat-less body? There seems to be an assertion here that men don't also feel self-conscious about our bodies. Little boys are equally exposed to unrealistic body expectations in super-hero movies and other media. The difference is that a man's self-consciousness is "unmanly" and not to be spoken of. It's the same suffering, but with no socially-acceptable outlet for expression.

Are we really supposed to look this good at 50 now?

Yes, why not. There is no reason to be unhealthy.

Jennifer, sadly you know very little about men.  Despite the humorous aspect of this column, there is some serious psychological stuff going on here. If you think boys and men do not feel the heat of stereotypical physical perfection, think again. JLo represents our culture of objectification, where Super Bowl entertainment value is merited on looks for heterosexual women, no matter what age. But a culture of objectification is only the start of a process that proceeds with internalization of that perspective (self-objectification) which then leads to body shame and compensatory behaviors. Gay men and heterosexual women, as objects of the male gaze which drives this culture of objectification, both suffer disproportionately from body image dissatisfaction, body dysmorphia, and eating disorders. Changing the culture may be a tough battle but if we can find ways to avoid internalizing the view that our worth is predicated on “dat ass” and objectifying ourselves, we have the power to break free of the pain that ensues.

Some women engage in this harsh self-judgment out of a lack of genuine love for themselves.  It's not a disorder.  It tends to happen when women grow up with the message that looks equal power.  Or that looks equal value.  J-Lo's appearance/fitness is a trigger, not a cause of inner dissatisfaction.  My take is that human beings' talents are manifestations of one creative spirit.  Much of the work women (and some men, too) have done historically has  been minimized, ignored or taken for granted.  There is space for J-Lo's artistry, sexuality and athleticism, and the diverse talents of the rest of femalekind.  No matter what's marketed for public consumption, make it a routine to be grateful for your own life, your own purpose, and what you have created so far.  Be generous.  Be loving.  Be grateful.  Give these acknowledgements to yourself, as you would give them to others.  Be true to yourself, and allow other women that space, as well.

I love this article -- THANK you, Jennifer Weiner. I'm 58. I remember when, in my 20s, a magazine cover (Time?) first showed an impossibly fit woman in 80s dayglow aerobics gear proclaiming that being fit was the new beauty standard -- as if that was a triumph for feminism. I remember even then my heart sank: you mean now I not only have to diet, but have to worry about THIS? The end of Weiner's piece, admonishing us women to regard J-Lo with as much detached admiration as men regard the football players,  is a helpful shift in perspective, but a bit too glib. We have so much culture stacked against us.
I love tunics.

I think you do a disservice to the cause to assume men don’t feel insecure. Here’s the biggest mistake women make in thinking about men: performing idealized masculinity involves hiding insecurities from yourself and others, especially women.

And if anyone was paying attention, men's insecurities weren't left hanging, so to speak.  The very first screen shot after all that halftime pole dancing was a commercial for Roman, the men's online sexual health clinic.

Serendipity?  I think not.

JLo's athleticism is indeed impressive.    But was no one but me bothered by the extreme camera angles that the show was filmed at?    All bodies on the stage were elongated and slimmed down, to almost absurd proportions, I am sure by design.   JLo and Shakira, and everyone else on the stage, looked not like the firm and muscular people that they are, but like attenuated Barbie dolls!    Talk about a mixed message!    We should love and celebrate our bodies?    While faking their true proportions???

I am a 53 year-old man, so your idea of watching the game like a man made me laugh a lot, because it’s so very true. When I see a man of my age in better shape than me, I just think « good for him ». I also think that he probably spends more time than me at the gym or he is just blessed with great genes. As per me, I exercise 3-4 times a week, but it’s not to look good, it’s simply to remain healthy. When I turned 50, I noticed that my stamina had decreased and that I had gained about 6 pounds over the last two years. Big deal. It’s normal. It’s called getting old. 

So Jennifer Lopez looks great in a skimpy outfit... Good for her. But don’t worry about it, unless you have a desperate need to think of yourself as seductive in the eyes of every man out there. In the end, my question is: what do you want? To feel « hot » or to be loved by the people you care about? Believe me, they will love you no matter what. If they don’t, they don’t deserve you.
With the right amount of time, the right amount of money, and the right genes, you can also look like that!

Dear Jennifer, 
Yeah, but can JLo write a novel (by herself, not with a ghostwriter) even half as good as you can? 

I didn’t think so.

Best wishes from,
A fellow writer
Eventually she, like the rest of us, will die. We'll all look pretty much the same then.
If the author checks in with her Facebook friends every morning to gauge how her life is going to go that day, she's got bigger problems than comparing her body to J Lo's.

"The number of backup dancers is in inverse proportion to the quality of the music. The Beatles...zero backup dancers. Katy Perry: seven dancers. Some Australian band named Zoe that you've never heard of... 26 dancers. And Kim Jong Un: 24 million dancers!"       --Bill Maher

Kind of an absurd article. JLo cant act like Meryl Streep. She can't sing like Aretha Franklin. She earns her living by looking good. So maybe, if you had the time (like she does), and the money (like she does), you could look as good. If you had the lucky genes to have something to start with. But cry me a river about 'women' being 'judged' by their looks. Think that isn't the same for men ?
Amen, alleluia Jennifer.  You pegged we men perfectly.  Now, where ARE those nachos?

This article really proves that spirituality is dead. It is nothing but the outpouring of the author's endured social engineering. Jennifer Lopez was put there so she feels that way. But not a word about taking a step back and realizing how she and her feelings are played with, just good old wallowing in that self-loathing mire with the typical semi-positive twist at the end to not crumble under the weight of society's gaze. These are very sad Times.

My wife and I are in our seventies. We've known each other for almost sixty years the advantage being that we still see the early-twenties person we met in 1965. Of COURSE neither of us look as we did then, but we're not doin' bad. Another truth is that those such as J-Lo and George Clooney do what they do--and that involves looking their pluperfect best--for a living! for heaven's sake. All that said, to my mind, the only reason to not keep looking your best as you navigate the years--becoming 'better seasoned'--is insufficient self esteem. A certain amount of ego is necessary, always, in several aspects of life and while it seems just fine to recognize that as regards the workplace--god forbid you're pushed around!--it seems somehow outre to engage your ego with regard to how you look and even interact. In sum, being the best person you're capable of, both for yourself and others. For me, its keeping trim without being obsessive about it, as well as learning French and Italian. Fries? Great, but not the whole serving. An attractive external and internal self are both legitimate objectives, and we should embrace them, never forgetting the words of that great San Francisco sage Harry Callahan--"...a man's gotta know his limitations". Works well for women also.

It's a shame that so many women are so self obsessed with how they look. Sure, I wish I looked like J. Lo, and at 50 I still looked good. But I'm 61 now and just accept that I'm not so physically attractive anymore, at least in a sexual way. The aging process is not fun, but just deal with it and try to be good to your body and mind. It isn't fun to lose your good looks and become old, but why waste your money (if you have that kind of money) getting plastic surgery so that you can maybe look a few years younger? What's the point?
The super bowl half-time show was ridiculous, tasteless, tacky, and trashy.   And I couldn't take my eyes off it.

If you feel personally judged by J. Lo's body, then you must be an extremely insecure and uninformed person. 
If anyone did 1/2 the amount of exercise that Jennifer Lopez does daily with professional training, they'd look "amazing".
She is paid to look great. Now her image can help business target over 50 yr. old women to sell product. 
Take a walk, read a book. Don't watch the misogynistic Super Bowl to determine your personal standards.
Yes, yes, yes, so much yes! Thank you!

"Are we really supposed to look this good at 50 now?"

No, but if you want to keep your husband, you will have to learn how to pole dance.
If you care about yourself, you will take care of yourself, to look your natural best at any age - rather than defacing yourself with food, drink, drugs, ink and body hardware.

I read Jane Eyre at age 14, and it shaped my world view. I believe women's power - and eroticism - resides in their intellect. (I think the same of men.) But a half time show of two women reading a book would have been dull, so let J. Lo glitter and shine and shake her booty! She's lovely to watch, and nothing wrong with that.

This should be in a diary, not in the NYT.    BTW, I own a closet full of Eileen Fisher clothing, which is not a sign that I've given up.  I suggest you stop by one of their stores for some tunic styling tips.
OMG! Iâ€™m sixty, and I applauded like crazy! WOOT  to J LO!!!! (And, I would have been happy to wear that outfit, as well!)

As a male I find J Lo's body to be pretty hot... especially because of her age.

Having said that, you know what? She is more a freak of nature than your typical 50-year old woman. Women, you don't need to have her body to be hot. You can be hot within your own body. Some displayed self-confidence can go a long way!

I love my 64-year old wife's body. Is she hot by society's standards? Far from it. But.. she's hot to me!! And, she's not flaunting herself up on a stripper pole.

Face it ladies, J Lo is in love with herself and perhaps in ways that are not quite healthy. I don't know this with certainty of course; just a pure guess given her mode of dress all over the place.

Loâ€™s achievements, not make excuses for why we failed and can continue to fail.

Women like to blame men for a lot of their problems, but honestly, feminism would take a giant leap forward if women just learned how to be nicer to each other. How do you think J-Lo feels having this ladyâ€™s insecurities dumped on her in the New York Times? 

The author  condemns the half-time show as being designed for the evil â€œmale gazeâ€�, but just a few lines later says that women should learn to watch such things as men do. So which is it? Is the way men operates a horrendous crime in society, or should women aspire to behave more like men? Canâ€™t be both unless it is your goal to behave as horrible as you perceive men to be. 

As I tell my daughters on a near daily basis, you worry about you. Itâ€™s not your concern what the person next you looks like, or behaves like. You make sure youâ€™re doing whatâ€™s right for you.

Hi--reading the reviews of the half time show, I understand one reason people admire the show is because it showcases African or Ethnic music. I happened to stumble on you-tube videos of people playing the Kora, a precursor to the banjo. This is an African instrument, and the music is so beautiful, I think it will calm any angst you feel thinking about the half time show https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8luhdxS2KuM https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MQ_wq-2UcbQ

You never have to so called â€œlook this good.â€� You are not required to fall for the hype - live your own best life.
Great article.  Agree 100%

Planet Earth is being obliterated and youâ€™re obsessed with Jo Loâ€™s 50-yr-old booty? Boy is that vacuous! 

And in terms of inspiring female artists, Iâ€™ll take Billie Eilish over Jennifer Lopez any day.
I didn't "clutch my pearls" until the young women were on stage. I prefer to leave bondage rope and pole dancing to the adults.
THIS ARTICLE MAKES ME WANT TO CANCEL MY SUBSRIPTION.  I am a 57 year old menopausal woman.  As I believe Jane Fonda once said, "Good genes are a lot of money."  As Be a Authur would say, GROW UP!

Guess what, Jennifer? Not every woman wants the same things as you. Not everybody has the same beliefs as you. Some women actually want to be sex symbols. Some women pity you because you're too afraid to embrace your sexuality. Nobody is forcing J-Lo or Shakira to do what they do. Other divas like Mariah Carey put on weight and embrace it and continue to perform.

If this show had taken place 10 years ago the performers would have been much thinner.  There were a bunch of hot guys to watch, for those who enjoy them.  The stars were middle aged.  Sounds like progress to me.

Sex has been part of Shakira and J's program since forever and you can't put that on men without taking the performer's agency and free will which isn't being a good feminist.
Only you should judge yourself, so if you feel like J.Lo's body is judging you, remember, it's really YOU judging yourself and only YOU can change that.

At 62 I applaud these woman. I don't partake in the unhealthy American lifestyle, eat smart, never diet and exercise regularly. In most other countries this is the norm, however not in the land of plenty. It's  a choice and sorry people feel bad about this, but my philosophy is to love yourself however you do that and don't put down regimented healthy people for their lifestyle. I am tired of people who put this down. Stop pointing the finger and worry about yourself!

I really do not care what she looks like. The gyrations don't matter to me. I do not care that much for her "talents", and I talk not of her acting or singing. She is a not a real woman, just a fake creation. She belongs to A-Rod. Joksters. Natural women of this world, don't fret, forget about her, do not compare, "real" beats plastic every time.

Stop this nonsense. Stop comparing yourself to others. JLo has the means to work hard on her body and so does everyone else. Also, take in to consideration that she's either padded or has very tight clothing that does not allow her normal rolls and folds to show. 

If you stuff yourself in her sausage casing,

Donald Trump is personally fighting the idea that sexy over 50 is "tight and toned".

Speaking as a man, I have never found the extruded plastic Barbie Doll look attractive or erotic.
❤️ this. I will be right next to you in my Ecco shoes.

Why is this about how she looks? What about how she danced and sang? What about how she brought life and excitement?

I’m so tired and frustrated with everything having to be acceptable. Aren’t you? 

Plus, America is a land of different cultures. Some don’t have the same Puritanical views of repression. Stop representing J Lo, Puerto and Rican and Latino culture. 

While you’re at it, stop repressing yourselves.

Doesn't occur to me to feel bad or judged. If women want a J-Lo body, they have to put in the work she puts in.  Watched Beyonce's journey to performing at Coachella.  She was 30 pounds beyond where she needed to be after giving birth to twins, exhausted, mind on being with her new babies, yet  she worked off the weight, got the flexibility back, and performed with the energy of a teenager.  That's her job and the career she chose.  Do  women go to a ballet and feel judged by the skill and bodies of ballerinas, or women athletes? Do they envy Jane Goodall? She's svelte, lives an amazing life.  Admiration does't necessitate comparisons. Get a life, I say! Your own.
I thought this was the New York Times, but it reads like Cosmopolitan.

What a world of triteness we live in when there are those who are drooling over violent game saturated with over-hyped advertisements, overpaid athletes (and their management), stupid commentators, greedy bettors, and overhyped (and often stupid) half-time shows.  And now, just when you thought it couldn't get more trite, there are those agonizing because they don't look as good as professional entertainers who are 50-ish prancing around in outfits that most 20 year olds couldn't pull off effectively.  I guess there is nothing else to contemplate or escape to mid-winter.
What do the #Metoo people have to say about this?  Does this pure display of sexual attraction have any affect o mens' desires or approach to them?
It’s time to think through how and why J Lo’s looks have come to be  considered “good.”

This is a silly article. J Lo's business is her appearance.  She has the resources, the time and the staff to ensure she looks "good"  But J Lo also does not let let ethics stand in the way of looking "good"  She equates wearing the skin of dead animals with looking "good"

What a dumb headline! My first reaction was, "If you feel personally judged by J. Lo's body, that's your problem. Why should you, unless a main component of your career depended on your appearance?". ..and to bypass your article.   Absolutely, the points you raise are valid and very important ones. But one would never know that from the headline, which seems straight out of a NY Post style book.

Has everyone lost their sense of humor or is it just stuffy NYT readers? I'm not familiar with the writer, but based on the tone of this article I'm pretty sure she doesn't really feel shamed by J. Lo's ageless beauty. 

Please save the scolding. Yes, we all know that superstars have good genes and have lots of time and money to devote to sculpting their bodies, and beauty is only skin deep. We get it!
Body suits would make trump look svelte too

I really have trouble with the fact that the Times sees it fit to have both Style and Opinion coverage on this. Nothing against the quality of the reporting or commentary. But should we be buying into JLo's self absorption quite so deeply?

Women, let's celebrate one another and our greatness.  Some may have strengths that are physical in nature, can sing like a bird, negotiate artfully, write poetically, cook with epic talent, be creative or problem solve at extraordinary levels.  We all have superpowers and I hope that we focus on building one another up rather than worrying so much about shortcomings.  

Life is difficult and we will be more successful if we stand together.
I truly appreciate this article.  We should be supportive of one another as women, and look at it as entertainmnet, not comparing ourselves.  There is more to life.

I've had three decades - since In Living color - of being leagues away from Jennifer Lopez. She has maximized her gifts. I love the idea of watching like a man watches football, because there is no way I'm going to find the resources + discipline + core strength to work my body into the kind of perfection that can balance perfectly horizontally on a pole, but I'm perfectly happy seeing people push the boundaries of what feels possible, and happier still to let a little of extra possibility into my life.

When my friends (usually men) and I watch athletes decades younger than us, we sometimes marvel and think, "can you imagine being that good at 22?" And while we absolutely don't let that stop us from inhaling the next nacho, that doesn't mean we don't compare ourselves to these superstars. It's just that the comparisons we make are in the service of appreciation: both for their rare genetics and dedication to excellence. Many fans are such because they themselves know how difficult it is to perform the feats they see on TV.

Here's my conclusion after watching countless super bowl spectacles (I missed this one since I had a rare afternoon alone and indulged myself in catching up on series I'd missed).  The man in my house doesn't feel a twinge of self doubt because in his mind, he is one of those athletes on the field and could suit up tomorrow if the Team needed him.  He's always dogging the players (30-40 years his junior) for not "manning up," or missing tackles, or not fighting for the extra yards because he thinks they are slacking and he  totally believes he would be able to make all those plays.  In other words, he's delusional.

I find amazing what these two women do and did. It is an example of professional achievement, hard work and the desire to succeed. 

I am a 50 years old Latina woman. I fell better now than when I was in my 20s. I had to change my diet, redefined who I was and explore who I wanted to be. 

I normally don’t follow music because I am not interested but I watched a documentary about how hard it was for JLo to overcome the issues she had to and in regards to finding her own identity. Without being a dancer or singer, I had to go through the same issues of defining who I was, of listening to myself before listening to others. And I can anyone that it is worth it! I think we need to be real and forget about pre-conceived concepts that are not relevant anymore. These women work and amazing professionals. They deliver!
Looking good when you’re older is merely a sign of wealth. It takes money to look that good.
Do good looks equal happiness? Body and mind in balance seems a better goal and still works at age 80, I'd think.

"Men see entertainment, athletes who exist on a different plane than mere mortals. Their inner voice whispers, Are there any more nachos? I don’t even think it would occur to them to feel bad, or try to emulate what they saw."

Not entirely true.  I'm a male who just turned 50 and I've managed to maintain pretty much the same body I've had since my mid 20s via a lot of hard work and ongoing dedication.  I've decided very early on (back in my 20s) that I will not look like the typical male in his 50s with the so-called "dad" body, and kept that focus ever since.  I've maintained the exact same workout routine in terms of hours and days spent training (notwithstanding changes to certain exercises to shock the muscle of course) and a very strict diet all of these yrs.  Genetics is also a likely factor.  I also don't have kids so that's a huge advantage in terms of free time.
 The point being, men can be equally concerned about how they look and feel as they age, and compare themselves to guys in their 20s.   I don't see athletes existing on a different plane but as dedicated individuals who work and train hard - and I keep that in the back of my mind whenever I'm at the gym.

In most Victorian novels (and even a bit later, including many WWII stories), women in their 40s were already considered crones. So take heart.

On the other hand (not having watched the Super Bowl over here, nor would I want to), I'm so glad not to be part of the current middle-age 'mom stuff' of being tied to one's Facebook feed. Facebook is a menace all around, and I'm grateful my son's teen years ended before social media created an epidemic of neuroses.

Taking care of her body is her job and she does that well.  Other people have other strengths. I do agree that over accenting sexuality does not help the average person. Sexual in private is fine. The teacher, lawyer, surgeon, nurse, realtor, engineer work on their skills. Jennifer Lopez is a celebrity and can act, sing, dance and is a business woman. We should also celebrate cancer researchers, politicians who give their all like Elizabeth Warren. Being the best human we can be no matter the occupation.

I am petite. Women often comment on how small I am and, in the same breath, mention how much weight they'd like to lose, tell me what their waist measurement once was, or otherwise make me aware that my size, which has been my reality since I was a preteen, is being read by them as a comment on THEIR sizes. I, for one, feel "personally judged" by the unwelcome comments on my body (as well as the suspicion I get from women about my smallness—I have been told by strangers that I must be starving myself, exercising hard, or must not like food as much as someone else does, none of which are true). We've made strides in terms of catcalling and other means by which (mostly) men comment on women's bodies in public and now it seems that there is work to be done on the ways women talk about other women. Can a woman's body ever just be hers? Mine is not a statement on all of womanhood. An entertainer like J. Lo is held by tabloids and by her audience's expectations to a separate standard. 
So-called Shakers and Clutchers alike need to evaluate the fact that their own expectations do not allow room for difference; rather than an EITHER Blanche OR J. Lo duality, why not accept that these are two vastly different types with different expectations, and that we are not required to be either?

(Also, editor, the word the author wants is "dyeing," not "dying" in reference to her hair.)
It is the profession of some to appear preternaturally beautiful and be on display for everyone's judgement.  Glad I can have grey hair and eat hamburgers.
I see a lot of 50-something's in Peloton group looking pretty close to JLo.

Let's not talk about how we are more than our bodies, because sadly, the entertainment industry, Hollywood, the music industry, etc. dashes all the advances that females have made in the last over 50 years by having the birth control pill, the ability to further their own career, even believing the truth that they don't have to get married, or even have children.  Beyonce, J. Lo, and Taylor Swift, have sadly become more about the flesh, than about anything relevant to add to society in general, and the female in particular.  No, I am not a prude, or religious, at all, etc.  I was working in finance in New York City at the age of 20, and I wouldn't of learned anything if all I had was my body back then.  Everyone looks better at a younger age.   I did, but as you age, and I am now 71,  your body changes, especially through having children for most women, and menopause as well.  If you wonder why most men only look at, and talk about females as only bodies, it is because too many clueless females continue to put that out there.  It is people like Adele, and others that don't have to look like a stripper to prove to the world that they have talent, can sing, etc.  The others, not so much.
The world would be visually improved. JLo just shows what is possible. Still needs individual motivation though

Other than a bad dye job I high school I have never dyed my hair even though my hair started going grey in my 30s. Now at 70 my hair is almost totally silver. Although I can appreciate how lovely some women’s dyed or highlighted hair looks, I am Ok with my gray tresses. It’s who I am and I also don’t want to spend the time of money to change it. 

I thought that JLo and Shakira looked great, but also knew that even at 30 I never looked like them nor could I dance or sing like them. So what. They are entertainers and the audience of 100 million, a majority men, probably enjoyed watching them but realized that they were like fantasy women, not what their wives,sisters or girlfriends are supposed to look like. Nor would anyone think that the average man would have the agility of the winning quarterback. 

I don’t know why the writer felt so threatened by them. I think Dorothy in the Golden Girls is a good role model,one worth emulating. Is it necessary to go through hoops in the article,acting like that is being subversive for admitting that? You can admire JLo or not. There is no reason to assume that she’s being held up as a role model.

I didn't reflect on my own body when I watched these two talented performers. I was amazed to learn how old they are and marvel at how they kept in shape. What I didn't like was the sexualized nature of the performances, mostly in the case of Jennifer Lopez. The show was clearly for men. Also, I wondered what her 11-year old talented daughter thought and what message it sent to her, as she watched her mother on a stripper's pole etc.

Honestly, if people just ate better and got some exercise looking like this shouldn't be that hard. It just depends on if you like looking like that or like potato chips better. I think more choose potato chips. And there's nothing wrong with that.

I cant believe people are in thrall to this.

Jennifer Lopez has skin, hair and makeup experts at her disposal.  No doubt she has personal trainers and nutrition experts, too.  Who knows what plastic surgery she's had.  And she has the time to indulge these things.

Add in perfect lighting, costumers and special effects and anyone with all that can also look fabulous at 50.  And completely artificial.    Show me how she looks in the morning without makeup and then we'll talk.

yes, we should all  be taking care of ourselves by eating less overall calories (stop eating so much stuff that you know is not natural food)  and sweating for 30 minutes a day (or just walk more or stand at your desk will do it)

JLo looks like a 50-year-old who has spent a lot of time and money on being in shape and trying to look much younger than she is.  She does not look like an actual young woman, however, and there is a big difference.
They look great for their age and clearly worked hard to get there. Why should they be criticized for that?

For me, self-acceptance came when I turned 60.  I looked in the mirror and realized I looked like my mother.  It's also the time I bought my first Eileen Fisher tunic.

30 years ago, my widowed mother and I were having dinner with my co-worker who was in his 60's.  The next day, He said to me, "You know, your mother is a very good looking woman."  What?

I told my mother this and her response..."Hey, I've still got it baby!"

well, if your livelihood rests dependent upon the beauty of your physical appearance, yeah, your gonna prioritize the time and effort to maintain it. But there is much to said for the development and life of a beautiful mind.

If we had the money that J-Lo has, good genes, could work-out everyday, etc., etc.  We could look like that to a degree.  What comes with it, is the maintenance, pressure of being in the limelight all the time, etc., etc.  

I like J-Lo, I think she looks wonderful!  However, I don't like her singing and I don't think she is the best dancer.  I however, like to see her in movies! I think she is good in movies or a series.

I do like Shakira...she is a natural.

I think JLo's body is what you are supposed to look like at 50 when you have the time and financial resources to hire multiple trainers, cooks, nannies and other staff that allow maintaining this body type not quite as much work as it appears from the outside.

How about just saying, "You looked great JLo and Shakira, good for you"? And you don't have to like their choice of outfits or dance numbers (I didn't), but perhaps they did. Why does everything have to reflect on society as a whole?

I turned 50 this year and what I like the most about the J Lo performance was how it was SO J LO.  It seemed like she was shouting from the Super Bowl - I am one sexy, strong, loud WOMAN.  And her kid came on stage so I believe she emphasized her motherhood as well.  Loved the performance.

It’s really great to know with all that’s going on, a NYT columnist who lives in the Upper West Side feels attacked by the body of an entertainer.

Excellent journalism, superb quality. At times like this I feel like cutting my losses and just unsubscribing from NYT.
If you can afford it and can endure the pain to keep the look.
I am 51 and look fantastic.
About the male gaze: my wife is 58 and I think her legs are better than those two stars. Views are, of course, subjective. Thank goodness for that.

Glad I live in France, where although being a woman of a certain age, and even with the passage of time, I’ve never been made to feel invisible or without any sex appeal, by men or women. My women friends and I may comment on the perfectly “engineered” beauty of Shakira or Jennifer Lopez but we never waste time comparing ourselves to them and neither do our partners. They are fantasy, we are real.

The problem with America is that we are a majority overweight country (about 1/3 obese, 1/3 overweight & 1/3 healthy).   As a result, the average body type is overweight. It's fine to strive to meet that beauty standard, and many women achieve it somewhat, but it's frustrating that we're not enough without the veneers, all the covering up and fake parts. Even knowing that what you're seeing is a costume, it's impossible to escape the anxiety of not looking like that. The most common compliment an "attractive" women of a certain age receives is something along the lines of "you look way younger" or "you look great for your age" -- why does it always have be in terms of how well we defy reality? I don't understand why female entertainers are still selling sex in skimpy costumes and using poles as props, but the Super Bowl is definitely a male-driven marketing tool so that's probably one significant reason.  On the other hand, you praise Lizzo in an earlier piece but skewer J-Lo -- they *both* sport skimpy costumes showing lots of skin and cleavage and leg, are highly coiffed and made-up.  Why do women feel dehumanized when JLo is on stage but feel empowered watching Lizzo?  If watching JLo perform makes you feel bad, then don't watch her -- watch Lizzo videos instead.  If we surround ourselves with the things that make us feel good and sexy and empowered, we can make peace with how our bodies look.  Yes, we are bombarded with messages of thinness and beauty, but we are all personally responsible for how we respond to it.  True empowerment comes when we take control of our body image and stop allowing celebrities and popular culture to dictate how we feel.
Come now... "personally Judged"?
As her to see an instagram of her just getting out of bed in the morning, and you will feel better (maybe).

Relax, Jennifer, my bet is that her skin tight outfit was made of an enormous amount of very firm spandex.  She essentially was wearing a modern version of a girdle that covered 90% of her body.

You didn't see 90% of J Lo.  You saw the girdle that created the shape of what you saw.

What nonsense. JLo may look great, but at every day’s end she perhaps peeks around her mirror&  sees ARod across the table. Maybe he’s glancing back at her, temporarily sated by his own beheld glorious countenance in his own mirror (set of mirrors?).  Such, I’d imagine, is their day.  Count your blessings ladies!

If J-Lo wants to spend her hard work  and money to look young, that's her choice, not yours.  Yes, I found it all to be mostly burlesque, but that seems to be todays  low bar for show business. How about projecting a little more tolerance and less judgement.
Maybe it’s just me, but I think she looks ridiculous.

Anyone else catch j lo’s micro expression when she finished and took applause? Exasperation, almost rolled eyes —“glad THATS over.”

Now she will (as she should) go home to sip coffee and make toast for her kids. 

Speaking of which..
Did we ask this about Madonna's look in 2009 Sticky tour?

Oh please, just be yourself and look how you want to look. No one, I repeat, no one, is telling you to be J Lo, Shakira or Bea Arthur. Either sit back and enjoy the show or turn the channel until the game resumes.
Maybe quit throwing shade and start lifting weights.
Ms. Weiner, if you made your living as an entertainer, you would find a way to present yourself like Ms. Lopez. Interested?

I look like Mr. Peepers but I wish I looked like Daniel Craig.

Your point?

No, it doesn't matter what you look like when you are fifty. Comparing yourself to J.Lo is the mistake here. She likely does nothing except work on her body and figure out to be more famous and talked about. That isn't terribly interesting. And neither is the parade of the skimpy clad female bodies.

Dont fret it! Dancers have always looked good at 50 + most women dont have millions to spend on plastic surgery and the best makeup artists and seamstresses in the world... She's hot, yes, but I'll bet you that she's pretty normal looking in the sunlight on a Sunday morning. Wrinkles, cracks, flab, spots and all : )

The halftime show was a bit like porn.  Perhaps a little in the performer's movements, haha.  But mostly in that it is a work for entertainment purposes.  It is not meant to be realistic.  Enjoy it or don't enjoy it depending on your individual taste.  Then move on, either way.  Why is it so difficult for some people, including the author of this piece, to distinguish between fantasy and reality?  It's her decision to be entertained or not by that particular show, but conflating it into some kind of competition among all women is crazy, as is using it to define beauty standards.  In similar vein, people can be entertained by the game itself if they like football, but without projecting anything about the performers into their everyday lives.
Elvis Presley comes to mind...

What strikes me most about these two ladies performances is the fact that we're just coming out of the "Me, too" movement, where a vast number of women demand to be viewed as more than just sex objects, and yet, the entertainment world (from whence the "Me, too" movement was born) continues to insist on using provocative sexuality to promote their entertainment.   Too many celebrities, and non-celebrity women, want one thing, but seem to be clinging to the opposite.  "Don't exploit me sexually, but let me be as sexy as I can be."  Good grief...how about dangling a piece of steak in the face of a lion and demand that he not try to eat it.  Not much difference there.

I actually loved their performance and thought it was incredibly strong and powerful. Two Latina performers taking center stage (and making history, mind you) and singing together as a team is so beautiful. You also saw their support for each other. Neither one was trying to one-up the other. They worked together as women and human beings. I grew up watching both of them when they were first starting out, and watching them now, I saw very dedicated, strong women who have made it far in their careers. And I couldn't believe how great they sounded and presented themselves all these years later. 

Maybe instead of focusing our attention all the time on women's bodies and what they look like, we should be focusing on their achievements and how strong they are (and genuinely be happy for them). That's the only way we will stop this comparison trap.

I also remember when Shakira and Beyonce came out with their "Beautiful Liar" video (as well as Gwen Stafani and Eve with "Blow Your Mind") and thinking this was so cool that two female performers are singing together and aren't competing against each other. 

So, instead, let's be happy for JLo and Shakira for all of their hard work and success and for being two strong women supporting each other's successes.

This is dumb. It's her job to look like that. She works hard it at - just as many of us work hard at our jobs. If I worked 10 hours a day on my body instead of my actual job, I would probably look different - I'm not saying better - just different, more like her (but honestly - there are genes and things too).
And yes, by 50, most of us should be pretty good at our jobs. 
Do you think she is doing your  job in addition to her own? No....but if you want to look like that, feel free to take on a second career!

Women judging women and blaming the patriarchy.

Even more absurd:  The Stripper Pole as a symbol of Female Empowerment.

I'm a fan of yours Jennifer, but stop picking at your navel.  JLo has the time and money to devote herself to looking youthful.

Working out with a trainer, Pilates, yoga, massage therapy, and yes, fillers and plastic surgery. And yes, JLo looks great because of the time and the money she has, but also because this is what is important to her.

She is not the stay-at-home, car-pooling, home-coking, housecleaning parent.  Her Super Bowl make-up reportedly took nine hours too.

I don't have to watch JLo like a man. In fact, I don't have to watch JLo at all. And I didnt'!

First there were “empowering “ commercials for females. Then there was the bump & grind halftime debacle of females.  Let’s don’t cheapen ourselves by these displays. The cost is far more than in dollars.

Please Jennifer - Enjoy who you are, love your body as it is, go to the gym to keep in good health, and let Ms. Lopez dance her heart entertain us like she does.

I still rides horses, work out at the gym, but as an older guy I can't get crazy every time I see Brad Pitt with his shirt off complaining that I don't have the body he has.

Well, Jennifer, I am feeling judged by YOU.  I'm in my mid-60s, have been wearing Eileen Fisher for 30 years, and am annoyed by the tendency of GenX women to dismiss the brand as frumpy cover-ups.  (Are my college students more comfortable in yoga pants and crop tops?  The epidemic of depression and anxiety in their cohort would suggest it's at least not helping.)  And your use of the term "pearl clutchers" to describe women who found the Super Bowl show pornographic clearly shows that you judge that opinion to be Victorian hyper-ventilation. The idea that flaunting one's sexuality constitutes empowerment is a CON: it is just a retooling of the old power-behind-the-throne con, that we can flutter our eyelashes and get men to do what we want.  Let me beat you to it: OK, boomer.
I feel sorry for you if you can't accept what has been given to you.  Don't judge your body by what others do. Judge it by what you have do to and for it. Learn to love yourself.

If more men felt judged by the athleticism of sports figures, leading them to put down the nachos, get up off their rears, and get in shape, there would be fewer real widows (as opposed to sports widows), and our health care costs might drop a bit.

I live in Denver most everyone is fit and active. Many many women my age in their mid 50’s look great. Go to a pure barre class and see how hard women are working to keep their body in shape and stay fit. 
I worked 30 years as an RN raising my two kids while my husband was deployed with the navy or when in private sector traveled internationally he was gone 50-70 percent the whole time ..needless y to o say I didn’t have much time to work on my body ..
Now I’m retired ... I have time and focus on staying healthy..I’m in great shape and proud of my looks ..I work at it just like J Lo ..and many of the women in my classes have bodies like
J Lo. I think it’s ridiculous to body shame another women for how they look.
If you or other women reading this don’t feel good about your body ..do something about it!!
Bike, walk, hike, swim take classes..
It’s not hard to have a rear like JLo but you have to work at it..and if your not going to don’t trash another women who does chose to work at it....it’s just petty and tacky

Get used to it and get over it, ladies. You've brought it on yourselves over the years and decades.

Who buys "Cosmo?" "Vogue?" (when it was still being published). Vanity Fair? Who buys the clothing made by Givenchy, the jewelry made by Bulgari, the handbags made by YSL (along with his other stuff)? (Or, who seeks others out to buy it for them?) Who poses for those ads? Who's really behind the (laughable) promos for ED drugs? For "barely visible" absorbent underwear?

You do.  And we all know why. This is the place where the adage, "Be careful what you wish for . . ." really belongs.

Articles like this are gross. Yes, the writer is entitled to feel less than, but this is an odd juxtaposition of a white person coveting a brown body. Icky. No J. Lo doesn’t look like most 50 y/o white people. She is not white. There are many women of color who look like this, even without surgery. I hate hate hate to see this.

I watched a couple of minutes, then muted the sound and read the newspaper till the 2nd half started. Only in a nation where 40% of adults are obese, would these women be viewed as having such phenomenal bodies. Sorta' like the 325# linemen are svelte?

J.Los is an actress, singer and entertainer. Her fans pay good money  to look at her. So of course she is more pressured to stay young and hot looking.  This can be achieved if you have drive and unlimited funds. God genes help, too, but you would be amazed at how much "preservation" a high net worth  can buy. Expert wardrobe and makeup artists at J.Los disposal also shave many years off for the camera. Take away constant access to luxury maintenance and she would probably look surprisingly close to her actual age. Don't let the smoke and mirrors make you feel insecure, ladies. And don't let aging make you feel that way, either.  It is a relief when you get to the age when your value is no longer tied up with hoping men salivate over you. There are so many other ways to be beautiful, physically and otherwise.

Wow! I'm surprised I'm reading this type of drivel in the 21st century. This piece was drowning in gender stereotypes and closet sexism. 

If you don't want to dye your hair or pluck your eyebrows - don't! Whining about unrealistic expectations placed on women while simultaneously allowing such expectations to determine your self-worth is a losing battle.

I couldn't get over the performance really. I felt that it was so demeaning and wondered where the heck the me too movement went.  Women were up in arms about a swim suit competition for Miss America and then you watch this with your young kids? I just think it just sends such a confusing message to women and men.  It was flat out vulgar.

I really enjoyed the show. After all, it was singing and dancing and people having fun. We had a super bowl party and all the women watched and danced along with them, excluding the stripper pole. We had fun! And we are all 50 and older. 

The fact that you make it out to be some sort of competition is silly. We need to support women who love to stay fit and work on looks as much as we need to support women who don’t. It shouldn’t make you feel bad about yourself if you think someone looks better than you. Just appreciate them for who they are. Then appreciate yourself for who you are. 

We need more kindness to others. There was no harm done here. It was all harmless fun. It was theater, awesome entertainment. Quit trying to look past it and make it a statement of something that really doesn’t exist.

I have long ago become sickened by crotch grabbing hip gyrating breast revealing machinations in today’s popular culture. Miley Cyrus spread eagle in yesterday’s paper. Bad enough when it was just breasts, now we get the gynecologist view as entertainment.

I pine for the talents of Janice Joplin, Carole King, Bob Dylan, etc etc etc.

Maybe  it's  time to cancel  the Suprr Bowl half time show.  It's  gone from a fine family fun event to an X rated disaster.  Jlo sliding down that stripper pole was just another  example of incredibly bad taste.
(Whispered): Who hid the nachos bowl?

Aging with dignity, a valued credit to the community in which you live...are ya in or are ya out?! 

Appearances be damned. Human beings only need to look just good enough when the time comes (and inevitably moves beyond us all) to pass genes successfully into the future generational mixing pot. After that one relatively short time in an otherwise long and presumably productive life, that which actually fuels individual worth and defines dignified membership in the human clan still will be needed for the refinement of our unique and precious life form. just struggling to get by. Understand this and keep perspective on real life for all the time you are lucky enough to have been granted...without prejudice or adverse judgement, of course. Let life happen as it will, like it more avidly than not.

J Lo & Shakira work as hard as any pro ball player to look like that & it costs a lot of time & money. And if you watch any interviews with them, they are so so smart. All power to them, but I have my own life to tend to. Their world is not my world. 

As a big fan of Latin music & dance, I was happy to see them get a national audience. The clothes were skimpy; & ask yourself, why did Fox cameras always seem to be aimed at  crotch level? Hmmmm.

Don't give up. 
My wife was hired as a professional dancer at age 71!

If I may, from a male perspective-
I am nearly 50 years old, as is my wife- who is a beautiful woman, but does not look like J-lo.  
Neither do I, for that matter.
That is because NO ONE does.
I still love and desire my wife.

I do not intend to take away from what J-lo has accomplished- the performance was world class. But one has to remember that that is WHAT she does. She has inexhaustible resources, trainers, dieticians- you name it- at her beck and call to accomplish one goal- looking like THAT, whilst doing- THAT.
Jenny from the block, my ass. More like Jenny from the block with an army behind her.

Women- chances are you are professionals, and mothers, and damned good at both.
Neither you- nor the (assumed) men in your life- should expect more than the miracles you already pull off.

Enough already. If J-lo had to do what you do without 50 personal assistants, she’d be at Walmart in sweats with the rest of us.

My dear Jennifer Weiner, you are not alone - in fact, this self-assessing affliction lives within all of us, like it or not. Indeed, female intrasexual competition is a tough taskmaster, definitely an evolutionary adaptation to sort out the best "breeding stock of the tribe." Assessing, denigrating, coveting, and scheming to be chosen by at least another person - it has been there as long as homo sapiens has existed, for about 300,000+ years. And, since evolutionary adaptations change according to their environment, we are living in an era where Vogue magazine has been ultimate arbiter of the female ideal for decades. As to any consolation or juicy schadenfreude, this also ensures that JLo is equally miserable about her body, since it has been criticized for being too short, too fat, and too "ethnic." We only need to look back at the year 2000, when Cindy Crawford, supermodel extraordinaire, said this about Jennifer Lopez: "If I had a b**t that big, I'd never leave the house."  And on that note - la lucha continua!

I'm a guy nearing his last years in his 50's. I like to believe that I look a tad bit better than my dad did back then. I suppose a great deal of that satisfaction comes from costume.  

I don't where short-sleeve button down shirts with shorts, black socks, and hush-puppies. I am not uber-shique but control my youthful appearance with jeans and comfortable shirts.

For the record, while watching J-Lo doing her half-time gig with Shakira, my one thought is that I didn't think Jennifer was that tall or for that matter Shakira was that short. Next to Shakira, J-Lo looked like an Amazon Woman - I suppose her outfit aided in this illusion.

But the one thing I didn't even consider was her age or timeless fitness and beauty. This is J-Lo as I will always imagine her as and no doubt, as she always wants to be remembered as.

So hold up your chins somewhat because no doubt there was a time when you were happy with yourself and your appearance that provided you with the assurance that not too much has changed since ..... you were younger.

But there comes the time when the body simply can't hide what the cells can't do. Eventually your veins show through ever thinning skin. Bones become more obvious as muscle tissue turns to mush.And hair grows less from places that it should and more from places that it shouldn't.

1)  We've gotten to a point in this country where I can't even watch the Super Bowl half time show with my kids because it's soft porn.  Crotch shots, Ms. Lopez grabbing her crotch, etc.  Lovely.

2) What has happened to the idea of not objectifying women?  The more we see them as sex objects, the more they are thought of as meat. And we wonder why they are so often abused?  

Anyone who thinks it's perfectly okay to "celebrate" women as sex objects on a national stage like the SB is part of the overall abuse problem.

how about you just... don’t take another woman’s body personally? She looks great, good for her, but she’s a mega star who’s always been known for her great butt and fab abs. I feel like one half of the bodily expectations complex is a psychosis brought on by women onto themselves with language not unlike that of this article! very counterproductive and not very feminist. Say “good for her” and move on. Is it really that hard

Apparently so.  I’m 60, I try and eat right, shower regularly and wear clean clothes.  I am not thin, I am not fat, I am pretty average, I think.  I am healthy. I have grandkids.  You wouldn’t catch me in an outfit like that even if by some miracle I could pull it off.  And no, I’m not jealous. Just a bit sad, really, that we still think women need to pole dance and thrust their crotches at the camera to be entertaining.  I’m no prude, or crusading Christian in a hair shirt.  I’m just a normal woman who has worked all her life, married, raised kids, paid taxes, voted, and tried to follow the golden rule, who is so very, very tired of it all:  Hooters, Victoria’s Secret, cheesy NFL cheerleader outfits, boob jobs, bleached teeth, Botox lips and butt implants, liposuction and colored contacts, hair extensions and eye, face, and neck lifts.  Endless diets, exercise routines and artificial underthings designed to force-fit us into shapes that never were anatomically correct (taking about you, Barbie!).  And the beat(ing) goes on.  As I write, another Jenny Craig commercial appears. Sigh. I feel you, Jennifer.

Please.  JLo has been a dancer all her life (she started showbiz as a "Fly Girl" on In Living Color).  It's not all costuming, makeup and plastic surgery.  Asa dancer, she most likely works out/rehearses *every day.*  Can I do that?  No.  I'm making a living.  Am I healthy?  Yes.  I get exercise (never enough sleep though), and enjoy chocolate now and then.  The only thing that bothered me about the halftime show was the gratuitous crotch shots, but that's a producer's decision, not the performer's (at least, not in the moment).  

So get over it and count your blessings, please.

I realize this deviates from the main discussion point here, but what I really want to know is why was that soft-porn display appropriate for half-time at the Super Bowl? Is this day and age of being "woke," how "unwoke" was that? Stripper poles and breasts galore -- makes Janet Jackson's wardrobe malfunction look like small potatoes. In a matter of minutes, we back peddled decades with this display of  a male fever dream.

I love JLo. She's beautiful and talented and from what I read, a really nice woman. However, what struck me was that the male singers were all wearing baggy clothes. What I would l like to see is a half-time show aimed at women. Picture a famous male performer surrounded by dancers all in a  jockstrap, twerking and grabbing their crotch. Now, that would give  me a reason to watch "the game."

What I find really offensive is the repeated claims that this was done "for men's viewing pleasure."
