Sorry, but J Lo and Shakira is the last thing most men wanted to see for the SB half time show-- that had to be a woman's choice. As a friend claimed (a woman), "I'd rather see J Lo shake her stuff than a bunch of big dumb jocks smashing their helmets together."
Yes, we've brought the most superficial and tacky Las Vegas stereotypes, true American Trash Culture, to TV viewers across America. Not sure why J Lo and Shakira had to go to such lengths to attract attention. If I had an 8 yr old kid, I certainly wouldn't shield his/her eyes, but I would have a sincere apology about this most American pastime, Super Bowl Sunday's halftime show. Sorry kids! We all long for Prince, to see him once again in the Purple Rain.
Since I've become an old man I now question why women feel they have to dress this way and sing, and dance like strippers. What is the point?

Listen, you do you, let J Lo do J Lo.  When you're in the business of fitness and dance, it's a lot easier to be fit, because you're exercising 8 hrs a day.
I just turned 50 and I'm embracing me.  I don't look like J Lo, because I'm not her.  I am the best me I can be today.  
This article is what's wrong with women.  Instead of giving her a round of applause, you've decided that this is about you.  Knock it off.  Let her have her moment, and if you're insecure, do something about it, or otherwise stop commenting.

Come on, now. Of course Jennifer Lopez looks amazing. That's her full-time job. And she's very, very good at it.

Any of us would look incredible at age 50 if we had access to the same things that she has access to: i.e., millions of dollars (and all that it buys); mansions; trainers; nutritionists; chefs; maids; an army of personal assistants; bodyguards; the best beauty items and treatments that money can buy (ditto for hairdressing); stylists; makeup artists; massage therapists; facialists; luxury clothes and shoes; doctors; therapists, etc., etc., etc.

The super-rich have always been able to afford these luxuries. The vast majority of us will not. This was true before Jennifer Lopez came on to the scene, and it will be true long after she's gone. 

What is also true is that no one can make you feel intimidated or reduced to inadequacy by Jennifer Lopez' looks and accomplishments UNLESS YOU LET THEM. 

And if you do let yourself get sucked into that, that's on you, not on her.

There’s certainly misogyny, driven by men.  

What do you call the rules of behavior and acceptability that women construct and impose on themselves and other women?

Are you serious?  We're supposed to tear down other people's efforts to keep themselves strong because they don't pamper our own less-than-stellar efforts?  There's always the picture of 'coronary-waiting-to-happen' Lizzo on the cover of this month' Rolling Stone to warm one's own lowered expectations by.
I loved this article, Jenn. Weiner! Thanks~ "Aged 58 Hotness in GA"
First world problems -  I can't believe that women (I am one) actually log into social media and discuss J Lo's body. Seriously folks, who cares.
You are not looking at her skin, she is covered in a flesh colored garment to hold her in, give her body a smooth appearance.  Don't get me wrong, she is beautiful and 50 is beautiful!
Good Opinion piece Ms. Weiner. I'm sure a lot of people are thinking the same thing.

JLo is a professional dancer.  She keeps herself in top physical condition as all dancers do.  Dancers are professional athletes.  She also has access to topflight trainers, cosmeticians, and dietitians.  She ain't the mom down the street.  So no, you aren't supposed to look that good.

A silly discussion. 
It was a show, not a moral statement. 
A pretty good show at that.
What would JLo and Shakira look like if they had spent their lives as waitresses, teachers, or even doctors?

If it's any comfort to Ms. Weiner, look closely at the photo: It is obvious that most of Ms. Lopez's costume is flesh-toned spandex and not her own skin. It's all smoke and mirrors, makeup and costuming. It's theater. Those of us who live in the real world have better things to do with our time and money at this stage of our lives. Anybody who is expecting a normal woman in her 50's to look like a stage performer who has devoted their life and career to their appearance is a shallow fool who needs to get out more. 

The only person who I care about being sexually attractive for is my husband.

Thank you Jennifer. I'm a 66 year old woman who grew up knowing that no matter what I did, I would never look like the models in the fashion magazines that I and my sister poured over. I was actually more offended at the Super Bowl by the men dancing next to Shakira who were covered from head to toe. Look at the red carpet -- men in suits, women nearly naked. I, for one, am really tired of it. Where's Chris Martin of Cold Play with his T-shirt and jeans? He's in great shape too; he just doesn't have to flaunt it.

Rather than feel judged by “JLO at 50” I was happy to see she is not anorexic and has full hips and thighs. She proves you don’t have to be a skinny twig without curves to be sexy. I loved her dancing and the choreography of the show.

Seriously? Is inviting sexual objectification the main measure of aging well? I know lots of 50-year-old women who are in great shape, look good, and manage successful careers while raising teens. None of them would want to make a sexual public spectacle of themselves. 

J-Lo has a career and she's done extremely well. She must spend half her life on her appearance. Doesn't bother me. Good for her. But this conversation is pretty demeaning. And the show was vulgar and the 'politics' shallow and token, despite how talented both women clearly are.

One suggestion: 
a. Find a safe trail that is 4miles long. In Philly, it's the Bala Cynwyd Heritage trail. 
b. Old school, a power walk. It takes time but after a few months, you'll be thankful. Your stresses will seem minor.
c. Eat well. No tuna due to mercury levels. The more plant based foods, the more phytoestrogens to slow the change of life issues. Take Dong quai.
d. It's your body and health. Don't screw it up! The next ten years of this simple protocol will make all the difference twenty to thirty years from now.
She looks amazing! But let’s not forget that genes have a lot to do with it and lots and lots of cash!

The casual racism of this is troubling. I’ve read so many versions of this article in the last two says, all written by white cis women. I did a quick check and couldn’t find anything similar for Madonna or Gaga, despite the similarities in their costumes.

I gave the performance  C /D. Yes, they both looked great.
Celebrating two Latina women is great - but all they do is shake their ass and pole dance ( even if done in an artful way)?
Unfortunate.  I say let’s go back to marching bands.

I agree. Since I joined Facebook in late 2008, I have been stressed by Senior/Older Adult  Olympics challenges by even Boomer and Silent Generation social media leaders whether by physical,  intellectual or social  achievement prowess. 

In the meantime, the real life Older Adult Olympics challenges of well-functioning older adult svelte or softig women--income, housing, transportation, caregiving to husbands and children, widowhood and medical care delivery problems galore--are being ignored.

Shakira's performance was of far more musical interest, though this is clearly an afterthought for many. 

I was fascinated by the degree to which the two women's pudenda were the feature of focal and sartorial interest. There are so many ways to read this, some of them--I think--positive. My fifteen-year-old daughter, who is one urbane post-structuralist-feminist, kept saying, "Oh, you have children!"

The nod to Puerto Rico's plight was so slight as to go mostly unnoticed. In my day, the island wanted its independence; I still think that would be a good thing.

Like the athletes on the field, or actors who hold on to action roles, it's part of the job to stay in shape for some artists. Not unlike CLE courses for lawyers, or keeping up-to-date on health codes for kitchen staff, or learning the newest tunneling equipment for the union people working on the new transit tunnels. J-Lo looks amazing, and kudos to her, but that's part of her shtick.  Aretha Franklin did not have "an amazing body" in 1993 when she performed at the inauguration, but I would pay 10x as much to listen to her than J-Lo, not to take anything away from Lopez' talent. Aretha focused on her voice and vocal training, and honing that to a level of perfection rarely heard - that was her choice in focusing her career.

I don't know how the author can claim to know what men thinks about their body in general, I'm sure there are plenty of men that experience the same feeling that the author are experiencing. I know a lot of them that are really worried about how they looks and how much they weight.

I admire JLo’s beauty and physique and yesterday had a delicious Ghiradelli home chocolate with whipped cream (made in my kitchen because those are normal grocery store purchases). 

I also went to the gym to work out with my barely-affordable trainer and spent the rest of the day - like most days - in cushioned  sneakers and elastic waistband leggings.  

I’m turning 48 and have gained 15 pounds in the past ten years which I’d like to lose.  

Yet I know my jobs are to create customer engagement strategy for my consulting clients and care for my 85-year old mother whereas JLo’s is to keep her body, face and voice in tip-top shape.  

I never thought I’d say this, but I appreciate my inner couch potato man.
I had lots of private thoughts about the half-time show, but it never occurred to me to compare myself to any element of the spectacle.  Why on earth would I?

I'm a 40 yo male, and I assure you that the body dysmorphia described, while not shared by all men, is something that a huge number of men my age go through.  Many of the men who I know at the gym are only there to achieve a physical appearance similar to professional male athletes.  Some do so the old fashioned way: weight lifting, cardio and a stringent diet.  Not all do.

I imagine that many people can relate to looking at yourself in the mirror. Feeling the shame that comes with your body changing in respect to age in this era where I'm encouraged to compare it to the bodies of the most beautiful people in the world, I do understand, even as a guy.  I assure you that many of the men eating nachos in that room feel shameful for doing so, but are on the losing end of an emotional battle.

I think that it's important to remember that traditional masculinity in the United States has a lot of emotionally and psychologically harmful traits, and not talking about this kind of thing is an important aspect of that.  Please don't assume that this means men don't care about their appearance.

There are certainly more important things in a woman’s life than their physical appearance. The female spirit can be truly beautiful in its compassion, in its grace and in its strength. We are as young as we feel and need to keep growing at any age.

Too bad  we focus on such superficial aspects of  who we are.  Beauty is wonderful and it is there at all ages. In the end all that matters is love.  How have we loved?  We are so much more that just  our"looks".  If we( all people regardless of gender) really  want equality why not lose the 'comparison" tendency? Why not focus on who we are as people and what we are called to do in our lives?

Maybe the moral of the story is that women should stop judging each other. Women Unite! I'm a man and all I saw was Jlo putting in countless hours of practice, exercise, sacrifice and rehearsal for what would be the biggest moment of her professional life. And that makes some people insecure?

I am not 50 yet. But at 40, I am incredibly thankful for being healthy, and the increased wisdom, comfort and freedom aging brings.

No, I do not feel judged by JLo's body. Not even a bit.

Don't feel judged. There's an entire team of people, trainers, choreographers, hair/makeup & wardrobe stylists, etc, working with these celebrities to ensure age-defying results on stage or on screen. Diet commercials on tv are equally guilty — and a little diffusion on the lens or bright lighting washes away a multitude of flaws. It's a performance, yes, they look amazing and have worked very hard, but they've had help. Go, live, and enjoy your nachos.

I’m 55 and I didn’t watch the Stupor Bowl. I was at the gym doing laps in the near empty swimming pool. Later when I watched the show, I thought “power to the Latinas! And wow they must have an army of trainers and stylists.” Then I resumed pondering which swim, bike and run events I’ll sign up for this year.

I think it's interesting that anyone would feel 'personally judged' by what anyone else is doing.  The comparing mind is relentless, ruthless and certainly not something that is wise to indulge.  I doubt if any man is thinking, "Why doesn't my wife, girlfriend, mother look like that?"  Separating reality from fantasy is a good thing to take up as a serious endeavor, and as others have said in these comments, the real work and cosmetic work J-Lo does to attain her physical capacity is a full time job.  So, unless I want to work out for 2-plus hours a day and focus almost 100% of my resources on the 'outside', I need to stay in my lane and appreciate someone's ability to perform.  Personally, I have a life centered around helping people change from the inside out...and I do dance whenever I have the chance.

Back in college, I had a friend who took time off, went to Southern California, and got a job tutoring a prominent actresses' children.  She was a prominent late 1950's through mid-1970's sex symbol.

As he told me, one night they were all at the dinner table and all she had to eat was a baked potato with nothing on it.  She looked across the table at him with a bit of anger in her eyes and said, point blank, "You think this job is easy?"

This was her career, one she wanted to pursue and something she was willing to sacrifice for.  And she was no different than Mick Jaeger and other performers who hire personal trainers, watch what they eat, and do what they need to do so they can pursue their dreams.

If you want, make the choice I have.  Drop the envy.  Join the Y or other fitness center.  Develop the mental discipline and put in the effort.  And get your kids to go too as it will help them develop some good habits.  The workout regime may not be part of your career path but there certainly are benefits.  I certainly can't say I'm sexier but at least I'm in better health and I feel better about myself.

It is a matter of good taste.  The performers of today do not know the meaning of the word.  They are competing with the notion of who can be the most sensual.  These women are not the role models we want for our children.  Of course, performers never were and I guess it has to be taught in the home.  I feel so sorry for young people today.  They are getting so many mixed messages.
I know plenty of 50 year olds who have good looking bodies. At 50 you're suppose to look like what you're willing to put the work in for and what your body allows.
Beautiful work, Jennifer!

Celebrity and money can work wonders on someone who also happened to be born gorgeous. Tell your daughters that this isn't the standard to judge themselves by. Brave, funny, smart, kind and loving are several aspirations that our young women should know are more important (and lasting) than carefully curated beauty.

Also, don't let J-Lo intimidate you. Whatever year you choose, it will be YOUR year, Jennifer!

Look at pictures of crowds from the 1950s and 1960s of men and women watching ballgames, rocket launches, and civil rights protests, and you will see a marked difference in physical fitness.  Negligible obesity, smaller waistlines and bra cup sizes are visible.

What’s changed since those halcyon days?  Well, Mom and Dad aren’t home to prepare healthy meals with real foods instead of letting everyone fend for themselves reaching into the freezer to pop some garbage food into the microwave.  Far more fast-food and restaurant visits eating food made by strangers in the name of “saving time.”

It’s not that hard to look similar to JLo and Shakira.  There are scores of Professional, working Moms in their 40s and 50s at my gym who look fabulous.  The Halftime show shouldn’t be a threat.  It should be a challenge to strive for better.
J Lo and Shakira both look fabulous.  But they are performers, and appearances are part of the act.  This can’t be the standard to judge ourselves.

Thank you! And it's not just the women. Guys like Rob Lowe set an unattainable standard for men in their fifties, too.
As a marathon runner, I'm faced with the aging person's dilemma: be a thin faced athlete or look young. Can't have both.

You probably shouldn't let this bother you.  People like J. Lo are paid millions to look great. It's literally part of her job. Male Hollywood stars are also paid to look great, and spend  just as much time in the gym.  Human beings like to look at other human beings who look good, and if you're an entertainer who is paid millions to entertain, looking good is part of your job. If someone paid me millions to spend all day, every day, in the gym, I would look like The Rock.  If you did the same thing you would probably look as good as J. Lo. But unless somebody pays us millions to do so, most of us don't have a million hours a week to spend in the gym.  Thus, most of us don't look like J. Lo, or The Rock.  Pretty simple really. Not that deep.

I’m not a sports fan but I went to a Super Bowl party at my brother in law’s for the food. Room full of men and only me and one other woman present, both in our 50s. At halftime the sound was turned off so that we could listen to some Greatful Dead. Most of the group didn’t even bother to watch JLo and Shakira, but I was glued to the TV. I was proud of these women, they looked amazing, they’re successful, they’re talented. Sure they’re flaunting what they have, who cares, it’s entertainment, it’s what they do. I’m 56, do I want to look like that? Yes. But I realize that’s not an option for me and I’m okay with that.

If you want to focus your daily life on working out so you can ultimately push yourself into a compression body stocking you can have what JLo has too. The package is the commodity, and she's doing what she can to maximize its potential. Admiring her tenacity and discipline seems more useful than seeing her body as the standard for 50 year old women.

oh good grief...of course you can look like Jennifer Lopez at 50 (minus the wide hips).  It does take work but its totally possible...even on a low salary (as I had at 50).  I just walked 5 miles a day.  Every day.  You do that.  You can eat what  you want.  You do have to cut out all the sugar that alcohol creates.  50 is still young so its not a big chore to be disciplined.
She is an entertainer. That’s part of the kit. Men and women. No need for comparison.
Relax everyone.  Sure she has the genetic goods to start with, but body suits, impeccable make-up, expensive hairdo and lighting do the rest. She has tired Tuesday mornings as well.

Yes, this is how you are supposed to look at fifty. And sixty. And seventy. I am J-Lo’s age and without boasting, I look as good for my own body type which is, shall we say, more El Greco than Rubens. I have nothing but contempt for women who let themselves go, finding excuses in age, genes, or culture instead of admitting to being lazy. Being beautiful and sexy is as important as being smart and educated. Beauty is a great gift and should be treated with the same respect we give to intelligence, which is, after all, also a combination of natural endowment, training and personal effort. I didn’t watch Super Bowl because I am not interested in sports but I will look up J-Lo’s performance just to admire her achievement and express my solidarity with her. “Beauty is truth; truth - beauty” (John Keats).

I feel great and I don’t look like that for sure. Girl, you said it all with the guys not feeling not an iota of remorse over their loss of youthful bodies. Me and my man travel, make love, study, publish, and enjoy life immensely!

First, if nachos whisper to you, I think you have a problem with food akin to an addiction.
Also, maintaining a healthy body fat % is not just a cosmetic issue.
Consistent daily exercise doesn't have to be strenuous...even simply going for a walk helps maintain overall health, including mental and "spiritual" well being.
Priorities are merely the things we want to do. Put your phone away. You'll be amazed at the amount of time you have to indulge in your favorite physical and mental health regime.
And finally, YES, you can look that good, without J Los money or her fleet of personal assistants. Go for it, any age is too early to "let yourself go".

Of course, feeling personally judged in this case is a projection, a hallucination. And if Jennifer Weiner saw my 70 year old wife I doubt she could recover from her shock. Some people keep their bodies in good shape, others keep their minds sharp and many do nothing at all but deteriorate.

This is Hollywood! Of course they look better then the normal person. And yes, men see George Clooney and Brad Pitt and feel a twinge of guilt about their own looks. For those who have the desire and genetics to look younger then their age I tip my hat. Yes, they work hard at it. But if you spend a excessive amount of time mourning the passing of your youth you will solve nothing and ruin your remaining time on earth.The fact that most people, with the rare exceptions, look their age is just a fact of life.

It's a good thing guys rarely feel shame when watching elite athletes.  Being an athlete at that level requires something beyond the immensely hard work they do, something also required of J.Lo - rare genetics.  Genetics are outside of your control.

As long as you're working to be the strongest version of yourself, you should never feel bad about yourself simply because you aren't the best.  You gotta just compete against yourself, and be better than the person you were yesterday!

I have better/more constructive things to do than being obsessed with how I look. Her performance was SO not family friendly. I felt like I was in a strip club or something. Katy Perry's show in 2015 was spectacular.

I’ll be hitting seventy in March and I’ve been gray (Prematurely, like my dad) since my early forties as a way to accept my aging process rather than letting society dictate my attitudes about myself.  I’m fed up with anyone telling me what to do, so I understand that attitude.  

At the same time, I do think it’s a mistake to be too dependent on your looks.  Because, of course, you will age and have to deal with all that comes with that fact.  All the Botox and dollars spent of falsely advertised creams, etc. won’t change that. 

I’ve had my own home practice of yoga, use my indoor bike and walked my dog, everyday for many years.  Yes, my skin is wrinkly but I enjoy life to the fullest, gardening, traveling, studying French, oil painting (and selling), style my hair and use a little bit of make-up each day. 

 I take excellent care of myself and feel just fine.  I wish the same for women around the world.  That is the best revenge!

THIS:  "The answer, I think, is to watch these types of performances like a man."

But it happens to a lesser degree for men.  

Mick Jagger, Bruce Springsteen have performed at halftime at the Super Bowl.  One often hears  remarks about their physical appearances and physical capabilities and how good they look too.  My wife could not believe that Howie Long (one of the FOX Sports halftime guys) looked so good for his age (over 55) so it goes both ways, but I think you are correct that women looks to a very much higher level.  That is because society tells them that their self worth is wrapped up in their physical appearance.  Make up is a billion dollar industry.

For men is it often a joke that they are out of shape.
We feel affronted when we get “objectified” and yet here we are objectifying ourselves.  We can’t have it both ways.

J-Lo’s career depends on her body and she’s been a lifetime dancer, which most of us were not.  After 50, health is far more important than being hot and that involves gaining a few extra pounds so if you get sick, you won’t be reduced to skin and bones.  Homo sapiens women post menopause were never meant to spend their time pretending they were still 25.

This is what spurs contemporary culture? Did anybody catch any of the lyrics? So much energy put into so little inspiration. 

We deserve MAGA.

My wife, who is also 50 years old, is hotter than J.Lo. 
(At least in my eyes)
Well, speaking as a perfectly normal mid-century male born one month after Pearl Harbor, I don't see the problem.
Dorothy was my plan too, and I'm sticking to it.

There's such a profoundly simple solution to this problem: stop caring what J. Lo looks like, and stop comparing yourself.

If your world is made up of people who don't allow you to do this, seek better friends.

If that doesn't work, recognize that literally she's spent more on making her body look good than would be needed to feed small countries in Africa.  I'm probably only partly exaggerating.

Perhaps all celebrity images should come with the equivalent of a nutritional label:  2346 hours of hair and makeup went into this image; 36.7 tons of weights lifted; 429 hours of nutritional training and professional catering.

Maybe that would help us recognize that what we see is the product of enormous expense, and utterly unrealistic a goal for most of us normal people.

The one thing truly worthwhile question is how can I be more fit.  Activity and appropriate weight make us live longer, think better and, oh yeah, also look better.

Oh, maybe it's also useful, reduce stress by no longer comparing ourselves to ridiculous ideals, striving for absurd standards of appearance.  Stress is not pretty.

Don't we all have something more important to do than fritter time and money on our appearance?

Ok, if you feel “personally judged” by someone’s body- be it J Lo or anyone else, then perhaps you need to a little introspection. For many people, their outward appearance, body and athletic performance are a priority. For many others, it isn’t. If it isn’t yours or you never plan on it being a priority, get over it and live your life.

I am a competitive athlete and therefore, spending hours training in the gym and adhering to a specific diet are a huge part of my life because that’s what I need to do to perform at my best. 

Since you are a writer, I imagine you spend far more time and effort meticulously writing, editing, and reading than I ever will. And that’s great because it’s your profession. 

No one is “making” you feel judged. That’s all you.
Love the comments regarding guy’s psychology! Hysterical and accurate from my own personal perspective.
That's not what a male inner voice whispers. Pretty unhealthy minimization there.
It's about time we stopped moralizing bodies, regardless of age. Period.
Who cares? If anyone has not figured out looks are not the most important thing by the time you are (fortunate enough) to be 50 years old, then your wires are crossed.

"Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter." 

You can think that all you want, but a lot of us feel intense shame and self-hatred about it.

When your job is to "look good", you work hard to "look good".  J. Lo has trainers, personal chef, can make her own schedule and works at her craft.

"Regular" people also work hard... at Nursing, Teaching, Administrative, Banking, Technology and other types of jobs.

If you asked a fish to climb a tree you would think the fish is useless.  Everyone has their 'thing' - don't get lost in other people's 'things'

Dear Friend,
I love you for writing this down for me!
I’ll see you in the back with Bea
Don’t forget to moisturize : )
Love,
Me

How did this become about you?  If you want to look like JLo, you should have started to dance and exercise years ago.  You can still get off the couch and get in shape now. Either watch and enjoy or don't watch, but quit the complaining about your own looks; it's not about you.
Nachos are good and they don't judge. Now where is the dip?

I'm not a Pearl Clutcher.  Shakira and JLo are talented women who are quite beautiful and notably well-preserved. More impressively, they are also the authors of their long tenured success in a difficult business. 

My issue is with commoditizing female sexuality under the guise of 'power'. This sends a clear signal about where our culture believes a woman's power originates. It reinforces the notion that our primary currency is appearance and sexuality. I'd like to think our power is rooted in strength and talent and capability and compassion. Or is the sad truth that it's simply about shaking our half-naked asses while you still can?

The show was bright and shiny and energetic but felt regressive in terms of women.
At 66, with just my routine 30 minute daily walks, my body would look good in J.Lo's outfit, but I dress like Bea Arthur and aspire to Betty White's wit.

I, a woman well past her forties, watched in awe as the two women twirled, shimmied and leapt across the stage. I never had a body remotely approaching theirs, but that is only because I never put in the necessary self discipline and hard work. Salacious schmalacious, theirs was an Olympic level performance with a mind. How ever can anyone move with absolute precision so many muscles in so many opposed directions at the same time? Coordinated, no less.  Who even has them?
The performance left me on the one hand rueful of my lifelong sloth, while filled with new respect for these two intelligent, gorgeous and hard working women. Born in the USA indeed. Alexa, play J Lo.

Jennifer Lopez, a lifelong professional dancer and entertainer, who has been a meticulous steward of her health and fitness, looks and performs on a level we associate with someone 20 years younger. Her entire existence revolves around this work. I think that a point made during this show (among others), is that if you still have the stuff to be center stage, you should be welcome to stand in that spotlight, numbers be damned. Let's not diminish that progress with these rather specious debates.

Why should men not walk around as our equals, and us not as theres?
Young girls gyrating with stripper poles in the background (initially) - where's the empowerment for women and girls?
The performance left me with more questions than answers to feminism.
All I saw at the party I was at were men with big smiles on their faces, as they watched the half-time show. And, yes, those smiles were all about how they thought women were there equal!

Crazy logic here. Ms Weiner maintains that the entertainment industry is making her feel badly about her looks. Huh? She is making herself feel badly.

The male athletes, the men and women dancers, are highly engineered entertainment products, and most of us understand that. They are not pretending to be role models. I've tried to talk my 58 year old wife out of getting cosmetic surgery; it's not going to make me love her more. But I've realized she's not doing it for me, but rather for other women. Get your acts together sisters, you're the feminists!

I watched the show with my hip-hop 18 year old daughter and my wife. We all loved the show, twerking and all.
I'd look that good too if I was being paid the kind money she makes.
I suggest that no one feel too bad.  To paraphrase the immortal words of Dolly Parton, it takes a lot of money to look that cheap.

BRAVO!!!!!!!!

It's all in the genes. Or jeans.
If you really want to attrack the crowd pictured below her, then yes, you will have to look that good.

it never ceases to amaze me...why are people stupefied when a celebrity manages to contravene the accepted american standards of beauty and age?

is jennifer weiner so delusional that she believes jennifer lopez doesn't have a team of (assumedly highly paid) people to keep her figure in check? to keep her diet free from trans fats and cholesterol? lopez is a trained dancer with millions upon millions in the bank, which allows her the freedom to devote time to her appearance, a factor not afforded most women her age. 

weiner should stop comparing her body (and, in turn, other women's bodies) to lopez's as if it serves any other purpose than making "normal" 50-year-olds with a belly and grey hair feel like moral failures. this article is clearly meant to be complementary to lopez, but reads completely tone-deaf on a wider scale.

Feeling judged? Your choice, your problem.

And your foolishness. Can't you see how much of her face and body is covered up? You're not seeing anything up close, and that's by design. 

She looks very good, obviously takes care of herself (with plenty of helpers), and has cause for pride. 

But look at her up close when she is naked in bright light and you will see a 50yo body in almost every sense.

Why compare yourself at all? She's up there because she's considered to be near the very top among all the possible people that the stage could be given to after a lifetime of dedication to her looks/dancing/singing etc. 

Try to imagine men the day after the superbowl feeling threatened in their masculinity and writing articles about how they are no Patrick Mahomes or Adam Levine. We'd probably ridicule them. 

And as for JLo's outfit, there was a large amount of complaining last year about the double standard between Levine and Jackson, who was fined $500,000 for exposing the same parts of her body. If it was okay for him, people said it should be ok for her, and they put that double standard to the test again this year. The outfits can be read as female empowerment, and female empowerment can feel challenging because it is.

But the bottom line is if you are constantly getting articles on celebrities' looks or a social media feed of fighting over the subject, you are doing that to yourself.  You click the links, you curate your own social media feed, etc. If you're a 50 year old, its time to put on the big girl pants and actively decide for yourself what standards to hold yourself too already.

Gimme a break! All it takes to stay in shape is easy routines and not overeating. We should celebrate JLo and Shakira for being able to maintain a healthy weight and fitness level for so long when most who have gotten enormously wealthy would have given up and gotten fat and happy. And of course, so many white folks are going to say it has something to do with race that makes it so "easy" for non-whites to maintain fitness. It's all so silly, and please women, think for a moment what your reaction would be if a man wrote this about someone like Dwayne the Rock Johnson.
Good grief. Get over it! JLo looks terrific. But she has to due to her profession.
If men or women were watching a game filled with athletes carrying single-digit body fat, it sure wasn't an NFL game.

Yes. And all men need to look like Alex Rodriguez. I mean, what's the problem. Can't everyone afford a 24/7 personal trainer, chef, assistant, stylist, and dresser. I mean, c'mon, isn't that just too basic in America? We're not Soviet Russia for heaven's sake! Oh yeah, and portable lighting, wind, and fog machines to follow us throughout the day. Please.

I won't speak for all men, but Jennifer, I'm 75 and hate to look in the mirror after I've showered at the gym....where did that belly come from?  I'm sure that this issue is more of a woman's than a man's, but I'm equally sure we men are not immune from it.
I wish I didn't care, but I do.
And by the way, I was more impressed by JLo's (and Shakira's) incredible physicality than by their looks....their flexibility, strength and endurance were amazing.
J Lo's performance was more about showing off her body than her talent.
Fun article to read.  My advice to women who look at J-Lo....don't compare yourself to others, aspire to be the best form of yourself.

this is just the antiquated female stereotype of the middle aged woman (1) comparing herself to professionally attractive people, (2) feeling shame at not being equally professionally attractive, (3) blaming men ("the male gaze") for the standard of professional attractiveness.

i'm inferring that you do not know J Lo recently starred in a movie that had a lot to do with pole dancing. or that half time shows are marketing and promotion opportunities for all concerned.

woman's sense of body shame is the insecurity that tethers women to a big industry of appearance management, from cosmetics to "fashion". 

unfortunately, we can't tell the author's real opinion because the undertone of sarcasm or irony is self deprecating. "i'm only pretending to feel body shame as a joke, haha!"

feeble joke.
You always know the exact right thing to say, Jennifer. Thank you for this and please pass the nachos.
She is a dancer. Stop making everything about you. Sit back and enjoy the show.
That show was just tasteless and unwatchable.

Um, excuse me, Jennifer Weiner.  I don't know how old you are, but Blanche Devereaux of "The Golden Girls" was not supposed to be 50.  They were senior citizens (like me)!  I never thought of her as 50.  I assumed all of those women (with the exception of Dorothy's mother) were in their 60's.  That having been said, J-Lo is not particularly exceptional, as celebrities go.  Doesn't anyone remember the picture of Helen Mirren at 62 in a bikini?  Or Cher, for God's sake!  J-Lo has always been beautiful, she's incredibly rich, and has the time and money and determination to keep herself looking great.  It's Hollywood.  What is all the fuss about?

At some distant point, Jennifer Lopez, like Greta Garbo and Marlene Dietrich before her, will have to face the looking-glass and ask:

"My face in the mirror conveys ridicule.
I turn away saying, “Time is so cruel.
The weathered complexion I cannot avoid,
Nor the oval face that’s gone trapezoid.
My dark brown hair’s fast losing its sheen.
It’s mostly mouse-gray, betwixt and between.
The torso, once firm, is starting to sag—
Must I face the world like some brooding old hag?”

Time is indifferent in a week to a beautiful physique. Then only moral beauty finally counts like that on the face of a Mother Teresa.

I'm nine years older than J Lo, and I remember there being the exact same debate back in the 80s when Tina Turner had her "What's Love Got to do With It" comeback.  She was built like the proverbial brick you-know-what house, danced like an Amazonian on speed, and belted out tunes that would make both lovers of Motown and lovers of metal cry with joy.

And here's what I've concluded:  these women not only take a professional approach to their singing, choreography, and staging, but they also take a professional approach to their bodies:  personal chefs, dermatologists, plastic surgeons, hair & make-up stylists, fashion consultants, and trainers.  They get paid handsomely for what they do, AND they pay out huge sums of money to keep their bodies ogle-worthy.  Think of it this way:  the NFL teams that competed in the Super Bowl have an army of coaches, trainers, nutritionists, etc.  J Lo and Shakira have a similar entourage; they just pay for it as a cost of being who they are.  It's WORK, people!  

In any event, to try to compare oneself as an average working stiff with kids you are raising without the help of nannies is a fool's errand.  Even if you a dedicated health and exercise enthusiast, it's just not the same.

So, yes.  Enjoy it for the spectacle it is; don't think for one moment the mere mortal can achieve the same.

Why does SHE LOOKS SOOOO GOOO = I LOOK SOOO BAD?!
This doesn't have to be the case. She's looking good because that's part of her job, she has a full time staff helping her look that way etc. The rest of us are not that.
So from now on: She looks good. PERIOD.
You aren’t supposed to perform at the Super Bowl either.

I find this article a bit dated. Many men I know - gay and straight - are self conscious of their bodies (your author included). I would refer the author to bodybuilding competitions, crossfit gyms, or . . . Instagram as evidence. To reduce men in the article to nacho-eating baboons feels demeaning and unfair. If the author's social circle only includes men who fit this description, I would recommend she find new male friends.

This article started soundly, but somehow turned into an underhanded swipe at men. 

Try harder next time, I'm sorry you feel judged. Taking it out on men seems petty.

The question to ask is how much money and time it takes to achieve and the 50 year old feminist question of what women could be doing instead. The headline pitting Weiners body vs. JLos is classic patriarchy.

Seriously, folks?   She's got a dermatologist and plastic surgeon on call.  Those are hair extensions.  Notice the design of the body suit, outlining the skinnier version of her body?  She's got at least one personal trainer...maybe more.  Her job is her body and voice.  She's talented and no problem recognizing that. But, you're talented too.  That appearance is her job.  Your job is likely different.  Let it go and enjoy who you are.....
Excellent, Ms. Weiner you can write. Somehow you made a subject that I have no interest in, funny, interesting, and insightful. Thanks!

I have no idea why Ms. Lopez has suddenly become the standard bearer for women over 50. What is driving this? I don't want to look like her - she's far too "constructed" for me, and I don't even like her music. Why all the fawning over this woman? Very strange.

Looking good is her job, and she does it well. Also in her defense, she puts in a LOT of time at the gym. I don't think she's one of those reality-show ladies who zaps and cuts instead of grunts and lifts. All that said, whatever works for you (that you can afford) is cool. Let's lift each other up instead of tearing each other & ourselves down.

It's sad that you feel "body shamed" by J-Lo instead of a sense of feminine pride.  That a 50-year-old Latina is still so attractive, so acrobatically agile, and so talented demonstrates a Strong Woman.  And J-Lo clearly intended that to be felt by the Hispanic community under constant attack by Donald Trump in unfurling the flag of Puerto Rico as well as the white male dominated Hollywood Academy Awards process.  As one of those endangered species--a 79 year-old white male, all I can say is "Go woman!" Let J-Lo be the harbinger that 2020 will be "The Year of the Women."

Jennifer - if you have concerns with your body, why are you on social media? I am sorry that you feel the need to compare yourself to J.Lo (that would be like my 40-something football teammates comparing themselves to Tom Brady) then I would think social media would be even more destructive to your psyche.
Brad Pitt is 56. Maybe guys don’t compare themselves as harshly as women do, but it’s there.

I found J Lo's overall performance sad, insofar as, it seems that even a 'successful' mature women feels the need to try and prove to the world that she's still physically and sexually desirable.  No, this was not about empowerment or 'choices'.  It was J Lo's desire for self-affirmation, as seen through the eyes of others ('wow, doesn't she look amazing?!')  And btw, a woman can be seen as attractive, and even 'sexy', without dressing/carrying on in that way.

As for women as a whole feeling the need to 'keep up' with certain standards, and the ever-higher bar some women believe we are held to, it behooves us all to remember that... anyone with a brain understands full well the difference between reality and fantasy.  The J Lo show is the latter.  Professional hair and makeup.  Personal trainer and personal chef/dietician.  Then there's all the 'distraction' aspects...her outfit...the dozens of other dancers...the lights.  Sure, J Lo may have been blessed with good genes, but all the aforementioned sure does help as well.

Hetero women need to stop comparing themselves to others and wasting so much money/energy to try and 'look younger'.  Just be the best version of YOU that you can be, regardless of age.  There's nothing more Unattractive than self-loathing ('why bother trying anymore?') and an air of desperation (i.e., obvious 'procedures' all over your face). Truly beautiful women are content with themselves, and not obsessing over every sag and wrinkle.

There is definitely a generational thing happening -- just not the one the writer describes. I am a few weeks short of 38, but can’t think of one peer or friend who goes online to complain about how two women who performed made them feel bad/good. Perhaps we might discuss the next time we got together -- if it came up -- but I think generationally the idea of using facebook etc. for this kind of discourse is rather passé, especially for those of us who have been using these communication technologies for nearly two decades. 

And re: J Lo, she trains to be a strong athlete & performer. That said, I am not obsessed with age but I do care what I put in my body, how much exercise I get, and think about things like my skin -- because I want to live a healthy life. I hope I do look good at 50 but that will be driven by how I feel, how my body feels & is treated. I am not sure that “letting yourself go” is what women are meant to pursue at 50. Also, women of a previous generation (a la Golden Girls) aged more quickly for other reasons and it was convenient to portray them as old ladies when they weren’t really. With life expectancy up and awareness of how we can maintain health & longevity, 50 isn’t your grandma’s 50. JLo and Shakira are not that far apart in age and yet we can’t reconcile it because 50 has this weight to it that suggests we should have blue hair and tissues up our sleeve. Truth is -- only if you buy into that sort of thing.

Also, women, let’s be kinder to each other.

JLo chose to dedicate her life to the pursuit of body perfection and singing ability. Other women use their energy to run for public office, raise children, return to college or pursue careers. 
I'm not sure how well that toned, tanned flesh will sustain JLo into her 80s, but enjoy whatcha got, girlfriend! We are our values, and the best we can hope for is those values sustaining us into old age. 
Personally, I'd prefer a conversation with Elizabeth Warren to watching someone old enough to be a grandmother writhing on a stripper pole.

I was energized watching the Half-Time show. JLO and Shakira were fantastic. The music was fun. I could have done without some of the visuals, but frankly, the women performing came off strong, assured and not giving a damn about anyone else except what they personally could do. If that isn't empowerment I don't know what is. I sat there eating my Girl Scout cookies laughing at all of us (male and female) because I knew their strength and attitudes were going to be challenged by the most woke of us. Don't think for one minute anyone had control over what was going on except those two women. You go girls! It's all about the attitude. And strength. And courage. And doing whatever makes you strong. Brava!

At age 71 and counting, I just spent $22,450 on plastic surgery.  I drank the Kool-Aid.  It's not all good looking younger (and I do).  People do not know my real age, so they judge my my physical agility and mental acumen by the wrong gauge.  I'm sure they wonder why this apparently "60 year-old" is not more sprightly.

If there is a joy in being 50, it must surely be having reached a point where one can recognise that if it is important to someone to look a particular way, then good on them if they commit to spending their time and effort on doing it and if it is not sufficiently important to someone to spend the necessary time and effort on looking like this, so what?

If being 50 brings any responsibility, it is making that clear to people without the benefit of 50 years' experience.  Decide what is important to you and own your decision. Time not spent in the gym is time available for other things.
Thanks for the shout-out to the great Bea Arthur, who remains an inspiration to people adoring wit over skin deep notions of beauty.

This column really just shows how divorced from reality Americans are, in general. 

First of all, Jennifer Lopez doesn't have a regular 9-5 job. She's made her career as a dancer, among many other things since 1991. She also found success and celebrity, and with that, millions of dollars. You can do a lot with millions of dollars. For one thing, you can hire an army of nutritionists, personal trainers, chefs, hair stylists, etc. She also has the luxury of being able to spend her time on her body. She is one of the very lucky few.

99.9 percent of Americans will never even come close because they need to work behind a desk for most of their day and then pick up the kids at school. And yet we expect the same results?

We have a very real problem with celebrity worship in this country.

She has nothing but time and money to work on her appearance, which is after all a professional necessity. She has good genes.  With modern makeup, hair styling and color and possible surgery, who knows what anyone actually looks like?  Chronology is over-rated.  I am obviously not a woman and nobody has any interest in my curves.  At the same time at the age of 70 my weight is identical to what it was thirty years ago, 125lbs, all muscle and sinew.  I have not lost a single step on the tennis court (my nickname here is Conejo - Rabbit). I can run ten kilometers without breathing hard.  I am not cataloging my good fortune with the object of bragging but as an instruction.  I have excellent genetics.  I stretch and do deep yogic breathing exercises religiously.  I engage in athletic activities almost thirty hours a week and average 20k steps daily.  I watch what I put into my body and research all supplemental possibilities.  Not everyone is so lucky or has the time, but staying in shape is possible for most of us.

I find it remarkable that millions of people watch a game played for hours, exclusively by men at the height of physical fitness and, indeed, bodybuilding, and no one asks whether the men watching feel inferior for being in the television presence of those more physically fit and attractive than themselves … but put some women on stage for a relatively short half-time show, and all folks can talk about is how some women feel inferior for being in the television presence of those more physically fit and attractive than themselves.

I am 58 and I enjoyed the performances. It wasn’t really my cup of tea musically but it was pop-y and upbeat. I am sad that so many of my sisters feel so inadequate in comparison. I know it’s a struggle that is uniquely female. As I watched, I was just impressed by how well they got through a performance this is no less physically demanding than a high level athletic competition. That takes dedication and hard work — they didn’t get there with cosmetic surgery and hair dye. I remember a similar dust up back in the 80s about Jane Fonda and her workout tapes. It’s tough to break the shackles of judging ourselves against others and social media makes the churn even worse. I would love to see us get to a place where we can set aside these harsh judgments.

J Lo takes excellent care of herself. Daily naps have been a priority for her for years and sleep is a powerful anti-ager. She largely eats an anti-inflammatory diet and makes fitness a top priority. I would not dismiss her appearance as the sole result of money or plastic surgery. Try not to hate. I think everyone can achieve their best self. Let her be an inspiration. She is also an empathetic and kind person; her beauty is inside and out.

I don't remember a single word or melody from that halftime show. All I remember is a virtual strip act featuring Goddess-like bodies doing things and looking like something us mere mortals can only admire from a distance. 

It felt as if someone somewhere was trying to make sure I understood just how ordinary I was so they could sell me solutions one ad at a time. 

Some people are gifted with extraordinary looks and talent, and the energy and desire to translate them into stardom. I'm not one of them. I'd like to think I'm on the better side of average, but not by much. But that's OK because I realize two things. First, the people who show me those avatars have an agenda to sell me something that might make some of that star power rub off on me. I know better. Second, I've always liked looking at Bea Arthur; not the characters she played but the person who played it. I would have dated her any time.
Why can’t we just enjoy the show for its tremendous physicality, sublime joy, energy and Latino pride, lighten up, let it go and live ladies!
Sexual attraction is based on the assessment of reproductive capabilities and people are by nature very good at assessing that.

Where was the outcry when Brad Pitt (56) appeared shirtless, tanned and abbed?  Where were the complaints about him representing what all men should aspire to be?  Or how much time and money he spends on looking good?  If you complainers identify with movie stars, you have more issues than they do about looks.

Jenn, This column is terrific, just your cup of tea for a display of your sparkling sense of humor. I roared with laughter, marveled at your metaphors and sent it to friends. Wonderful, world class gift you have. Love you, hugs, paul in bessemer
This is insightful and brilliantly written. How liberating it can be when the pressure to be sexy is lifted.

So... what is next? 49er fans feeling bad because Cheif fans' team won? So they feel less? She did not make you feel bad. You choose to feel bad. Take some responsibility for your own happiness. You choose your thoughts. You choose your action and what is important to you. Tom Brady keeps throwing footballs better than me. My day is ruined. Yes, I can now blame Tom Brady for my emotional health. 

What has happened to us as a culture?
Brilliant. But I might point out that Brad Pitt at 55 is triggering some remorse over those nachos for at least a few of us guys.
I would not paint men with that broad a brush. Many feel inadequate about their bodies.

To be fair, most women at my gym Equinox look better than JLO. 
Clearly she is a successful entertainer but her body is not remotely something to be envious of.

I think a lot of what Kawhi Leonard told his Toronto Raptor team mates during the 2019 NBA Championship run (paraphrased):
"Enjoy the moment.  Control what you can control.  Do what you do best.  Enjoy the moment."
It's her job to look like that.  It's not mine.  (I'm 51)

self-defeating to compare with professionals. “ genetics, effort, discipline and money “ says it all. money for best of healthcare, cosmetics and surgery. also, those versace body suits.... look closer: excellent design /sewing  talent and solid foot to neck spanx-type material. and.... blanche looked hot in her red dress in the jealous of dorothy at the bar episode.

Most people can look and be pretty fit right up until they die. 
Why aren't they/we? 
The way our lives are lived does not allow for the time and effort of eating well and exercising the whole body properly, and an awful lot of ignorance about how our bodies work.

Maximizing profits is damaging in so many ways. Unionism is not just about making good pay. it is also about not working your body so hard it breaks and leaves you broken for the rest of your now very limited life.

Bea Arthur and Betty White were both in their mid 60s to 70 years old when Golden Girls was on. Rue McClanahan was 58 when the show ended. 

As a Gen X woman, I admit watching the halftime show thinking, "How are these ladies the same age as me?" and then I decided (perhaps delusionally) that if my JOB were to look good, I'd look pretty darn good at 50. I don't feel the need to look like a sequined pop goddess. But please, I beg you Jennifer, do not rush me into looking like a Golden Girl one single minute before my time.

I was a feminist before I knew what the word was. I still am. Which is why I applaud Ms. Lopez and Ms. Shakira. If either one of them were a journalist, they would be the best journalists out there. If they were welders they'd be the best welders out there. They are alpha females.

You are correct. You are all being judged. 
Please get to the gym ASAP.
I'll just have another cookie while I watch sports on TV.
Oh, and another beer.

To those saying that the performance was an empowered reflection of cultural differences and we should all celebrate these cultures, I’d respond that no, I don’t celebrate or appreciate aspects of cultures that seek to either (a) oversexualize the female body.....or (b) hide the female body.  Those are 2 sides of the very same misogynistic coin.  

I find the Southern European/central-South American style of “macho” misogyny quite repulsive. I have been treated aggressively by men when traveling in those countries and I didn’t like it one bit. If that means I don’t “properly appreciate” Latin culture, so be it!

I am 67 and still pretty much have a dancer's body but that didn't stop me from feeling that Jennifer Lopez unnecessarily buried what is true talent beneath overly sexualizing herself. I found it demeaning of women and of her individually.

This article is a testament to a great unspoken discrimination: that based on looks. You can't talk about it honestly, unless you enjoy being attacked, just like you can't talk about the contradiction between women's obsession with looks and their desire to be treated just like men in the realm of power. 

Throughout human history, whole classes of people (women, blacks, youth, etc.) have been oppressed by others. And though in outward matters this meant ridicule, poverty, enslavement, etc..., the ironic truth was that being oppressed resulted in a kind of blessing: they benefited inwardly, learning through suffering, and you could say, becoming more beautiful inwardly.

But humans have advanced to the peak of superficiality in our age, and now those formerly oppressed are getting their chance at power and glory. But at what cost? At the cost of being plastic, superficial, meaningless, and worst of all, blindness to ones own condition.

Jesus said, "Blessed are the poor", "He who seeks to save his life will lose it"

But let's face it, most today can't even conceive of what He was talking about. It's like playing a violin to cows: after mooing a bit in serious agreement, they rejoin the herd.
Jennie from the Block.  She is a self-made powerful woman.  I have no problem that she is super smart, powerful and yes beautiful.  Use it!

Oh honey, don’t do that to yourself.  I’m sure J Lo doesn’t mean to set a new standard of even more pressure to some unattainable beauty, unattainable for everyone except the few who have lots of money and time and obsession to create structures in their lives specially for that goal.  Just appreciate, don’t compete.

Why all this attention on J-Lo? Lots of celebrities have looked great at 50 (and no doubt, many non-celebrities). Jane Fonda boosted the idea that women in their 50s and 60s could look fit when she started the aerobics craze in the 1980s. Speaking of which, I think the important thing is to look healthy, no matter your age or physical characteristics.

Of course she looks terrific, she takes care of herself, like Madonna, and whether they have all the money in the world to make them look good on the outside, it’s what on the inside that counts.  I will take Dorothy any day or even Rose, two wonderful characters with a heart of gold.

Every decade has had a woman with amazing “looks” whose business was to capitalize on their brand of beauty. Sophia Loren, Raquel Welsh, Jane Fonda, and Cher, to name a few. But in terms of half-time shows, the one I will remember is Lady Ga Ga’s. Her talent, exquisite voice, and confidence gives her a genuine beauty.

I'm in my 20s and I don't look, dance or sing like J.Lo but I sure think she is inspiring. She is breaking the glass ceiling in her profession! She's worked hard to be so glamorous, it's her job.  While I'm pretty sure I will never look like J.Lo today, tomorrow or when I turn 50, I really hope I can replicate the perseverance and energy she brings to her job.

To be honest, many 20 year olds looked like Rue McClanahan in 1985 (I'm 57, I can attest to this!).  JLo is genetically blessed, rich, and works hard to look like she does.  I am still skinny and fit (genetics and hard work) but I won't ever look like I did in my 20's.  People now dress more alike across generations and have children at different ages too - my son is a freshman in college, but many of my peers have kids pushing 30 and some are grandparents already.  
And I think some, if not all, of men feel the same pressure to hang on to their "youthfulness," although most of them focus on their athletic prowess (master's ski racing and marathons in their 40's-70's around here) rather than their faces.  But realistically, we can all still get on the dance floor together, at any age, shape, or size!

I’m a 68-year-old woman.  It’s more what I can do as I age, rather than how I look, that is important to me. My husband and I both remember looking better, but we have those memories of each other.

Brain still learning new languages and music.  Body still hiking and rock climbing.  Yes, things are harder, and my body has various ailments, but I can still do things I enjoy.  When I can’t do the things that motivate me now, I’ll try to find other things.

It must be hard to have a profession that has the requirement of looking young and beautiful.  I don’t envy JLo the efforts she must make for that.
To be fair, my body at 30 didn't look like JLo's at 30. And I didn't look l JLo at 35 when I turned 35. I assume I will also not look like JLo at 50 when I turn 50.

"Pearl-clutching" normally describes the reaction to breaks from traditional morality.  Maybe some object to the half-time performance on those grounds, but the more common and important reaction is that this is another example of the portrayal of women primarily as sexual objects.  The fact is that women of prime reproductive age, that is fairly young, are most attractive to men for obvious biological reasons, so this is why it is important for performers to appear young, by whatever means.  If physical conditioning were the object there might be various athletic competitions or demonstrations instead of twerking and pole-climbing.

:-)

Also, I really wish celebrities would tell us what they have done and are doing in order to look they way they look. If I knew how much they worked out, which treatments or procedures they have had, and whatever grooming assistance accompanies it all, then I would feel a lot better.

It would be a public service!
Love this! I need to fine tune my inner voice to be more concerned with nachos than my imperfections for sure, new goals for 2020.

Yes, it goes without saying that as a successful professional entertainer and performer, she has access to an avails herself of a bevy of professional services. However, to imply that “any of us” could do the same would the same “help” really diminishes the incredibly hard work that she’s done (for decades) to maintain an athletic prowess that I personally find inspiring!

At almost 47 I am ever mindful of the changes that basis biology has in store for me and so I do as much as possible (that feels reasonable and balanced) to keep my body fit and healthy; my primary reward is that I still FEEL about 25 and the aesthetic rewards are secondary. I certainly don’t begrudge those who have more resources, “better” genetics etc. 

Because one thing you can’t buy or have given to you is the dedication and discipline that is required to achieve certain physical abilities. 

I worked with a trainer a few years ago after a major shoulder injury with the goal of being able to do full extension pull-ups by age 45 and I got there but only by my own two arms in the end. 

The issues of hypersexualized entertainment
is a whole separate interesting topic but it does feel a bit like another double standard that her hard work is minimized while professional athletes on the field are lionized for their well funded and supported achievements simultaneously.

I'm a 55 year-old woman who has exercised and eaten well most of her adult life. For me, it's about health more than appearance. A nice side effect? My body looks (and feels) almost the way it did when I was 20. I don't have a trainer and haven't had plastic surgery. The rest of me looks young as well because exercise and healthy food slow down the aging process. The human body is not intended to be sedentary or take in endless amounts of simple carbs. Yes, JLo works out, but that's what the human body is meant for - movement. Please don't judge her or other women over 40 for making the health, strength, and yes, appearance of their bodies a priority. It isn't about you.

Men do judge themselves, constantly. I think it's quieter, and manifests differently. Perhaps they're not all comparing themselves to elite athletes, but I think some are, even as they dip into the nachos. And, I agree with much of your article -- and much of what you write in general. I turn 50 this year and feel okay about my body; aches, hairs and all, knowing that I don't have the time or money to be sculpted and learn how to dance on a pole, but do have the time to swim, paddle around the bay and go dancing now and then. But it took 49 years to be able to no longer be deeply affected by these expectations of women, and that is liberating.

How ultra-sensitive has our society become?  Should I analyze the fact that I don't happen to look like The Rock and then cry about it to men of my generation?  Or perhaps we need to step back and value the performance as a whole and move on with our lives.  Else we start to become overly critical of everything in our daily lives.

"Women see inspiration or goals we’ve failed to attain or a pretty stick to beat ourselves up with." 

Speak for yourself. I'm a woman, I'm turning 50 this year, and I don't see J. Lo's body as a stick to beat myself up with. That's the beauty of being (almost) 50: Having the maturity to know better, to put some perspective around things, to stop creating unnecessary drama.

Stop pitting women against women. Stop pitting body type against body type. Stop pitting generation against generation. It's all so cliche and inaccurate and limiting. Enough already.

Honestly? J.Lo looks incredible.  

But the fact she looks incredible does not make me feel bad about my own body.  

I stay active not because I want to look like J. Lo, but because I want to be strong, and I mean STRONG well into my 50s, 60s, 70s, 80s, and god willing, 90s.  I don't wear high heels or make up, and I've eschewed injectables (but not lasers).  But I work out every day because I want to be able to do the things I LOVE--like hike and run and ski--for as long as is humanly possible.  

It's true, on a spectrum, my body is closer to J Lo's than the pot bellied man on the roller coaster, but it's not about looking incredible in a body suit.  It's about fighting osteoporosis by running.  It's about delaying knee replacement by keeping my weight manageable.  It's about staying fit so I can enjoy the ocean and mountains and wild landscapes of the world because I'm strong enough to go out into them alone.  

I'm not looking towards the horizon for that age when I can hang it all up.  I'm looking towards the horizon so I can keep fighting to keep the strength I currently have.

Those shows are not designed for men. They're designed by and for women. Just as men compete among themselves to form heirarchies based on strength, power and wealth, women compete among themselves to form heirarchies based on beauty, as a stand-in for reproductive health. Both approaches are innate, developed over millions of years to enhance reproductive success. It's literally in our genes (and jeans). The vast majority of the audience for beauty pageants is women, not men, because that audience wants to get a gander at the competition.

And Jennifer - you made me laugh about the roller coaster ride men are always on, and not missing a nacho chip, and also not having a moments self-doubt even when they watch men that are likely at the top .01% of honed  physical excellence. 

So all of us cut ourselves some slack and just love these women for their talents, hard work, and their willingness to share their art with the world. It ain’t easy, but it lifts me up!!!  I LOVED IT!!

“The answer, I think, is to watch these types of performances like a man.”

I love this. Right, reach for another chip, or head tot he gym or the dance floor and do your own thing, as you please, but don’t let someone else’s accomplishment diminish our own.  Appreciate it!
I have to admit, I almost didn’t read this column because, reading the headline, I immediately thought, “Why on earth should ANYONE feel bad about her own body, because another woman’s body is so beautiful?  Just appreciate and remember that beauty takes many many forms. “
But I am so glad I did read it. As a 67 year old cancer survivor, who has awakened to a full appreciation of my own imperfect body, and a determination to make the most of what I have and can do, I hold these women, and the many many powerful women I have known, in inspired awe.  Inspiration to keep dancing my own dance as long and as hard as I possibly can.

I’ve found great freedom in working hard to not obsess about my body. My family won’t love me more if I lose 10 pounds. I take care of myself - some days (periods, eras...) are better than others - and refuse to beat myself up and try to shrink. When my hair grays, maybe I’ll color it. I have a multi-step skin care routine because I like how it makes me feel, not how it makes me look. Truthfully, I’m not even certain that I look much different but I like that my skin feels softer and that the routine forces me to look in the mirror and acknowledge that I’m worth caring for. It would never occur to me that I’m “supposed” to look like Jennifer Lopez when I turn 50 (in four years).

I’m 69 years old now. I loved my fifth decade because I truly stopped thinking about what other people think of me. I want to be healthy, but couldn’t spend the time it takes to look like J.Lo and Shakira. They must work out for hours every day, and eat with the constant thought of the ramifications of each bite. No thanks!
Being an entertainer is very different from being an artist, activist, parent, grandparent and wife. I am very happy in my life, and I hope they are happy in theirs. Otherwise, what’s the point?

It's J-Lo's JOB to look great, she has endless resources to plunge into the work and can hire out most of the tedious daily tasks and responsibilities that distract the rest of us from our appointments with our trainers, our "team". Pretty sure I wouldn't want that job, certain I wouldn't want to be instantly recognizable when I go to the gym or just out shopping. Looking for that middle ground where I can recreate some of the muscle building and toning that 40+ hours a week of construction and athletics used to give me without getting obsessive about it, can keep some of my young vigor, and still have time for other things. And oh yeah, look pretty good for 68;)

"I have always tried to tell myself that celebrity bodies are a little like art galleries. I can appreciate and be inspired by their beauty. I can acknowledge the time and money that went into their creation. When I’ve finished looking, I can go home, secure in the knowledge that nobody expects my living room to look like that."

Excellent!

It was great to finally see two Latinas at the half time show.  I thought J Lo and Shakira both looked amazing.  They clearly take care of their bodies -- so what?   I hit the gym every day and see plenty of women in their 40s, 50s and 60s who look as good.  It has nothing to do with money but rather with your commitment to staying healthy and fit . . . looking good is just a side effect of that.

I can't imagine how much work she must put into looking like this. The dietary sacrifices and the hours of exercise. If your body is your livelihood, you live in a different world than the rest of us. Sure, I'd love to look the way she does (or the way I used to 25 years ago) but I like pasta too much and don't like exercise nearly enough. I'll take being a 54 year old who's in good shape over being a 50 year old who defies gravity and aging.

J Lo is a first class entertainer, and I was highly entertained. And inspired, by her and the hundreds of other beautiful, athletic dancers. I'm a 69 year-old woman. Why on earth would I feel "personally judged" by what they, as professionals, can do? Do you feel judged at a rock concert, the opera, the ballet, because you can't do what professionals do? If you can't enjoy, maybe just don't watch.

I have a minor disagreement with one point, that being that when I see toned-up guys doing their thing on TV, it makes me want to work out. I credit the spate of superhero shows and movies with the resurgence of my workout program.

That said, yes, J. Lo looks good, but who wouldn't, if they could afford to hire a staff of dieticians, cosmetologists, and trainers? Not to mention masseuses and celebrity orthopedists to make sure you don't have to contend with sore muscles and achy joints along the way.

Jlo, Shakira, professional athletes are like people playing the lottery. Some win a little. Some win a lot. You have to play to win. But even if you do, you’ll probably lose. So why bother? I won’t. And I won’t look like that at 50 and didn’t at 20.

This is about one thing, summed up in two words: unlimited resources. With the phalanx of trainers, choreographers, stylists, costumers and countless other resources at Ms. Lopez's disposal I would be shocked if she looked any other way except stunning and amazing. Don't get me wrong, she is a force of nature and an amazing performer. She goes for it every time she is on stage and I give her tons of personal credit.

Nobody should even begin to compare themselves to Jennifer Lopez until they can muster the same level of support she has. $40 million a year and a $400 million net worth can get you a lot of time with your trainer. A full-time job plus commute, a couple of kids, soccer practice, piano lessons, an escaped hamster and you're out of milk, good luck finding time to read this article in the Times let alone get to the gym a couple of days a week.

Cut yourselves some slack, it is not just between you and L-Lo.
The ideal result of moving away from ageism would be  acceptance women who look any age.

As a man when I see someone like The Rock or Jason Mamoa or any of the Elite athletes that played in the Super bowl of course I think "Man I wish I looked like that" but it never turns into trying to downplay those peoples achievements or attack them for showing me all my shortcomings. Rather it inspires me and I use it as motivation to make my self get up at 5am and hit the gym. Will I ever look like those guys, probably not but at the end of the day they look that way because the earned it.

My husband and I had an argument about the show. He thought it was salacious, i thought it was great. Most every woman in America would like to dance like that - and probably tries, in their Zumba class!

Spot on. I particularly liked your references to older men who keep reaching for the nachos without a thought about their beer bellies. Different standards for men and women’s looks. It has been ever thus.

J. Lo's appearance "for her age" is spectacular, yes.  But have we forgotten Madonna looked just as in shape when she was 50 and yet not one word was written on her in-shape body.  Rather, she was criticized for aging and for being 50.  Once again, Ms. Ciccone was battered for creating the pathway that others, like Ms. Lopez, now shimmy down.

The show-for me, anyway--wasn't about me. It was about celebrating two phenomenal women and their abilities. And I do think many men feel insecure about their bodies (which is why guys post pics of themselves looking ripped, etc). I love how amazing JLo and Shakira looked--and I love my own body, too (all four feet, ten inches of it).

I am male.  I never looked as good as Robert Redford (about my age), and I never will.  Get over it.

Of course, I'm a better physicist than he ever was or will be.

I think the author ends up in a better place than where she started with the title of this piece. J Lo is an incredibly disciplined, ambitious, world-class performer. She looks great and she works at it for I imagine a notable percentage of most, if not every, day. Don't feel judged- it's really not about you. Respect the hustle.

I don't look at these women and judge my body any more than I  look at professional athletes and judge my body. Other than keeping it healthy, I don't really think about my body all that much. As a 50+ woman, there are a lot of other things that deserve my attention more.

Years ago, I had a neighbor in her 30's who'd been born with severe physical defects - no ear, and so one had to surgically fashioned, bell's palsy, a hunched back. I hate to admit I was taken aback when I first met her. But that was the only time her physical appearance registered with me. She was intelligent and kind, dressed beautifully, and had a very successful career. She once remarked that her mother told her "if you don't think you are beautiful, how do you expect other people to?"  We need to look beyond the exterior and see the beauty within ourselves as well as 
others.

"Women watch a 15-minute show featuring elite entertainers and, in some cases, end up feeling bad about ourselves."

"Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter."

The reason:  Intra-female competition to select is more intense than intra-male competition to be selected.
Thank you! As a 50-something man who never forgoes a nacho chip, I have seldom laughed - and learned - as much.
I love this! Since I am 4 years past JLo's age, I can look back fondly to when I, uh, never looked like that. Oh well!

The performance was a brilliant celebration of cultural diversity, with clear messages about the state of this nation. Two women who have chosen an arduous, athletic profession showed us how very skilled they are at what they do. To fixate on the condition of their bodies is to disregard their artistry, their voices, their willingness to work so hard to entertain us without sacrificing their ideals. In honoring their Latina and Lebanese roots they challenged the notion that Caucasian Puritan values define us. White people are learning what its like to be a minority, and it's about time.

I was pretty envious of the physiques of the final-four men in the Australian Open. At age 59, I'll never approach their level of fitness but I'm going to do my best. It's all anyone can strive to do. Don't beat yourself up.
