I don't begrudge anyone, male or female, their success in remaining youthful, fit and attractive.  More power to them.  I've always striven to do so myself, with fairly good result, but nothing compared to Lopez.  I know what is possible but I also accept what is realistic for me given the fact that I have a full-time job that is in no way dependent on my appearance, and competing financial priorities.  I have paid for cosmetic procedures.  One of them, a breast reduction, made me more physically comfortable and allowed me to buy clothes that I didn't need to have alerted to fit.  My goal was to look proportional, not win a pole dancing contest.  I'm now in my late 50s, and I'm okay with that.  I don't need to compete for Hot Chick designation with my 20something nieces.  As lovely as they are, all have more on the ball than I did at that age. My hope for them is that can enjoy the perks of youth without fear and dread of it yielding to the normal changes that come with age.  Time needn't be "a cruel mistress".

If I was “supposed” to look like J Lo I’d for sure have more money and time!  No really good plastic surgeons are in my budget and I know that I should be using that used rowing machine.  But j lo has a whole lot more than face cream from the dollar store and a fifteen year old rowing machine!

So. Ami I supposed to look like that at 50.  I guess not! 

I choose instead to be grateful that I am as healthy as I am. (And I spent 3 hours yesterday with my neurologist, so I know of what I speak I do not take my health for granted!) 

I have fun getting dressed every morning, sometimes wondering if I’m too old for what I’m wearing (it’s usually too late to change. Gotta get to work.) I wonder what color lipstick is best with the aging face. 

And. I can get up and dance! I’m pretty sure I’m supposed to do that!!

If I had a nickel for every guy who pointed to a woman who hasn't had work done and said how terribly she has aged, it would pay for the plastic surgery that keeps celebrities looking impossibly and improbably youthful. Not having work done now equates to aging badly. It's not a level playing field, people.

Boy, life must be hard when you take someone who you don't even know's body as a personal affront to you. She's been a dancer all her life, and she has the wealth and the resources to stay in the kind of shape that I assure you requires at least three or four hours in the gym every day. I mean, life is full of tough choices. Aren't there things you'd prefer to be doing with that time?
As a guy who reaches for the nachos bowl, I salute you and this article (and J. Lo).

No!  The woman on the stage has had the benefit of good genes and talent and re-investment.
Those attributes and practices have bought and paid for all of the looks money can buy.
In some ways she is more a business than a person at this point and she reinvests time and money in her looks and upkeep.
Ordinary people have to work and take care of themselves while celebs are taken care of as a matter of profit.
It is fruitless to compare oneself with celebs.
Lopez would probably tell yoy herself to be who you are.

Please remember: people in Lopez' profession spend all of their time and a lot of their money on whatever wardrobe, dieticians, trainers, surgeons, stylists and photographers are necessary to look a certain way. That's their currency. Without it there are no sales, no half-time shows, no press. No income. It's not content-driven, but appearance driven.

People who are not pop entertainers have no need to look like they are. But due to America's obsession with superficial entertainment and the "everybody's a star" mentality that commercialism imposes on us, Ms. Weiner and countless others suffer from what this article describes, a self-image problem. 

It's really a shame, that.
Multiple belly laughs: first for the evolution line then for the nachos. Thanks!

Keeping fit, exercising, eating healthy, having a trainer and stylist are part of J Lo's job, her brand. Just as I go to work and write, program or design; J Lo goes to work dances, trains, sings, and collaborates with other professionals. Do men feel insecure about their bodies when they see the football players on the field or do they recognize and appreciate the hard work, skill, and training that went into creating the player's physiques?

J. Lo stays in this kind of shape because it's required for her job.  Unlike their male counterparts, most female celebrities don't have the luxury of looking their chronological age if they want to keep working past 50.  Far less pressure on their male counterparts, who are routinely paired with much younger leading ladies. De Niro, Pacino, et. al. don't have to look good in form-fitting outfits to keep getting roles in their latter years.  Hollywood is still an unforgiving place for women.

Football players aren't single digit body fat. On the contrary.

It's not hard to thirty when you're fifty.  Or sixty.  All you have to do is exercise three times a week and watch what you eat. Most people don't want to do that.

Significantly, men don't do this to themselves.  Men aren't saying, "does Brad Pitt looking like he does make me feel pressure to look like he does at the same age"?   I've never had a body like Jennifer Lopez, at any age or stage, and that's okay.   For people like me, there's law school.  It's all good.  Let's just be who we are and be okay with it.  Let's be more like men in that regard.

Just the title of this reminds me of every obnoxious comment that Matt Lauer made to women who looked good, in his opinion, after they had had children. As if they cannot,  are not supposed to, First, J Lo has had exceptional beauty all her life. She was gifted with a beautiful body. She’s athletic, takes good care of herself and she

has access to every cosmetic procedure available, provided by the best doctors, anywhere.

I don’t compare myself to supermodels. 

I have never had any work done and it’s hard to be held to a beauty standard based on looking like I haven’t had fillers, laser fat removal, my neck lifted, little tucks here and there, a myriad of skin peels, lasers, lasers, and more lasers.....access to nannies, personal trainers, lots of time to work out. As a dancer, working out, is her life....

........

This perspective is lamentable.  First, there is something unhealthy about thinking that someone else's appearance is a standard for judging one's own.  Second, there is something immature about being uncomfortable about no longer being what you were (or imagine yourself to have been) decades earlier.

Even more lamentable is the sense of personal unworthiness and the inability to accept oneself in the ordinary transitions in life.  I am not the "stud" who I was 60 years ago, but I am content to be who I am at 80.  It helps not to worship youth if only because it is transitory--or should be if one wishes to evolve into adulthood.
I really needed this today!!!  Totally hilarious and accurate.... pass the nachos!

Ha! Yes, why do we allow people whose entire career depends on looking great make us feel bad about ourselves?  I mean if we let it bother us that others are better at certain things than we are what is even the point of trying for our own standard of excellence?  If you didn't look as good as her at 20, 30 or 40 why on earth would you look as good as she does at 50?  Completely unrealistic expectations.

I wish all women looked as good as J Lo has for her entire life. Use that exercise equipment for something more than a clothing rack. Eat sensible meals. Walk, run, climb stairs. And some of those skin care products really work.

We live in a culture now controlled by people under 30 at all the social media portals, and now everybody is to be judged by the standards of youth, it's a progression of fear and anxiety that marginalizes age that has been going on since the 1950's. Our form of rapacious capitalism commodifies everything including the human body and this is the result. J Lo's one and only job is to spend all her waking hours looking "good" and she has the resources to make it happen.

I'm a 60 year old male who has convinced himself that he's held up well . . . a mostly full head of hair, a chest that is still greater in circumference than the waist . . . but after watching the acrobatics(and just the acrobatics) of these "seasoned" women, I found myself in the drop the nachos, pick up the weights camp. Its not just a girl thing.

It's sad, really, that in 2020, no matter how smart you are, or how talented, the highest praise you can receive as a woman is, "You look amazing for 50." What's even sadder is that even women as accomplished as JLo covet and seek that praise. We haven't come a long way, baby. We're still right where (some) men always wanted us to be.
Looking good is literally her job, and she has all day and all the money in the world to get it done.

And so Jane Fonda does that to me, but I remind myself ( somewhat snarkily) that some of that is what money CAN buy.

Tina Turner was both hot and indefatigable when she did her last tour at age  69.  

 Let's be honest: they looked better than most of us at 25 and 30 , etc.  And they have a lot of talent, and work at honing it.  

what I like: they ARE models for unapologetic comfort with your female body at any age.

As a 50-something woman, I know there's a broad range in our body types.  There's also a broad range of opinions around hair-dying, body sculpting, clothing etc.  Let J Lo be J Lo.

But I am creeped out for J Lo's kids, especially her 11 year old daughter who performed with her.  That girl goes to a Catholic school.  How is Emme supposed to make sense of her mother's 4th marriage (5th engagement) and You_tubed   lap dance with A Rod.  Ewww.

Shakira and J-Lo put on a hugely entertaining half time show.  I did not for one second feel bad about myself, because I will never look like that, or sing and dance with the same skill and energy.  It was enough to see them both beautifully pull it off.  Too bad we had to read to the utter end of this piece to get a clue you might feel the same way.  If you feel judged by J-Lo's 50-year old body in a Super Bowl half time show, maybe you need to widen your circle of friends.  Superstars!

You only need to look like JLo if you buy into the media myth.  JLo is talented and hard working entertainer, devoted to having a beautiful body. More power to her.  But that's her, not you.

The fact that you feel inferior to her is a victory for the perverted myth makers.

Many of us have rich lives full of love, even though we might be wrinkled and flabby. And we choose not to compete in a game that has no winners, turning our attention to a more sustaining reality.

Maturing means looking inward to your own core and finding your unwavering center.  That is true power.

I agree with Jennifer, men do have a better grip on reality.  We realize we can't all be Brad Pit or Patrick Mahomes, so we just accept it on move on.  We also have a better grounded set of priorities: forget the unattainable and focus on the attainable - Nachos and beer and fantasy football.

P.S. I did not vote for Donal Trump

P.P.S.  Remember, 50 is the new 35.

While this is not in the least bit silly, it is pathetic because of all the angst being expressed by women. Jennifer Lopez is a professional performer and makes a living based on her ability to perform; therefore, anything less than peak operating efficiency is unacceptable. Her full time job is to do what she does to perform which means an entire support group. We don't get to see the all the trainers and facilities she must use to do what she does. All we see is the end product and marvel. If we all put in that much time and money into performing we would all look that young and vibrant. Alas, the other 99 percent live in a different, bereft environment. Seeing what it could be like is a great fantasy which is what J Lo is selling, which is what we want to imagine for ourselves, and which is what we don't have the time or wherewithal for.

I love this column. As a man, and probably clueless in many ways, there's so much I don't understand about how women now view their own bodies. I feel enlightened by your sentence: "Whether women singing and dancing in barely-there costumes or otherwise celebrating their bodies is empowering, or an assault on our ability to move through the world as men’s equals, is one of those forever fights . . ." And thank you for the bittersweet meditations on aging.

Ah come on! 
 So she’s fifty and she looks fantastic. 
It’s her job to look fantastic, her appearance along with her talent, is her wealth. 
 I’m sure she works very hard to look that good and if any of us were in showbiz we would too. It’s ridiculous to compare or even feel threatened. 
 I’m fifty and while I don’t look JLO good I’m pretty happy with the way I look. 
 I suspect as well JLO and stars like her would not mind the anonymity and quiet life I enjoy!
What ever happened to the idea of inner beauty?

Uh, Ms. Weiner, 50 is nothing--try 60!  Now, there's the fun.  Part of a celebrity's job is to spend massive amounts of time, money, and effort to look fabulous, but then you have actresses like Glenn Close, Helen Mirren, and Jamie Lee Curtis, women who seem to be aging gracefully and who are comfortable in their own skin.  Personally, as  my mother used to say, if you have your health, you have everything--the rest is icing on the cake, no matter how you decorate it.

Hey, can't you look at her and get motivation. Sure, this is her job to be in shape but it's not an inhuman goal. Body types aside, it's nice to know that a person can be in that kind of shape at 50. Good for her.

Sadly, the "male gaze" is not something that will be easy to adjust.  That part of the brain is a lot older than the cerebral cortex; it's part of what we feel, not what we think.Just as the wiring that makes men check out women for mating suitability is buried deep, so is the wiring that makes women want to be attractive to the best mates available.  

We may be able to transform our society and culture to be enlightened and egalitarian in many ways, but our bodies and our sexual urges will remain the same.  We will continue to feel that we have lost something when we become sexually irrelevant, so we will continue to put a lot of effort and money into putting that day off.  Men will continue to try to have sex with fertile young women, and women will continue to try to look fertile and young.  It's who we are.

What we saw is not the body of a 50 year old woman. It’s a perfectly manufactured, detailed product that happens to belong to a 50 year old celebrity who would not be on that stage otherwise. Interesting how men with their beer bellies don’t look at athletes and expect to look ripped. They understand it’s part of the business.

Didn't someone just write an op-ed in this same publication about the rising number of women in prime age range who are shattering their marathon trial times and positively reinventing themselves in healthy and happy ways? Let's not dwell on the fact that we aren't JLo and instead find inspiration in what drives our passions and shows our children that we weren't languishing in the shadow of a diva's curves.
I felt the same way when I saw Brad Pitt in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood."

It's all a matter of what one values. Character, integrity, hard and meaningful work, wisdom, thoughtfulness, service, concern for the common good? Or fame, beauty, narcissism, wealth, loud obnoxiousness, celebrity, mindless entertainment, instant gratification, and fake inauthenticity? Make your own judgements on where we stand in today's society. Though remember - it is not about what one says, it is about what one does. I didn't care to watch the Super Bowl. There are so many better ways to spend 4 hours of my finite lifetime.

Don't be silly. Ms Lopez is a dancer. She lives a lifestyle that most women do not have access to. She can afford the best personal trainers for her workouts, etc. She does look wonderful and it reflects what her hard work has brought. We cannot measure ourselves against her.

If you: 
1) used to be a professional dancer, so already had a strong body
2) had a personal trainer that worked you out in a controlled environment for probably 8 hours a day (hey, it's your JOB to look like this!)
3) had a personal chef to cook food perfect for your particular metabolism
4) had a PA/minder that didn't let you "cheat" on your strict diet, etc.
5) and wore a compression body suit whenever you performed in public...

... you wouldn't have anything to worry about!

Why, oh why do woman still compare themselves to celebrities in 2020?  Years and years of the media telling us who is attractive and women still buy into it.  It's really a question of self-esteem and there are tried and true methods of improving your self-esteem that include being mindful, exercising, helping others, etc.  I know because I struggled with self-esteem issues and believe me, when you stop comparing yourself and start liking yourself, what a wonderful world you will find yourself in.

At 50, sure. The question is, at 60. and the answer is still, sure.

With all the data we now have about what we should eat and how we should exercice, there is no reason why we shouldn't look great at 60 and over. And it is never too late.
Most of us didn't look that good at 20, so why is this provoking an existential crisis now?

Great piece! It's true that men don't feel body-shamed by football players. However, some of the more delusional ones think that they could either 1) play in the NFL, or 2) coach in the NFL. Lots of armchair quarterbacks out there!

Hey Gen Xers, better take a deep breath and just relax. It does get better if you accept the fact that you can't hold back aging. Your body will change. I repeat your body will change. No matter how much you exercise and do everything humanly possible. I am 81 and I don't look like Jane Fonda. Try enjoying your life, your children and others. Greet each day with gratitude. You are way more than your body.
Women can opt out of this.  Ditch the makeup and skin cream.  Watching commercials one realizes very little progress has been made since the 1950s.
Jennifer Weiner, I'll dance with you! You are amazing. Loved this piece.

I loved the half time show and wonder why there is so much controversy.  From comments about it being "trashy" and not suitable for a family audience to JLo's body. Please stop - No we all need not look so good at 50 but we need to be healthy and fit as possible.  I don't think I could do the move she did up that pole even when I was in my 20's and I never wanted to.  But I do want to be fit and healthy as I get older and look good, and not to be compared to anyone else but me.

The half time show was great,  wonderful entertainment for all, and a celebration of Latino culture. Can't we just enjoy things and not always be so judgmental and critical.

It's obvious that many of you either: didn't read before commenting or didn't comprehend what you read.

The last paragraph sums it up

" if you want to be J. Lo, more power to you. If you want to be Blanche, be Blanche. But if it’s always been about Bea Arthur, come sit back here, with me, in your Eileen Fisher tunic and the newish bifocals you haven’t quite mastered. We’ll wait ’til the crowd goes home, and we’ll dance like nobody’s watching."

Be what makes you happy!

I don't feel at all judged by another man's body, let's say Brad Pitt's, who, one year older than me, at 57 looks just as swell, as J Lo at 50. It's his body. Him taking his shirt off does not bother, offend or denigrate me in any way. I think women have a lot to learn from men on that art of zen. "Men, meanwhile, watch a three-hour game, played by elite athletes with single-digit body fat, and most won’t feel a single twinge of self-doubt, or miss a single chip from the nacho platter." Exactly. Who cares.

As a retired psychologist I just want to point something out here. We feel according to how we think. Cognition and emotion go together. No one is making anyone feel anything. If you saw that (ridiculous) show and feel bad about your body, you are doing it to yourself. No one has to look like those women to be ok. Accept yourselves for what is really important, who you are as a person.

"The answer, I think, is to watch these types of performances like a man."

Really? I would suggest women stop being so insecure about themselves if this is all it takes for you to go through a personal emotional crisis. Maybe if you could separate your physical attractiveness from your own sense of self-worth, you would be happier.
Nobody is supposed to look like anybody, period. We are who we are. Looks is only one part of it. Women are so focused on their bodies that they stop evolving in other ways.

At 50 you are just coming into your own. You know that you know that you know, finally, but then you realize everybody else believes that you are washed up, that you are a "senior citizen." 

I blame the AARP. They have been lumping 50 year olds in with senior citizens for  years now in order to sell insurance (The Hartford). Now everybody has caught on. I can go see a $4 movie right now if I want to at the age of 55.

 i grew up knowing that a senior citizen is 65 years old, but once I got to 50 I had suddenly lost 15 years of freedom from age discrimination. Thanks to the propaganda of the AARP,  our ability to get work, and even be considered beautiful, has been made exponentially more difficult.

This is with regards to Jennifer Weiner’s article on the Super Bowl half time show and JLo in particular!
I just wanted to say, she certainly nailed it.  As a white haired 62 year old, I always marvel at women who look stunning no matter how old they are! Why 50? Even at 40 some do look their age, and some at 70 don’t!
And also, Ms. Weiner brought back some of the opinions I so looked forward to from Erma Bombeck! Gave me reason to chuckle!
If Ms. Lopez can look so stunning, at 50 as they keep drumming - power to her!
Sita Avasarala

Celebrity envy is nothing new.  People have marveled over Tina Turner's fitness for decades.  These people are active and take very good care of themselves.  Their careers demand it.

Meanwhile, middle-aged men wish their midriffs looked like Tom Brady's.  But they don't feel judged.
Hilarious, as usual; and thank you!

Let's be honest, the author and most of her readers have never looked remotely as good as J Lo a day in their lives. 

That's not an insult, because it's J Lo's job to be gorgeous. The rest of us are writers, librarians, programmers, doctors, whatever. Be good at that, and we can all stay in our lane.

J-Lo a threat to middle-aged women's peace of mind?  Well, Americans of both sexes are fat on average.  Maybe there is some instinctive response at play here - fat doesn't seem good for the body, mind or soul.  The piece reflects a strangely defensive nature within our society towards being fat - Don't tell me I'm fat, I'm just being me, so back off!  It hardly seems possible everyone should walk around ripped like Tom Brady or J-Lo.  But instead of getting defensive and protecting our right to balloon at the waist, maybe we might ask ourselves if we would feel better in general if we kept our bodies in at least a mildly decent shape.  Leave that last nacho on the plate!

RE: chin whiskers 

I believe that there is no greater love for another woman, be she a relative, a friend or a stranger, than to say...hey, there's a chin whisker. Let me get that for you. (I carry one mainly for my MIL, who looks like a Snow White dwarf if I don't tend).

We all know we can't see them, our partners aren't great at finding them and poking about with tweezers is not comfortable.

Anyone who is healthy and wants to look good at an older age needs to eat less and exercise more. The math is simple. If you've made this a habit for most of your life, all the better. Why be envious and angry. You don't have to afford liposuction - in clothing you can look great. It IS possible. Most women just give up at a certain point.
The addition of little kids to the strip joint celebration was not a great look for me. And please stop calling this music, Vegas has clearly won the culture war.

I was appalled by the show. I am embarrassed by their highly sexualized dancing. Not family friendly. Wow how far from the 1960’s equal rights for women movement we have fallen. Women are better than this.

J.Lo's job is entertainer. She spends her time getting ready for performances. She practices her music and dance routines so she will give a perfect performance. She also exercises and follows a diet appropriate for her. That is her full time job. When she dresses for a performance she has experts helping her to present herself the way she wants us to see her. 

If history is any indication, many formerly slim and "beautiful" actresses did not age well. Some of them went from thin to obese when it was no longer their job to be thin and beautiful. Stop being envious. Stop comparing yourself to an entertainer. You and she have different jobs, different body types and different ideas of what is important. She is paid to put on a great performance, you are not.
The Gen-Xers have J Lo.  My Boomers have Tina Turner and Jane Fonda.  There's always a bar to cross.

Being fit, strong and of a healthy weight in your fifties means you won’t need a walker in your seventies. Or, for that matter, in your eighties. You’ll be able to get arrested trying to save the planet. Hello, Jane. Looking good and still fighting the good fight.
Thank you for this.  So well said.  When will we learn to stop buying into the misogynistic notion that our sexual appeal = our worth as human beings??
Eileen Fisher tunic?  You have to be built like a stick to make her clothes look good.  Maybe super tall Bea Arthur could pull it off, but not most women.

I resent the male and female stereotypes used in this article.  There are plenty of men who work hard on their bodies and their appearance and wish they looked like they did when they were younger, and there are plenty of women who are not working hard to preserve a younger image of themselves.  A better op ed might have examined the ridiculous extravagance and fakery of the performances.

How come you don't feel this way when you learn that a woman your age just got elected to the National Academy of Sciences for pioneering work in molecular biology?  You and your friends need a serious reset.

Pish posh. Have you seen Brad Pitt on the roof in the film Once Upon a Time on Hollywood? Do you think ordinary men in ordinary jobs with ordinary bodies feel judged?

I will never look like J.Lo & my life is fine the way it is.
Maybe this column should be re-titled, "This is the Biggest Problem I Have In My Life, I'm Very Very Lucky"

Bottom line don't identity or social engineer obsess.

Treat everybody equally and let them do what they want as long as it is legal and safe. 

The only legit issue is whether this type of show be on the super bowl because it is technically family entertainment.

Well, we could all look like Jennifer Lopez if we had 24-hour access to personal chefs, nutritionists and personal trainers. And plenty of time to work out. I assume she works out a lot more than my 30 minutes at the gym three or four days a week. To say nothing of getting plenty of sleep because someone else is looking after the kids.

Are we supposed to look this good at 50? Sure - if you're rich, have personal trainers, chefs, time to do all of those "healthy" things and not worry about shopping, laundry, getting dinner on the table and the kids out the door, finishing that extra project the boss dumped on you, moving the lawn and all the rest. It applies to men as well as women.

It's fine to admire a 50-year old having a great body, I suppose, for it still does take her work to have it (albeit by removing the drudgery I mentioned above) but we need to stop at assuming its the norm and attainable by everyone while still living a normal life.

Well my first thought upon looking at the picture: " She really is a beauty." and then: " Wow, those compression tights were really well designed." She is a professional in a job where you have to look good and I'm sure it is a lot of work. And dancers don't let their physiques deteriorate because they are also athletes.
For those of us who are way past 50 this discussion is just fluff. As others have commented we have the contemporary politics, the possible pandemic, the world burning up, refugees surging at borders and drowning in oceans and small children in cages for more than a year to worry about. And add your own concerns. 
Even J Lo will probably grow older and have arthritis and thinning hair and some lines. Until then it is fine for her to celebrate her beauty and entertain millions.
The rest of us will have to age gracefully a bit sooner. I am glad that I had my babies when one could still wear diaphanous cotton.  I'm a teacher though and see high school girls made miserable and anxious by the emphasis on the " smoking hot female body " in those kinds of outfits. When we hope they can be thinking about achieving some kind of balance in achievement, hard work, healthy habits and supportive relationships they are real focused on the glitz, glamour, and attaining that kind of look. That worries me much more than how it makes women over 50 feel. Because we are old enough to have some perspective.
Many women all over the world feel and look healthy, strong, and sexy at age 50, 60, 70. The author can too. Maybe find an encouraging community!

I enjoy Jennifer Weiner's writing and have read all of her books.  But while she writes interestingly of female experience, she consistently portrays men as cardboard cut-outs.  When she says "men" she actually means "straight men." As a gay man, I can assure her that loads of men have the same body dysmorphia, a combination of pursuing the Apollonian ideal with conforming to a consumer culture where youth always wins.  That's okay, though, we're used to being afterthoughts.

As a grown adult YOU have to posses the sense of self that makes you not revolt when you see a well-maintained and and genetically more rare body as that of Jennifer Lopez. Twenty years ago during the failed Clinton-era peace effort I took the time to find & read the 1947 UN Partition Plan. I was stunned by the authors' vision of regional cooperation on economic development and infrastructure. IIRC, water-resource management was paramount, as was expanding a trans-national regional railway network. Sure, the proposed boundaries of Israel were unrealistic and militarily indefensible. Sure, no one was willing to accept a United Jerusalem as an International Open City. Sure, the 22 members of the Arab League were not going to accept Jewish sovereignty over even one square-inch of Mandate Palestine. Today, the only thing more stunning that the visionary nature of the Partition Plan is the myopia of too many people today. I count among my friends & acquaintances many who are ardently pro-Israel. But _none_ has ever read the 1947 UN Partition Plan.

This is one of Friedman's more perceptive analytical pieces. It serves to highlight how climate change denial has grown from being a mere political stance to an all-engulfing cultural miasma. This fog engulfs us all to some degree. Our media politics has become largely an unconscious exercise in denial: 

"Regrettably, we simply won't have time to think seriously about climate change until after Trump is expelled from office. It is our present civic duty to watch the impeachment hearings from beginning to end, even though the predetermined outcome was long ago announced."

Identifying gang members is a sound priority for almost any police force.  This article hones in an insidious related practice--purposefully fraudulent identifications. 

There is next to no evidence here of purposeful misconduct.  Instead, we are asked to infer that street cops who make wrong gang determinations do so purposefully. On that subject, there is plenty of innuendo but next to no facts.

To prove the point, the writer needs to demonstrate a motive for pervasive police wrongdoing.   Presumably, the  motive arises from incentives and rewards for bad identifications by the police.  Surely, we're talking about quotas for arrests that enhance an officer's standing.  So the claim is that the police force is rewarding false arrests of non-gang graffiti artists and those who are undocumented.  

To believe this claim, you have to believe that this is a widespread and intentional practice--that police officers are sufficiently rewarded for false arrests to break the law day in and day out.   If that is true, the police are corrupt through and through, of course.

We should track certain categories of behavior closely associated with criminal behavior. Sexual predators, domestic violence, child abuse and so on. One giant gaping hole in data collection is gun ownership and gun violence but that's a conversation for another time.

The problem of course with gang membership or any other category is always two-fold though. 1) Accountability. 2) Incentives. Wherever you find an imbalance in the ratio between the two, you'll find abuse of power and injustice.

Police departments tie advancement to criminal convictions. No patrol officer is making captain holding a stop sign at the crosswalk. You need collars in order to advance. The more serious, the better. There's your incentive.

You combine that with low accountability. The police officer recording the chit, although legally liable for accurate information, is:1) Not regularly scrutinized. 2) Regularly assumed to have good character. And 3) Supported by other motivated officers engaged in similar illegal behavior.

Anytime we suggest greater accountability though, the police inevitably argue they can't have officers looking over their shoulders' for a lawsuit every time they approach a suspect. Hence, the system perpetuates.

What we need then is a change in incentives. We're tracking the wrong metric. We should reward officers for the absence of crime, not the presence of crime. Find the balance between the two and you'll find a solution.

The silver lining I see, however, is that it may finally lead to some real reforms in our severely antiquated voting and election systems.  First past the post voting is a relic of the past that should have no place in a 21st century democracy.  Once the center-left and center-right voters in this country--who, despite trends in both parties, comprise the majority of voters--feel like they have noone squarely representing them, maybe then we will see some change.  This should have been done decades ago, but when the two parties put forth candidates that are 90% the same and there was still a level of bipartisanship, the need did not seem so great. First off, there is a limit to the Sanders movement.  He splits his base with Warren and if you add the together, you hit a ceiling of about 45%.  The rest of the base is much more centrist and yes, that vote, at least in Iowa is mostly split between Buttigieg, Biden and Klobuchar. If Warren further dips, Sanders will likely rise. The same is true for the centrists who will face a formidable challenge from Bloomberg. But the numbers do not in fact bode well enough for Sanders.

Second, the Iowa Caucuses are not an ideal barometer of how most registered Democrats lean. It is a voting system in which you must show up to participate and I imagine that the low turnout favors the evangelized supporter's choice. I doubt that Sanders or Buttigieg are more favored than Biden. Further primaries will most likely prove me right.

They were monitoring 70% of the state's caucuses (some 1100 precincts) while Sander's team was basing their best guess on monitoring results in just about 25% of the precincts.  

This leads me to believe that Sanders is being outwitted by the young rabble-rouser and has yet to come up against a more formidable challenge from the likes of Bloomberg.

Bernie's "strong showing"?

25% of caucus participants
170,000 participants, about 25%  of registered Democrats
640,000 registered D, about 31% of all Iowa registered voters (compared to 33% R, and 35% Independent)
3 million people in Iowa, about 0.9% of the US population.

So Bernie supporters at the Iowa caucuses represent 0.01% of Americans.

We to the left of center like to say that truth doesn't care whether you believe in it; it remains true. The truth is that if a President Bernie Sanders gets his agenda enacted as he envisions it, you will see capitalism snap back to popularity just as it did last time out in the 1980s, with the attendant backlash and further social damage. This is because capitalism works well at producing wealth, on national and transnational scales. Few facts are by now better or more irrefutably established than this. What is currently derided as the "Democratic establishment," or "center-left" is nothing more than people who recognize this fact.

If your car lists to the right when you let go of the steering wheel, you get an alignment. You don't burn the car and start over. Concentration of wealth is a problem of capitalism run amuck, not its complete refutation. Sanders' ideas are morally beautiful, his ends are just and good ends. His means will not produce the expected results.

If you like the ideas of more equitable distribution of wealth and a government whose goals are at least consonant with social justice, you'd better hope like heck for a Buttigieg or a Klobuchar nomination. 

Because what Sanders will deliver, in the final analysis and when he leaves office, will be repudiation of those ideas.

Consequently, the "nuclear-level ammunition" the centrists are worried about handing to Republicans has fallen below its fissile point, which makes it a dud.

Secondly, don't count out Buttigieg quite yet.  To their credit, African-American voters are not bandwagon jumpers.  They take awhile to get to know a candidate before lending support.  After a strong showing in Iowa, Mayor Pete may deserve a stronger look, in their eyes.

Three thoughts:

Readers often point out that Sanders would not be considered a radical leftist anywhere else in the world. However, the election is not going to be held anywhere else in the world. The yardstick by which the nominees will be measured is the prevailing consciousness among American voters. One can spend the time till November trying to re-educate them, or one can spend it listening to them. They may well confirm that they like any number of progressive policies and yet find Sanders and his Bros too much in their faces.

If young voters who demand Sanders as the nominee don't get him, the upshot may be that traditionally unmotivated young voters turn out to be unmotivated after all. That's roughly a wash. The greater risk is putting off traditionally motivated older (Democratic and independent) voters.

Bernie Sanders speaks of "taking on the entire establishment." That's his mindset in a nutshell, and it goes beyond powerful interests. Bernie's worldview is "me against the rest". The more you learn about him, the more you realize what a porcupine he is. Where other people in public life try to build alliances and cultivate sympathies, Sanders says, in effect, "Don't try agreeing with me. You're part of the problem I'm out to solve." He's even that way with the mainstream news media, which any responsible politician today ought to value as a lifeline of democracy.

If the progressive message is ever to get through, the messenger mustn't be a poison pill.

Sanders and (more importantly) his supporters already represent a precariat of postindustrial, multicultural wage labor, an expanding social category in the US.   Bryan was deeply religious, a Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. ruling elder who prosecuted the case for the state of Tennessee  against Scopes for "teaching evolution" in the Monkey Trial.

A very considerable difference then, between the two cases.   It means the conservative "Gold" Democrats of our own time  won't have it as easy regaining control as they did by the end of the first decade of the 20th century.

Equality in Iowa was having and holding onto a family farm – about the size of your neighbors’ – and passing it down from one generation to the next…

Enter capitalism – in the form of railroads…

Suddenly, transport mattered more than production…

If railroads could now access supply sources that – in aggregate – far exceed average demand…

They can arbitrage that supply and demand, as the suppliers race themselves to the bottom…

Suddenly, like the peasantry in Europe their ancestors sought to escape, they are more indentured than invested, looking to the future…

So, granges came into being…

Sort of like rent-control – except you also live in the one unit you rent out…

Enter more capitalism – in the form of bankers…

If railroads now owned the farms – bankers now owned the railroads…

They could both drive the crop price into the dirt – and then the farmer, through over-borrowing…

Sort of like sub-prime car leasing – except they don’t tow away the farm, they tow away you…

Interesting – that some migrated further west and prospered, though many perished on the voyage…

So, how Iowans vote depends…

On whether they see the inequality and excess and deprivation of 19th century Europe as their past…

Or whether they see the inequality and excess and deprivation of 21st century California as their future…

Brutally cold and cruel – out there in the middle…

Especially since 21st century Europe coming apart at the seams…

Need a new Gold Rush – and stat…

 And also consider what is going to happen with Warren

I don't mind that Bruenig favors Sanders but this piece willfully ignores his many weaknesses.

First, while Sanders did well in Iowa, he is almost 20% behind his 2016 performance.  And he is neck and neck with a 38 year old small town mayor that establishment pundits had written off in the last month or so.  And that's with the Sanders' advantages of having run well here in 2016 and his outspending Buttigieg (and everyone else). Bernie did fine but it's not that impressive.

Second, Bernie is probably the most disliked candidate in the party.  I just spent over a week canvassing in Iowa and he is the only Dem candidate that people say they won't for.

Third, Bruenig claims the left is ascendent but never acknowledges that the way the Dems won back the House in 2018 was not by going the Bernie route. The winners of the swing districts look a lot more like Pete and Amy than they look like Bernie.

Finally, there is an air of unreality about Bruenig's analysis of the race going forward.   Either Pete will catch fire (in which case his current low poll standing is irrelevant) or Joe will rebound or, and I think this most likely, Bloomberg will gain momentum.  Bernie looks good now because the non-left vote is currently splintered but it's unlikely to stay that way.

Um... right now, Buttigieg is winning/has won a state whose demographics greatly favored Sanders. Buttigieg, even if he ends up being a close second, is about as center as it gets. Sanders will do much less well in Nevada and South Carolina and other states whose demographics are closer to the nation's. This piece just reflects the deluded nature of Bernie's followers. Also, is Bruenig a journalist or a paid political operative? The one thing readers can be certain about is that she would never criticize Bernie under any circumstances. She apparently thinks he is a perfect, flawless human being -- which makes her writing seem more like fan fiction than political analysis.

ever acknowledges that the way the Dems won back the House in 2018 was not by going the Bernie route. The winners of the swing districts look a lot more like Pete and Amy than they look like Bernie.

Finally, there is an air of unreality about Bruenig's analysis of the race going forward.   Either Pete will catch fire (in which case his current low poll standing is irrelevant) or Joe  will rebound or, and I think this most likely, Bloomberg will gain momentum.  Bernie looks good now because the non-left vote is currently splintered but it's unlikely to stay that way.

Seems a long shot, but Trump has not delivered on his promises of bringing back manufacturing, or even bringing China to heel.  Also, the pundits keep saying that Trump will win unless the economy collapses, so there seems little point in nominating a centrist.  As a progressive, I would rather have someone I want as the nominee, just in case the economy does collapse.

To defeat POTUS—AND keep the House and take the Senate—we need a Grand Coalition from center-Right to Left. 

A candidate who refuse to compromise, backed by supporters who refuse to compromise, it seems to me, is the wrong candidate for this particular, specific, highly-fraught moment. 

So, yes, the thought of Trump re-elected, keeping the Senate in Mitch McConnell's hands, and possibly with a GOP House majority, would send many people panicking. 

And for those who think that's hyperbole, I would observe that the country overall is more conservative than it's been before, and even in a more liberal clime, George McGovern, Walter Mondale, and Michael Dukakis all lost in landslides. 

And Santayana's cliché is true: Those who cannot learn from history are doomed to repeat it.

Can't we a least hold off until the South Carolina primary before declaring the center-left wing of the Democratic Party has been defeated by the progressive wing. It hardly seems likely that the partial results from Iowa can be interpreted as the center-left wing of the party having gone down to defeat. Sanders is going to do well in any state without a large metropolitan area or large black population because the base of the center-left consists mainly of people of color and white professionals. Sanders hung in there in 2016 by mainly winning states without large metropolitan areas and without large black populations but that wasn't nearly enough to defeat Hillary Clinton. So I think the center-left is still alive and well and likely to have the winning candidate.
No center in American political life means that we spiral downwards into third world status.  We are already well on our way.  We truly need sensible government, not a revolution.

Trump won't even have to attack Bernie directly. He can focus on the 50 or so Democrats who represented swing districts and force them to say No, they aren't going to support the Democrat nominee's plans if elected.

Are Orange County Democrats going to be promising tens of trillions of dollars of new spending and eliminating private healthcare? Are Pennsylvania Democrats going to get onboard with banning fracking, and the Philly suburbs onboard with the tens of thousands of dollars of new taxes Sanders' plans will see them pay? Is any voter who even dreams of retirement in a decade or two willing to risk it all on Socialism?

The GOP will hone in on these voters, and the Democrats will split down the middle. But don't worry, Democrats will still win AOC's seat by a wide margin.

Good piece, but even more than that, striking for how much more thoughtful and well-written it is than the average opinion article, where the chain of thought (recently, usually something about how Sanders is going to lose) seems to be based on thin air and assumptions.

Bernie’s supporters are dedicated to him for sure.
BUT Bernie has a hard ceiling and in an election against trump, not only will he be crushed, but neither will get as many votes as Hillary did in 2016.

They failed to prosecute the wrong doers of the financial crisis; they let the banks off the hook. Early on during the 2016 election run-up, before I'd started to pay much attention to it all (at a point at which it had never entered my mind that Trump could possibly become president--the good old days), I happened to watch over my mom's shoulder as she watched Debbie Wasserman Schultz being interviewed on one of the news shows. I remember thinking, "Wow--she's so openly contemptuous of Sanders--is the head of the DNC supposed to be so transparently biased at this stage of the game?"
So of course I went on to look more closely at Senator Sanders, and found a great deal to admire. I'd found my candidate. And I, like so many others, became enraged at the DNC's blatant favoritism.
And here we go again. Yes, I am without doubt an (almost) anyone-but-Trump voter this time around, but this piece just reminded me that I should make a contribution to Sanders' campaign. (As I said in another comment on a different article, the mere fact that he was and is the only candidate who doesn't feel that he needs to drink the Netanyahu Kool-Aid just to stay in the running makes me respect him all the more. And, as I also mentioned in that comment, the fact that he is Jewish kind of negates the whole "anti-semitic" argument that some might try to toss my way.)
I am, by the way, a 58-year-old woman, so I don't think I can be accused of being a "Bernie bro" either.
It would just be nice to have someone for whom I have real respect as president again. That someone is Bernie Sanders.

If there is one thing Republican voters hate, it is government, and Bernie's plans are to drastically expand the role of government.  Bernie as the nominee will result in an all-time voter turnout record for the GOP.

I'll vote for the Democratic nominee, whoever it is. But it's delusional to think Sanders would win a general election. Once you get outside the progressive social media bubble, you run into a lot of people who would love to vote for the Democrat, and they're fine with Warren, prefer Klobuchar or Buttigieg, but Sanders would be a dealbreaker for them. He might pile up votes in safe Democratic cities, but that's not where the election will be won or lost.

Here’s the real challenge for centrists: politics as usual have left too many Americans behind. The center needs to develop genuine solutions to poverty and its attendant disorders— but to people used to ineffective gestures, real solutions sound radical.

"Establishment attacks on Sanders — especially if effective — could result in Mr. Sanders’ base simply staying home in the general election." This statement by the author has to interpreted in terms  of  the counterpoint 'How many centrists, independents and moderate, anti-Trump Republicans will likewise stay home'. The latter group is definitely a larger subsection of the American electorate. Iowa id definitely a more realistic cross section of the heartland sentiment, which needs to be won over by the Democrats for an electoral college victory.

Furthermore, I don't see a large rising victory for the left wing of the Democratic party in the Iowa results thus far. Warren and especially Sanders are long term visible  and experienced campaigners and should have steamrolled over that upstart Buttigieg, a total unknown less than a year ago, yet who is slightly ahead of both in the Iowa caucus. Their failure to beat him handily is not lost on the rest of the Democratic voters. I wouldn't yet count out the more centrist candidates of the party.

Iowa is basically meaningless; read into it what you want - but it looks like the prime establishment candidate is trailing three who are not.

Where we go from here will be interesting. I am curious to see if the mainstream press continues to marginalize Warren at every opportunity. She continues to be viable.

Of the candidates that have appeared in the debates so far, Bernie Sanders delivers the best stump speech.

But the devil is in the details.  I don't know enough about his positions to know whether to prefer Sanders to say Bloomberg.

There are parts of the Sanders positions which seem not so clearly thought through.  In particular, the wealth tax seems a bit extreme.  Sanders suggested a rate of about 8%, which would confiscate the wealth of billionaires over time.  There is a possible problem with constitutionality, and it might be difficult to get such a tax passed in Congress, but the real question is whether it is a good idea.

Sanders wants to use the health tax to fund universal health care.  But you can't just cash in the stocks of billionaires and immediately provide health care to more people.  You need a plan which includes the training of new doctors to provide the health care and that takes time.  It seems to me that we do need a crash program to train more doctors, but even if that is done, it will take a decade for the new doctors to go through the university and medical school, and complete a residency.

These parts of the plan have not been discussed.

There are further missing details in many of the issues confronting Democratic candidates.  I am disappointed that the debates so far focus on applause lines with few details on how to achieve the major changes needed to improve society.

I hope debates between Sanders and Bloomberg will provide the details.

Wow, how great to finally have an article that seems at least to give Bernie some credit and begin to be critical of the Democratic establishment, instead of the largest grass roots donation campaign in US history.  And coming from The Times!

Interesting situation: Bernie may be the single most popular candidate in the field, but across all the primaries and caucuses, he is unlikely to translate that into consistent first-place, albeit plurality finishes.  That makes him the leader going into the convention, but not the presumptive nominee, especially if his second-and-less showings are in swing states (50 minus states that have gone consistently Republican or Democratic since 2000); such a position would suggest to me that he would lose more than his share of them to Trump and so the general.  And if 53% of the single most popular candidate's backers sit out the general if he is not the nominee (because of the need for a better bet for the swing states), those states will swing behind Trump due to lower Democratic turnout.  Heck, in that situation, Trump might even win the popular vote.

When we're no longer looking at national polls (frankly, anyone who does still doesn't understand what happened in 2000 or 2016 [and those who fail at history, well, you know] is an amateur) but polls in swing states ONLY, then we will get an idea who will be taking the oath next January.

Understandably, most of us feel let down by both political parties, burned by income inequality, terrified by the climate emergency, and dismayed by the growing divisions in our country.  It is all very disconcerting. 

That is why this is the worst time to choose to play tug of war with our beloved country, by replacing one extremist president with another.  The extreme right pulling on one side, the extreme left pulling on the other.  Eventually the rope will give, and so will our country.  

The extreme right also felt ignored and taken for granted by establishment or moderate Republicans, so they chose an extremist outsider for some "real change".   

We must not allow extremist voices from either side to drown out voices of reason.   Extremism is a simple solution to complex problems.  Extremism won't solve anything.  Extremism on either side will permanently rip our beloved Nation apart.

"Bernie Sanders’s strong showing in Iowa is a turning point in the battle between the party’s establishment and left wing."

Iowa is small and unrepresentative, and its caucuses are relatively undemocratic. In 2016 Sanders got 49.6% of the vote in a race with two candidates. This year in a race with significantly more candidates he presently has only 25%. His second round gains most likely came from Yang, who shares the Sanders demographics, but half of Yang's votes went to Warren or Buttigieg, and Biden's and Klobuchar's lost votes also went to Warren or Buttigieg. This demographics of Iowa and the caucus format both disproportionately benefit a candidate like Sanders. This isn't a turning of the corner for Sanders and his movement. He had to do this well in Iowa because, let me tell you, the vast majority of the other states will not be biased in his favor like Iowa is.

Buttigieg, smart and charismatic, seems to be willing to appeal to any demographic who will get him poll numbers or votes. More than any other consideration, he is too inexperienced to take control of a dysfunctional federal government. You cannot go from a mediocre performance as mayor in a town of 60,000 to the US Presidency. I am amazed at his standing although he seems to appeal to older, white, moderate voters and that is the majority demographic of Iowa voters. Bloomberg, Biden, and Bernie are pushing 80. Warren and Klobuchar are younger, experienced, with solid records of government success and a track record of winning elections. I am dumbfounded.
Nice to see that we can count on Ms Bruenig to tell us the truth: Bernie is winning the popular vote, but for some reason the guy the billionaires like is going to walk away with more delegates.

Bernie Sanders sounds dangerous for our country.  His free stuff policy appeals to the young and naive who do not realize that there is no such thing as a free lunch. This is very frightening and I do not think Bernie Sanders followers understand this.  Those supporting Mr. Sanders should visit Venezuela to see the truth about socialism. “We’d have to have people doing analyses of Medicare for All...”

It has been puzzling why Elizabeth Warren was forced to present analysis of where the money to fund Medicare for All, but Mr. Sanders was not asked to so. 

Instead of left and right, in this era of trillion dollar deficits, let’s focus on common sense. Any costly proposal - Medicare for All, relieving student debt - should require inclusion of its funding sources.

Shocking that this column makes no mention of Elizabeth Warren, who has detailed, thoughtful plans for actually accomplishing many of the same progressive ideas and goals of Bernie, while still having the temperament and inclusive vision to unite this country. (Not to mention better health, a much smaller/more widely relatable track record for Republicans to shred, and in fact a better track record at actually implementing the sort of major change Sanders trumpets.) 

Sanders has encouraged his supporters into an often vicious cult of personality and conspiracy theorists, not unlike Trump’s MAGA hat army. If it were truly about the leftist policies and change desired, every single Sanders supporter would be fully willing to also support Warren. The fact that so many of them would instead pout and sit home speaks volumes. Too many of them don’t want to build a better America for us all, they want to burn it down for everyone, just like Trump’s fans, mainly comfortable in their privilege that the worst of the destruction won’t impact them. Disappointing.

 It is the party establishment that sets the rules of the convention.  And it is not going down without a fight

Interesting.   When I started online in the 90s, I found such great pleasure in communicating with people across the world, about mutual interests no matter how obscure or arcane.  Books, bands, silent films.. you could find your people and discuss things. On BBS's or Usenet or even early AOL or Compuserve (remember that?).

It was fairly placid, but it did indeed cross my mind that one day malevolence online could easily take hold.  No one wanted to be a troll- which were actually rare enough to be distinctive then, as opposed to legion infecting our whole information ecosystem.  I saw the possibility of such an unfortunate thing back then, but in the 90s felt false assurance that.. really awful people weren't "into computers" then, and could scarcely write coherent sentences. I wasn't that concerned that the internet could turn mean.
Flash forward, and everyone is "into computers", or online, a computer or smartphone is a household appliance. Kara, since almost the time that IT dinosaurs ruled the earth, there were – and still are – two fundamentally different zeitgeists to software acquisition…

One is end-user – often, but not always, consumer-level…

There, the victor is the one whose code runs as close to flawlessly and instantly as possible…

Even as Sergey and Larry cut their coding teeth on optimized search algorithms – they knew that minimizing end-user latency would open up exponentially-large new worlds to them…

Mark knew that lower latency was the key to displacing MySpace – and that it’d let FB compete with Google for revenue, once Google eventually figured out how to make revenue…

Jeff – his intergalactic-scale storefronts and back-office are whole comments unto themselves…

The other is classical competitive bidding and corporate procurement…

There, the victor is the one whose code is as obfuscated and entrenched as possible…

And, at that point – rather than striving for instant and flawless – the light goes on…

The realization that code that barely works and is years behind the need-curve is as exponentially-lucrative as that street-vendor-food consumer-level stuff…

2 ½ words:

Health Care IT

But what about AI – code for bots, written by bots…

Once you get away from the deep platforms that A, A, G, and M use for their – consumer-level – transaction and subscription services…

All gilding the lily – training botnets beyond diminishing returns…

But – lucrative gig work, if you can find it…

My wife and daughter are swimmers. In every competitive meet, there are multiple back-ups to verify the winner. First the touch pad, then timers (two) on every lane, each equipped with a stopwatch and plunger to mark finish time, and finally finish judges (again two), who record the order of finish among the swimmers if all else fails. The answer isn’t just a return to paper ballots (I’m from Chicago and remember when boxes of these might turn up in the trunk of an abandoned car well after the election). The author holds the title "Director of Family Engagement."  Seriously.

The type of parent described in this article has profoundly misunderstood the purpose of college. Faculty are there to EDUCATE students. They are NOT there to guarantee their success. These are different goals, and no one who believes the second will ever be satisfied with the first.

I’d love to hear from family engagement deans or college health center leaders on a more serious source of trouble for young adults than what is mentioned here.

As a parent, my great fear is for the 1/100 people or so who experience first psychosis or diagnosable depression / mania at college. You want to be hands-off as a parent, but serious psychiatric illness is not that uncommon. It’s manageable, with good diagnosis and support.  But un-caught, it can be worse than a heart attack and no less surprising. It often gets going for real in late teens early twenties.  It affects the brilliant and the bemused. Parents are lucky if their first alert is a “harmless” interaction with police, or a student in the ER. Not that common, you say - but if not your student, others in their class will suffer this.

Colleges are understandably shy to discuss student suicides or “medical” dropouts. But for parents, these are real nightmare monsters out there for this age group. Sometimes a parent can’t help - especially if a non- minor student doesn’t want them involved. But sometimes early family support can be life-saving, or even just a small raft in a sea of what can feel like a disorienting catastrophe. When a student’s life path takes that kind of turn, staying at college may or may not be in the cards. But can there more than risk, stigma, and liability-anxious institutional silence for them and for their family?

I'm surprised the dean doesn't understand that parents do this sort of thing not because they think they're kids can't, but because they KNOW that the adults on the other end of a child's issues will absolutely give more weight to a fellow Adult.

My parents dropped me off at university, wrote the checks and beyond that everything was my own job to figure out. 

I got to watch nearly all my classmates apply late for classes and internships and have their issues resolved by parents. When I, as an 19 year old girl, tried to advocate for myself I was absolutely talked down to, ignored, and generally treated like I was useless.

I had an apartment with black mold. I followed all the steps, called everybody I was supposed to from the school and housing office, then from legal. Nothing. "We can't take this on right now."

Took my dad one call. 

Parents understand full well that middle age confers a sense of peer group respect from college admin that even the most articulate students won't have.

Here's another sure fire tip:

Don't waste money sending your kid to college, if you turn around and vote for federal office holders on the basis of looks or money, without noticing whether they are factually challenged about the geographical location of Kansas City, MO.

We Americans love to preach about the value of education, but at the same time we love to pick on the nerds and thinkers. 

If you're determined to prove me wrong, vote for Elizabeth Warren. She committed the cardinal sin of actually explaining the details of what she'd do to improve the country. I'll predict that will doom her, but give her some kudos anyway.

I used to go over to my daughter's dorm once a month for an hour on Friday night. I brought great snacks. One girl said that she a a D in Biology and she did not know what to do about it. I told her to take it over. I explained that I was terrible in Spanish so I first audited a class and then took it for credit. I basically took every class twice and I got A's. This is how much effort it took me to learn Spanish. I still can not speak it. Sensible problem solving is what a kid needs. (She took the class over and got an A.)

What to do when your student needs small, easy-to-do accommodations for a diagnosed disability? Can't talk to anyone at the college/university. Student with disability gets the run-around and pushed out the door. Really, helicopter parent?! When does post-secondary start getting the scrutiny that K-12 does?

As much as the university, or any other creditor, would prefer I drop junior off at their doorstep with my AMEX gold card and the happy declaration "Have fun! See you in the Spring," Um, that's not going happen.

And if the over priced administrator at the office of family engagement  whose job it is to 'handle me' after junior informs me via text that I need to tack on another semester to his college career because  his required courses are full,  she better be prepared to earn her check.

Some of these parents know from hard experience exactly how little other adults care and how little effort other adults are willing to make in order to do the right thing.  And they know that their kids don’t have the information they need, and that the adults in charge will take advantage of that asymmetry. 

I wish someone had helped me, and I’m not going to not help my kids.

I am a proud member of the Barnard class of 1963. When I was in elementary school and high school my mother interfered continually, often making a bad situation worse. During my time at Barnard, I made a point of not telling my mother when I had a problem, which mostly kept her out of my hair. When I was in grad school in England, I made the mistake of telling her my supervisor’s name. I can’t prove she ever called him (at a time when transatlantic calls were very expensive), but after a certain date he began many meetings with me by inquiring “And how IS your mother?” causing me to want to drop through the floor. I suspect she called him to complain that I didn’t confide in her enough!

Director of Family Engagement??   
Another reason for the high price tag.  And part of the problem.

Worth mentioning, too, is that over-involvement of parents perpetuates equity issues at many schools, too. The faculty and instructors who respond to these interventions are disproportionately women, who are then disproportionately criticized for not being sufficiently nurturing, compassionate, or understanding when they decline to accommodate unrealistic expectations.

Cultivating independence is easier if the parents don't have much ability to help. My son  let me know that, due to school bureaucracy, his work-study job hadn't paid him in weeks. He was struggling to pay rent and resorting to stealing food. But informing me didn't help him -- I'm still scraping together this month's rent here, and will have a grand total of $24 to live on after it's paid, so I have nothing extra to share with him. I suggested he look for another job ASAP. I have two myself, and they keep me from having the time to phone the college to complain on his behalf. I supppse that's the upside of income inequality!
Why is there a department call Family Engagement? Doesn't she see that having this office is also part of the problem?

I question whether it really “stems from love.” 

I think it stems from control and self-absorption. If it stemmed from love, then they’d respect their adult children, wouldn’t they?

1. Tell them not to take student loans
2. Encourage trade school
3. Tell them to get a job while they are in their post secondary education.
4. Ensure (if they decide to stay in a college environment) to study a STEM field and ONLY a STEM field.

I had just read a few articles on "helicopter parenting" right around the time my 9 year old daughter joined a travel soccer team that cost LOTS of money and monopolized our weekends for the next 4 years.  We did it solely because my daughter was both very good at, and very interested in, soccer.  I came from a lower middle class background where I played sports but with little parental support.  I was shocked at other parents on the travel team and the way they bulldozed coaches, referees and other parents on the team.  I instinctively knew, reinforced by reading the "helicopter" articles, that they were doing major long term damage to their kids.  So much so that I finally got my daughter away from the whole sordid situation.  The amount of pig headed bullying and screaming at referees, demands that their kid always be playing to the point of MONETARY BRIBES etc. was mind boggling.  When we got out I told my wife I knew exactly which kids were going to fall apart in the next few years. Two of those names have been thru drug rehab and are still "partying", one flunked out of school and has apparently been abandoned by her formerly helicopter parents and one is flunking junior college and injured a friend when she totalled the new Lexus while drunk  her parents gave her last year .  My daughter just graduated from a Masters program 6 weeks ago and has multiple lucrative job offers.  But yet those parents had absolutely no self awareness of what they were doing to their kids!

I have two daughters. 
When my daughter was in school. If she did problems totally wrong. I would help her to correct it. I am not particularly interested in standing in at eight to the school. When they can send me a B or C or not good enough. I watch their homework. When they made errors I am allowed it. I wanted the teacher to correct it as part of the system.

I never ever cleaned their rooms. Or demanded that they do it. In fact I would call and say the room look like it belong in the modern museum of art!  They will. And they certainly learned as they left the house to straighten their rooms and organize it.

With the cash and gifts they had. I always made them by their mother and father a gift from their cash. They did then. And they do now.

Some people call their kids gifted!  Some students are stem. Advanced students. My daughters were, well within their norm.  People certainly want to tell me how gifted their students are.

Coming from a large family. We were all invited at Christmas, Thanksgiving at Cetera. We declined. We made our own dinner for ourselves, And my kids learned how to cook.

We certainly have our own disagreements. We argue and discuss. When someone sees a comment from one of my daughters. They say do you allow it. I certainly do. Because that is the way I taught them to be independent.

My two daughters are very successful.  And we are a family.
Great writing and insights.  I think Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan had to wait until Helen's voice was acceptable by the people in admissions, before she could enter.

I accepted a position to teach at a 'student-centric' campus in the early 1990's, impressed with the commitment of the administration and faculty for going to extra lengths to connect individually with students to guide their success.  
I began my college experience at a very competitive SUNY StonyBrook in the mid-1970s, where there was no coddling, but a rich cultural and academic life for students willing to make the required sacrifices.  
In my new faculty position, I was proud of how we helped our students, many of whom were the first in their families to attend college.  We were given ample administrative support to do our course preparations, community service, and still work closely with students.  Once state budgets and enrollments began their precipitous declines, faculty support was virtually eliminated while every imaginable entertainment and comfort was offered to attract and keep students. Rather than foster responsibility by enforcing deadlines or limited seats, faculty were advised to be more flexible with due dates, allow re-takes on exams, and basically accept drivel for assignments while minimizing actual criticism of punctuation, grammar, or spelling.  Students sporting expensive tattoos would let us know they couldn't afford their textbooks or paper for printing out assignments.  Working all night to pay for tuition and then sleeping through, or missing class was to be 'worked out.'  Basically, no accountability at all for this new generation of students.

I went to Barnard.  My first roommate was a nightmare.  Her boyfriend moved into our room on Day 1 and they had sex constantly, even when I was in the room.  I came back from class one day and the boyfriend was wearing my shower shoes and bathrobe.  I took to spending as much time as possible at places other than my dorm room.  Without asking, my mother called the school and I was immediately assigned a new roommate who was a much better match for me.  I am grateful my mother did that.  At that age of 18, I didn't know how to navigate that situation.  I doubt that the Dean of Residential Life would have acted so quickly had I been the one to advocate for myself.

I could not disagree more with Tintin. After working for almost 30 years in higher education, I am astonished that this dean's advice is not taken as just plain common sense. If one's college age children don't have adequate emotional independence, problem solving skills, and resilience by this point in their lives, it is a clear sign the parents have not grown either.

My favorite professor once told me a story of an excited mother--wearing hair curlers, so you can imagine the date--appearing at the door of a lecture where her son was in attendance. When she came in and tried to engage the professor about her child, the prof merely pointed and said, "Madam, the door."

​When my oldest kid was in kindergarten, my husband wanted to go speak to her teacher because she got a "satisfactory" in reading instead of an "outstanding." I get where he was coming from. My daughter was reading at 3 and literally read the NYTimes at home in K. But my point to him was, WHO CARES? It's kindergarten! We knew she was doing well. She could get unsatisfactory in every single subject and it would have zero effect on her life. 

I took the opportunity to share with my husband my philosophy on the subject of intervening at school. I am not going to be "that parent." The principal will see me when my child is at risk of physical or serious emotional harm. Otherwise, school is their domain and home is ours. My kids are 10, 12 and 14 and doing well. I have yet to find cause to contact the teachers or principal. When it comes to these parenting issues, less is more.

The thinking behind this is generous and quite kind, especially when the author writes that parents are doing this out of love. But I disagree. It has been my experience that parents who interfere are doing it mainly out of self-interest and living vicariously through their children. It's the same reason that the celebs bribed to get their kids into prestigious colleges; that wasn't about love, either. It's about bragging rights and co-dependence. Considering that young men and women of 18 who do not have money to go to college often end up fighting our wars, I find it shocking that parents would so coddle their children who are similarly aged but socially privileged and emotionally swaddled. Maybe these children should take a few gap years to grow up -- and their parents, too.  And maybe universities should ask for evidence of emotional maturity, compassion, ability to problem solve and analyze instead of looking at what ZIP code or private school the applicant comes from. I'd bet that most of these instances involve very, very well-to-do kids.

Ms Friedman wrote "When a student isn’t able to register for a class because it’s full, for example, her exasperated father might call to inform me that the administration needs to open more sections of the course so there will be an open seat for his child. And when I explain that no one is available to teach an additional section, the common response from dads is, “Well, then you need to hire more instructors.”
People who work and teach at universities know that the institution is funneling an innordinate proportion of tuition money towards administrative, human resources, student life services. I think it is shameful that university departments have to struggle so hard to get adequate funds for hiring instructors to meet the demand for classes or sections. The father who is disparaged in her account was actually doing the right thing. More parents need to get the universities to prioritize instruction. Good job Dad...

Parents, this right here is why your kids cant make a doctors appointments.  Please dont call a college dean to fix your kids problems.  Your kid didnt get the class they wanted 9/10x because they registered for it late.  I would have been mortified if my dad had called my college to complain about my schedule.  If your kid is actually in trouble of course you should step in and try to help, but not for the small things.  Even at a small private college its unlikely that a dean has much more then a cursory relationship with the dean unless they are having academic or social problems.  Call your kid not their professors.

This op-ed reflects a common scam on the part of expensive colleges: Try to shame paying customers into being more passive and less expectant regarding their financial outlay, acting as if the parents are overly intrusive and hovering for wanting their money's worth.  Notice that the dean writing this piece comes from a college that charges more than $65,000 a year in tuition, room, and board.  Wouldn't it be convenient to shame parents into asking less for their money so the college can be even less accountable?  What better than to charge exorbitant tuition and not have to worry about those paying the bills actually expecting something.  This is nonsense.
